relating to the eradication or destruction or removal of such weeds, garbage,
refuse, public nuisances and/or unsightly or deleterious objects or structures,
the inspector shall employ all necessary assistance to cause such materials to
be removed or destroyed at the expense of the City.
   B.   Itemized Statement: The inspector shall prepare an itemized statement
of all expenses incurred in the removal and destruction of said materials,
including administrative expenses, and shall mail a copy thereof to the owner
or occupant, or both, demanding payment within thirty (30) days of the date of
mailing. Said notice shall be deemed delivered when mailed by certified mail
addressed to the property owner's last known address according to the records
of the Millard County Recorder.
      1.   Said statement shall include the address of the City Treasurer as
the place to make payment.
      2.   The statement shall also notify the property owner that failure to
pay the expenses may result in a lien on the property in accordance with Utah
Code Ann. § 10-11-4.
      3.   The statement shall also notify the property owner that the property
owner may file a written objection to all or part of the statement within 20
days after the day of the statement post-mark.
   C.   Failure To Make Payment: In the event the owner or occupant fails to
make payment of the amount set forth in said statement to the City Treasurer
within said thirty (30) days and fails to file a written objection within the
time limit set forth above, the City either may cause suit to be brought in an
appropriate court of law or may refer the matter to the County Treasurer as
provided in subsection (5) of this Section and Utah Code Ann. §10-11-4.
   D.   The City may file notice of a lien with the Millard County Recorder
indicating the City intends to certify the unpaid costs and expenses with the
Millard County Treasurer in accordance with Utah Code Ann. §§10-11-3 & 4.
   E.   Collection:
      1.   Lawsuit: In the event collection of expenses of destruction and
removal are pursued through the courts, the City shall sue for and receive
judgment for all of said expenses of destruction and removal, including
administrative costs, together with reasonable attorney fees, interest and
court costs and shall execute upon said judgment in the manner provided by law.
      2.   Taxes: In the event that the City elects to refer the expenses of
destruction or removal to the County Treasurer for inclusion in the tax notice
of the property owner in accordance with the provisions of Utah Code Ann. §
section 10-11-4, as amended, the recalcitrant owner shall be subject to such
powers as are thereby granted.
   F.   If the property owner files a timely objection to the statement, the
City shall:
      1.   Hold a public hearing in accordance with Title 52, Chapter 4 of Utah
Code Ann. (The Utah Open and Public Meetings Act.)
      2.   The City Council shall conduct the hearing and at said hearing shall
determine the actual cost of abatement, if any.
      3.   The city shall mail or deliver notice of the hearing date and time
to the property owner.
      4.   The property owner shall pay any actual cost due after the decision
of the City council to the City Treasurer within 30 days after the hearing is
held.
      5.   If the property owner fails to pay within 30 days after the hearing,
the City may pursue collection as set forth in (5) "collection" above. (Ord.
21-14, 9-7-2021)
TITLE 5
PUBLIC SAFETY
CHAPTER 1
FIRE DEPARTMENT AND FIRE SAFETY
SECTION:
5-1-1: Department Created
5-1-2: Fire Chief
5-1-3: Membership
5-1-4: Command At Fires
5-1-5: Duties Of Department And Members
5-1-6: Records Maintained
5-1-7: Fire Related Crimes
5-1-8: Services Outside City
5-1-9: Enforcement; Penalty
5-1-1: DEPARTMENT CREATED:
There is hereby created and established a voluntary Fire Department, consisting
of a Chief, and such other members as may from time to time be provided for by
the bylaws of the Fire Department. Except as provided in this chapter, the Fire
Chief and members shall be appointed in the manner provided by the bylaws of
the Fire Department. The department shall be part of the County Fire District,
but shall remain accountable to the City Council. The City Council shall have
authority to override the department's bylaws and remove the Fire Chief by two-
thirds (2/3) majority of the City Council. (1995 Code § 3-1-101)
5-1-2: FIRE CHIEF:
The Fire Chief shall have the control of the Fire Department and all fire
equipment belonging to the City. Whenever any fire equipment needs repairing,
the Fire Chief shall cause the repair to be done without delay. (1995 Code § 3-
1-102)
5-1-3: MEMBERSHIP:
The Fire Department shall have power to fix its number of members. (1995 Code §
3-1-104)
5-1-4: COMMAND AT FIRES:
In case of fire, the Fire Chief and his or her assistants shall rank in the
order named and the officer of the highest rank at the fire shall take command
of the Fire Department, and direct the management thereof for the suppression
of the fire, in the best manner possible; and when it may be necessary for the
protection of other property and to prevent the spread of the fire, the officer
in command may cause buildings to be removed, torn down or destroyed in the
best manner possible. (1995 Code § 3-1-103)
5-1-5: DUTIES OF DEPARTMENT AND MEMBERS:
The Fire Department and all its members shall hold the duty of extinguishing
all accidental or destructive fires and to prevent the occurrence or spread of
such fires. The Fire Department shall also use its emergency equipment in any
other manner approved of by the City Council. (1995 Code § 3-1-106)
5-1-6: RECORDS MAINTAINED:
The Fire Chief shall keep or cause to be kept a record of all meetings of the
department and the attendance of the members, a record of all fires, and file
with the City Recorder a full report of such records and attendance and fires.
(1995 Code § 3-1-105)
5-1-7: FIRE RELATED CRIMES:
   A.   False Alarms: It shall be unlawful to give or cause to be given false
alarms for fires or other emergencies involving the Fire Department. This
includes, but is not limited to, using the fire siren, ringing bells,
discharging fire warning systems, and any other means of intentionally creating
a false alarm to summon the Fire Department or warn the public. (1995 Code § 3-
1-201)
   B.   Interfering With Fire Equipment: It shall be unlawful to wilfully
injure or deface any fire equipment of the City. This shall include the wilful
driving of a vehicle over any fire hose of the City. (1995 Code § 3-1-202)
   C.   Obstruction Of Fire Safety: It shall be unlawful to wilfully interfere
with or obstruct the Fire Department's performance of its duties, either during
a fire or during a fire drill. (1995 Code § 3-1-203)
   D.   Intentionally Or Negligently Cause Fires: It shall be unlawful to
wilfully ignite or cause to be ignited any trees, shrubs, cultivated crops,
fences, buildings or other property on any land not his own, or to throw away
any burning object on any land which will carry fire. (1995 Code § 3-1-204)
   E.   Following Fire Vehicle: It shall be unlawful to intentionally follow or
otherwise pursue any fire truck or other emergency vehicle that is being used
to put out fires or any other type of emergency. (1995 Code § 3-1-205)
5-1-8: SERVICES OUTSIDE CITY:
Members of the Fire Department may go outside the corporate limits of the City
for the purpose of rendering aid to other Fire Departments or of extinguishing
fires or rendering aid in the case of accidents; provided, that the Fire
Department shall not render such service outside the corporate limits except
upon the order of either the Fire Chief or the Mayor. (1995 Code § 3-1-107)
5-1-9: ENFORCEMENT; PENALTY:
It shall be the duty of all officers of the Fire Department to see that the
provisions of this chapter are enforced and to arrest any person who shall be
found violating any provision of this chapter, or who shall hinder, resist or
refuse to obey any such officer in the discharge of his duty. Violations of
this chapter shall be a Class B misdemeanor, subject to penalty as provided in
title 1, chapter 4 of this Code. (1995 Code § 3-1-108; amd. 2019 Code)
CHAPTER 2
EMERGENCY PREPAREDNESS DEPARTMENT
SECTION:
5-2-1: Department Created
5-2-2: Administration
5-2-1: DEPARTMENT CREATED:
There is hereby created the Department of Emergency Preparedness. This
department shall serve the purpose of aiding the residents of the City in
emergency preparedness by providing education and any other programs deemed
appropriate by the City Council. (1995 Code § 3-3-101)
5-2-2: ADMINISTRATION:
   A.   The Mayor, with the advice and consent of the City Council, shall
appoint a Department Administrator.
   B.   The Department Administrator may be appointed to serve, either in a
voluntary capacity, or may be compensated at a rate determined by the City
Council. The Department Administrator shall carry out the acts requested by the
City Council with relation to emergency preparedness. (Ord. 98-01, 1-20-1998)
CHAPTER 3
ANIMAL CONTROL
SECTION:
5-3-1: Definitions
5-3-2: Animal Control Officer
5-3-3: Dog Licensing
5-3-4: Kennels
5-3-5: Animal Care And Control
5-3-6: Communicable Diseases
5-3-7: Vicious Dogs
5-3-8: Hybrid Animals
5-3-9: Financial Responsibility For Damages
5-3-10: Impoundment
5-3-11: Public Nuisances
5-3-12: Penalty
5-3-1: DEFINITIONS:
The following words and phrases used in this chapter shall have the following
meanings unless a different meaning clearly appears from the context:
ANIMAL AT    Any animal, whether licensed or unlicensed, off the premises of the owner
LARGE:       and not under the control of the owner, a member of the owner's immediate
             family or his agent either by leash, cord, chain or otherwise.
ANIMAL       The officer appointed by the City Council to enforce the provisions in this
CONTROL      chapter.
OFFICER:
             Any bite, attempted bite or similar fierce behavior by an animal which
ATTACK:      places a person or another animal in danger of immediate physical harm.
             Actual physical contact is not required to constitute an attack.
BITE:        An actual puncture, tear or abrasion of the skin, inflicted by the teeth of
             an animal.
             Any animal which:
             A. Has demonstrated aggression or hostility toward a human without
             provocation or has a known propensity to show aggression or hostility toward
             humans; or
             B. Has attacked, inflicted injury, assaulted, or bitten without provocation
DANGEROUS    any domestic animal or fowl, protected wildlife, or animal owned or kept
ANIMAL:      with a legal permit on public or private property on two (2) or more
             occasions or on the first bite causes serious bodily injury or death.
             Serious bodily injury is defined as an injury that involves a substantial
             risk of death, unconsciousness, extreme physical suffering, obvious
             disfigurement, or prolonged loss or impairment of the function of a limb or
             organ.
DOG:         Any male or female dog of any age.
             Animals accustomed to living in or about the habitation of man, including,
DOMESTIC     but not limited to, cats, dogs, ferrets and livestock. Domestic animals,
ANIMALS:     however, shall not include reptiles or animals which require a permit from
             the Utah Department of Wildlife Resources in order to own or keep.
ENCLOSURE:   Any structure that prevents an animal from escaping its primary confines.
FIERCE:      Violent, hostile or aggressive temperament.
             An animal, however tame or docile, that is the offspring of a breeding
HYBRID:      between a domestic animal and a wild animal, a domestic animal and a hybrid,
             or two (2) hybrid animals.
IMPOUNDMENT  Having been received into custody of the City pound or into the custody of
OR           any authorized or representatives of the City.
IMPOUNDED:
NONFARM      All animals except horses, cattle, sheep, swine, goats, rabbits and fowl.
ANIMALS:
             An animal that:
             A. Frequently runs at large;
             B. Damages, soils or defecates on private property other than property
             possessed or controlled by the animal owner or on public walks and
NUISANCE:    recreation areas, unless such waste is immediately removed and properly
             disposed of by the animal owner or handler;
             C. Causes unsanitary or dangerous conditions;
             D. Causes a disturbance by excessive barking or other noisemaking; or
             E. Chases vehicles or interferes with persons or other domestic animals on
             public property.
             When applied to the proprietorship of a dog, shall mean any person or
OWNER:       persons, firm, association or corporation owning, keeping or harboring a
             dog.
             Any deliberate act by a person toward a dog or any other animal done with
             the intent to tease, torment, abuse, assault or otherwise cause a reaction
PROVOKE:     by the dog or other animal; provided, however, that any act by a person done
             with the intent to discourage or prevent a dog from attacking or molesting
             shall not be considered provocation.
             Any animal under the physical control of its owner or the owner's agent
             having charge, care, custody or control of the animal, by the means of a
RESTRAINT:   leash, tether or other physical control device or enclosure. Animals upon
             real property of their owner, or upon the real property of another (with
             prior permission of the property owner) and under direct adult supervision,
             shall be considered under restraint.
UNLICENSED   A dog for which the license for the current year has not been paid, or to
DOG:         which the tag which is required under this chapter is not attached.
             Any animal which:
             A. Has attacked, inflicted injury, assaulted, or bitten a human without
             provocation or has a know propensity to attack, inflict injury, assault, or
VICIOUS      bite a human; or
ANIMAL:      B. Is trained or used to fight or to attack humans.
             Whether an animal has been properly licensed under the provisions of this
             chapter shall have no relevance to the determination of whether an animal is
             a “dangerous animal” or a "vicious animal", as defined herein.
             Any animal of a species that in its natural life is usually untamed and
WILD ANIMAL: undomesticated, including hybrids, and animals which, as a result of their
             natural or wild condition, cannot be vaccinated for rabies.
WITHOUT      An animal was not teased, tormented or abused; or the animal was not
PROVOCATION: protecting its owner or owner's property from criminal activity by a
             perpetrator of a crime.
             To harass or intimidate by barking or baring of teeth, growling, shaking or
             tearing with the teeth; or approaching any person or domestic animal in an
WORRY:       aggressive behavior which would cause a reasonable person to feel they were
             in danger of immediate physical attack. (Ord. 19-01, 1-3-2019; amd. Ord. 19-
             05, 6-18-2019; Ord. 21-10, 6-15-2021)
 
5-3-2: ANIMAL CONTROL OFFICER:
   A.   Authority And Duty: The position of animal control officer is hereby
created. The animal control officer of the City and other persons designated by
the City Council shall have authority and responsibility to enforce the
provisions of this chapter. This authority includes, but is not limited to:
      1.   Carry out and enforce the provisions of this chapter;
      2.   Take into possession and impound all dogs running at large and
dispose of the same as hereinafter provided;
      3.   Enforce the licensing and control of all dogs within the City as
hereinafter provided;
      4.   Provide for a good and sufficient pound in which all animals duly
committed to the animal control officer's charge or otherwise impounded by him/
her shall be maintained;
      5.   Issue citations for violations of this chapter and to swear out
complaints for such violations when necessary;
      6.   Enter privately owned land to investigate reports of violations of
this chapter;
      7.   Enter privately owned land to take possession of any animal that
enters such land during hot pursuit;
      8.   Impound and destroy animals in accordance with the provisions of
this chapter;
      9.   Destroy animals, upon request of the animal's owner, in a humane
manner.
   B.   Fees For Services: The animal control officer shall charge, and the
owners of animals taken into his/her possession for impound, disposal or other
services shall pay such fees and charges for services performed by the pound or
animal control officer as the City Council shall establish from time to time by
resolution.
   C.   Interference With Officer Prohibited: It shall be unlawful for any
person to interfere, hinder or obstruct, in any manner, the animal control
officer or any of his/her authorized representatives from discharging his or
her duties as herein prescribed. (Ord. 19-01, 1-3-2019)
5-3-3: DOG LICENSING:
   A.   License Required:
      1.   It shall be unlawful for any person to own or otherwise harbor a dog
within the City limits which has attained the age of six (6) months, unless
until such dog has been properly licensed according to the provisions set forth
in this chapter. Persons who acquire dogs who are over six (6) months of age
shall have ten (10) calendar days from the date of acquisition to acquire the
appropriate license. Persons who move to the City shall have ten (10) calendar
days from the date of arrival to license any dog that is over the age of six
(6) months.
      2.   Applications for registration and licensing shall be made to the
City staff or such other person as the City Council may authorize.
      3.   At the time an application is made for such license, the owner shall
provide the City his/her name and address, and the breed and color of each dog
owned or kept by him/her.
      4.   A dog that has been deemed vicious shall not be licensed in the
City. A dog licensed in the City that is determined to be a vicious dog shall
have its license revoked.
   B.   Fee; Renewal; Penalties:
      1.   The City Council shall have the power to set and change through
policy or resolution fee schedules for dog licensing, including delinquency or
penalty fees. No license shall be issued by the City until the appropriate
license fee is paid. The licenses shall be purchased at the City office.
      2.   All dog licenses shall expire on June 30 of each calendar year
without regard to when the license was purchased, unless renewed prior to that
date.
      3.   If a dog license is not renewed by June 30 of each year, the owner
of the dog shall have until August 31 of the current calendar year in which to
pay the renewal fee plus penalties. Otherwise, the dog shall be considered
unlicensed and the dog and owner shall be in violation of this chapter and
subject to the penalties set forth herein.
      4.   Dogs that are properly certified as guide dogs shall be licensed and
registered as other dogs hereinabove provided; except that the person who owns
or keeps such dog shall not be required to pay any fee therefor.
   C.   Tag And Collar: Upon payment of the license fee, the City shall issue
to the owner a payment receipt and a metallic tag for each dog so licensed. The
tag shall be changed every year and shall have stamped thereon the year for
which it was issued and the number corresponding with the number on the
receipt. Every dog owner shall affix each dog with a collar or harness to which
the current year's license is attached. In the event a dog tag is lost or
destroyed, a duplicate will be issued by the City upon presentation of a
receipt showing the payment of the license fee for the current year and the
payment set by resolution or policy for such duplicate tag.
   D.   Nontransferable: Dog license tags are nontransferable from one dog to
another, and no refunds shall be made on any dog license fee because of death
of the dog or the owner leaving the City before expiration of the license
period. (Ord. 19-01, 1-3-2019)
5-3-4: KENNELS:
   A.   Kennel Defined: As used in this chapter, "kennel" shall mean a premises
where more than four (4) dogs are housed or boarded.
   B.   Permit Required: It shall be unlawful to operate or maintain a kennel
without first obtaining a permit from the City.
   C.   Requirements: In order to obtain a kennel permit, the applicant for the
permit must demonstrate that the proposed kennel meets the following
requirements:
      1.   Enclosures must be provided which shall allow adequate protection
against the weather.
      2.   Floors of buildings, runs and walls shall be of an appropriate
material as required by the specific breed of dog and also to permit proper
cleaning and disinfecting.
      3.   Adequate ventilation shall be maintained and an appropriate
temperature provided as required by the specific breed of dog housed therein.
      4.   Each animal shall have sufficient space to stand up, lie down and
turn around without touching the sides or tops of cages.
      5.   Runs shall provide an adequate exercise area and protection from the
weather.
      6.   All animal quarters and runs are to be kept clean, dry and in
sanitary condition.
      7.   The food shall be free of contamination, palatable and of sufficient
nutritive value as to meet the normal daily requirements for the condition and
size of the animal.
      8.   Fresh water is to be available at all times. Water vessels shall be
mounted or secured in a manner that prevents tipping and shall be of the
removable type.
      9.   The proposed kennel must be one hundred fifty feet (150') from any
neighboring house and fifty feet (50') from any road.
   D.   Fee: The annual fee for a kennel permit shall be set forth in the City
Fee Policy.
   E.   Revocation: The City may revoke any kennel permit if the permit holder
is convicted of disturbing the peace or creating a public nuisance under this
chapter.
   F.   Kennel Inspections: The animal control officer or other authorized
person may enter any kennel to ensure compliance with this section. (Ord. 19-
01, 1-3-2019)
5-3-5: ANIMAL CARE AND CONTROL:
   A.   Conditions Of Ownership: It shall be unlawful to harbor or otherwise
keep any animal in the City unless the owner or other keeper of any animal
complies with the provisions of this chapter.
      1.   Animals shall be humanely treated at all times.
      2.   Animal premises shall be kept sanitary and shall not constitute a
fly breeding reservoir or source of offensive odors.
      3.   Animals and/or animal premises shall not be permitted to disturb the
peace or constitute a public nuisance or hazard.
   B.   Applicability To Nonresidents: Nothing in this chapter shall be
construed to affect persons not residing in the City, except that animals
belonging to nonresidents may not run loose within the City. (Ord. 19-01, 1-3-
2019)
   C.   Rabies Vaccination For Dogs:
      1.   It shall be unlawful for the owner of any dog to suffer, allow or
permit such dog to be or go upon any sidewalk, street, alley, public place or
public square within the City without first having had such dog vaccinated
every three (3) years against rabies, as provided in subsection C2 of this
section.
      2.   Every owner of any dog over the age of six (6) months within the
City shall have the dog vaccinated against rabies by a duly licensed
veterinarian; shall secure from the veterinarian a certificate thereof; and
shall attach to the collar or harness, which such person is hereby required to
place upon the dog, a tag showing that such dog has been so vaccinated. (Ord.
19-05, 6-18-2019)
   D.   Restraint Of Animal By Owner: Persons owning or otherwise keeping any
dog or other nonfarm animal shall at all times keep such animal on a leash or
within an enclosed area on the animal owner's property or the property of
another with permission of the owner thereof. Any animal set forth in this
subsection that is allowed to run at large shall be dealt with in accordance to
the provisions of this chapter.
   E.   Dogs Prohibited In Certain Public Places: It shall be unlawful for any
person owning or otherwise keeping a dog to permit such dog to enter any public
facility. Dogs trained for the specific purpose of assisting the disadvantaged
or disabled are an exception to this subsection. Police and other service dogs
are also an exception to this subsection.
   F.   Disturbing The Peace Prohibited:
      1.   It shall be unlawful to own or otherwise keep an animal in such a
manner that the peace and quiet of the public is unreasonably disturbed. In
addition to the provisions of section
5-3-12 of this chapter, a written complaint signed by three (3) persons who
have separate residences which expresses that an animal disturbs the peace and
quiet of such persons shall be prima facie evidence of a violation of this
subsection F; provided, however, that nothing contained in this subsection F
shall be construed to apply to reasonable noises emanating from legally
operated dog and cat hospitals, humane societies, pound facilities and farm or
agricultural operations.
      2.   The destruction of property by an animal other than property that
which belongs to the owner of the animal shall be prima facie evidence of a
violation of this subsection F.
   G.   Female Dogs In Season: Persons who own or otherwise keep a female dog
shall securely confine such dog within an enclosure in a manner that will
prevent the attraction of male dogs to the immediate vicinity while such dog is
in season; provided, however, that nothing in this subsection shall apply to
owners or keepers of dogs who intend to have a female dog bred while she is in
season.
   H.   Abandoning Animals: It shall be unlawful for any owner or keeper of an
animal to abandon such animal.
   I.   Removal And Disposition Of Dead Animals: It shall be unlawful for the
owner of any animal or fowl that dies or is killed within the City to fail to
remove or bury the carcass of such animal within ten (10) hours after its
death. No horse, cow, ox or other large animal shall be buried within the City
limits, but shall be disposed of properly at the designated City facility.
   J.   Rendering Assistance To Animals: Any person who, as the operator of a
motor vehicle, strikes a domestic animal, shall stop and render such assistance
as may be reasonably possible, and shall immediately report such injury or
death to the animal's owner; in the event the owner cannot be located, such
operator shall at once report the accident to the appropriate law enforcement
agency or the City office, or to the animal control officer.
   K.   Emergency Proclamation: The Mayor, upon reasonable apprehension of
danger from mad or rabid dogs, may issue a proclamation forbidding dogs of
every description from running at large, and after such proclamation has been
issued for twenty four (24) hours, any dog found running at large in the City,
not secured and muffled, may be immediately destroyed or caused to be destroyed
by the animal control officer.
   L.   Liability For At Large Animals: It is unlawful for the owner or person
having charge, care, custody or control of any animal to allow such animal to
be at large at any time within the corporate limits of the City. The owner or
custodian of any such animal which is at large shall be strictly liable for a
violation of this subsection, regardless of the precautions taken to prevent
the escape of the animal and regardless of the lack of knowledge of the offense
at the time it occurs, and will be charged an impound and care fee. (Ord. 19-
01, 1-3-2019)
   M.   Dogs Chasing Persons Or Animals: Dog owners and/or a person in charge
of a dog are in violation of this subsection if the dog they own or are in
charge of chases or worries any person, domestic animal, any species of hoofed
protected wildlife or any domestic fowl. (Ord. 19-05, 6-18-2019)
   N.   Keeping Wild Animals And Reptiles: It shall be unlawful to own or
otherwise keep animals or reptiles for which a permit is required by the Utah
Department of Wildlife Resources, unless the owner or keeper of such animal or
reptile first obtains a permit from the Utah Department of Wildlife Resources.
It shall be unlawful to own or otherwise keep a vicious wild animal within the
City limits.
   O.   Animal Waste: The owner of every animal shall be responsible for the
removal of any excreta deposited by his or her animals on public walks,
streets, recreation areas or private property belonging to another. (Ord. 19-
01, 1-3-2019)
5-3-6: COMMUNICABLE DISEASES:
   A.   Harboring Diseased Animals Prohibited; Disposal: No person shall
knowingly harbor or keep any animal afflicted with mange, ringworm, distemper
or any other contagious disease, unless such animal is, in the judgment of the
animal control officer or licensed veterinarian, being given adequate treatment
for such diseases. The animal control officer or licensed veterinarian may take
immediate possession of any such animal not being so treated and immediately
dispose of the animal, unless the owner forthwith places such animal under the
control and treatment of a licensed veterinarian.
   B.   Animal Bites; Reporting Required: All persons over the age of eighteen
(18) years who have knowledge, directly or indirectly, of a person being bitten
by a dog, cat, skunk, fox, bat, coyote, bobcat or other animal known to
constitute a serious threat of rabies shall notify the City office or the
animal control officer or County Sheriff as soon as is reasonably possible
after learning of the bite. The City office or animal control officer shall
likewise be notified of any person or animal bitten by a rabid or suspected
rabid animal.
   C.   Rabid Animals:
      1.   Any person who observes or who has knowledge of an animal which
shows symptoms of rabies, or which acts in a manner which would lead to a
reasonable suspicion that it may have rabies, shall notify the City office or
the animal control officer.
      2.   Any dog or other animal of a species subject to rabies which is
known to have bitten or injured any person so as to cause an abrasion of the
skin shall be placed in confinement under observation of a veterinary hospital
or the City pound and shall not be killed or released until at least ten (10)
days after the biting or injury has occurred in order to determine whether or
not the animal has rabies.
      3.   Any biting or rabid animal may be destroyed humanely after the ten
(10) day isolation period as set forth in subsection C2 of this section after
verification from a veterinarian that the animal is rabid.
      4.   Any animal that presents an immediate threat to persons or property
may be destroyed in a humane manner notwithstanding the provisions of this
chapter. (Ord. 19-01, 1-3-2019)
5-3-7: VICIOUS DOGS:
   A.   Defined: A dangerous dog is a dog which meets the definition of
dangerous animal as defined in section
5-3-1 of this chapter. A vicious dog is a dog which meets the definition of a
vicious animal, as defined in section
5-3-1 of this chapter.
   B.   Findings And Policy: The City Council finds that dogs occasionally
escape from the yard or building in which they are kept, by slipping under a
fence, jumping over a fence, slipping out through a door or gate temporarily
unlatched or open, breaking a leash or chain, or pulling up the anchor or the
chain or leash. It is the policy of the City that others should not have to
assume the risk of a dangerous or vicious dog having an opportunity to attack,
inflict injury, assault, bite or kill. The City Council finds there is a
difference between a dangerous dog and a vicious dog. The City Council further
finds that the benefits to a dog owner in owning a dangerous dog or vicious dog
do not outweigh the risks to the general public. As such, owners of a dog
classified as dangerous must comply with strict ownership requirements, or such
dog is prohibited from remaining in the City, and owners of a dog classified as
vicious must destroy the vicious dog in a humane manner or permanently remove
the vicious dog from the City limits.
   C.   Keeping a Dangerous Dog Requirements:
      1.   If the animal control officer finds a dog's behavior to constitute
that of a dangerous animal, such dog shall be so classified, and the owner of
the dog shall receive written notification of the classification.
      2.   Within two (2) weeks of notification of the dog's classification as
a dangerous animal, the owner will be required to sign an acknowledgment of the
classification and of the requirements of owning a dangerous animal.
      3.   Owning or caring for a dangerous animal.
         a.   A dangerous animal must be securely confined indoors or in a
securely enclosed and locked structure, suitable to prevent the animal from
coming into contact with a human being, other than the owner, or any other
animal, and designed to prevent the animal from escaping.
         b.   The owner shall prominently display a sign on the owner's
property at all entry points warning that there is a dangerous animal on the
property.
         c.   A dangerous animal may be off the owner's property or out of its
enclosure if it is restrained by a substantial chain or leash not exceeding six
feet (6') in length and under the control of a competent adult over the age of
eighteen (18) years.
         d.   An owner will be required to provide proof of liability insurance
with a minimum coverage of one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00). Such
insurance must be maintained and proof provided to the city upon request.
         e.   The owner of a dangerous animal shall immediately notify the
office of animal services when a dangerous animal is loose or unconfined; has
bitten a human being or attacked another animal; was sold, given away, or died;
or has been moved to another address. Prior to a dangerous animal being
transferred to a new owner or address, the owner shall notify the animal
control officer of the new or updated contact information. Each new owner is to
be given notice of the animal's classification as dangerous and, if said owner
resides within the city, shall comply with the provisions of this chapter.
         f.   The animal control officer shall have the authority to make
whatever inspections are deemed necessary to ensure compliance with the
provisions recited herein.
         g.   If this section is followed without issue for twelve (12) months,
an owner may petition for the removal of the classification of dangerous
animal. Following removal of the classification of dangerous animal, if the
animal is classified as dangerous again, the animal may be removed from city
limits indefinitely.
         h.   If unable to comply with the requirements of this section, the
owner of a dangerous animal shall have the option to destroy the dangerous
animal in a humane manner or permanently remove the dangerous animal from the
City limits.
      4.   A citation may be issued to the owner of any dangerous dog found in
violation of this section.
   D.   Keeping Vicious Dog Prohibited:
      1.   It shall be unlawful to own or otherwise keep a vicious dog. Dogs
held in violation of this section shall be deemed a public nuisance, and their
continued possession or ownership shall be unlawful. The animal control officer
shall impound any such dog that the animal control officer determines, after
investigation, to be a vicious dog.
      2.   The animal control officer shall notify the owner of any dog
impounded as a vicious dog. Three (3) days after notification of the owner (or
10 days after notification of the owner if a dog has bitten and needs to be
quarantined), the dog shall be destroyed in a humane manner, unless the
determination that the dog is vicious is appealed to court or unless the dog is
permanently removed from the City limits. Upon court determination that a dog
is vicious, the dog shall be destroyed in a humane manner or permanently
removed from the City limits. The dog owner shall pay all impound fees,
including care and feeding, for the period during which the dog is impounded.
To be permanently removed from City limits rather than be destroyed, the dog
owner shall submit a written statement verifying the dog will be removed from
City limits. Any dog that has been permanently removed from the City limits as
a vicious dog and is then picked up by the animal control officer shall be
destroyed in a humane manner.
      3.   Any unlicensed dog that has been kept within the City limits and has
been classified as vicious shall not be licensed.
   E.   Exemptions:
      1.   Nothing in this section shall prevent the reasonable keeping of a
guard dog or dogs for security. Guard dogs shall be kept in such a manner that
they cannot come into contact with other persons or animals that are legally
upon the premises where a guard dog is maintained. The property shall be posted
with a sign clearly visible stating that a guard dog is on the premises. Guard
dogs kept in violation of this subsection C shall be subject to the
determination that they are vicious dogs.
      2.   A dog that bites a person who is attempting a criminal act shall not
be a vicious dog.
      3.   A dog that bites or attacks on either private or public property
because the dog is provoked in some manner or is protecting its owner from harm
shall not be a vicious dog.
      4.   Trained police dogs shall not be considered vicious dogs. (Ord. 19-
01, 1-3-2019; amd. Ord. 21-10, 6-15-2021)
5-3-8: HYBRID ANIMALS:
   A.   Policy Declaration: Domestic dogs crossbred with wild animals are
considered by the State to be wild animals. The State has taken the stance that
there is no known effective rabies vaccine for wild animals, and although a
hybrid dog may have received a canine rabies vaccine, it is still considered to
be nonvaccinated. It is also a fact that the inbred vicious nature of wild
animals may be inherited by hybrid dogs.
   B.   Legislative Intent: This section is intended to utilize the authority
and powers of the City in order to secure the citizens of this City the
protection of their health, safety and welfare. The unique history, nature and
characteristics of the wild animal hybrid dog have been determined to make it a
vicious wild animal.
   C.   Hybrid Animals Prohibited: All hybrids are hereby declared vicious
animals, unless approval for them to be held and owned by a person is obtained
under subsection 5-3-5N of this chapter. No vicious animal shall be licensed or
kept within the City limits. (Ord. 19-01, 1-3-2019)
5-3-9: FINANCIAL RESPONSIBILITY FOR DAMAGES:
   A.   Policy Declaration: The City finds that the health, welfare and safety
of its citizens are paramount. If a dog escapes and causes damage to persons or
property within the City, the dog owner and/or person in charge of the dog at
the time the damage is caused shall be responsible for the damage caused by the
dog 1 .
   B.   Dog Owner To Take Financial Responsibility: It shall be unlawful for a
dog owner to fail to take financial responsibility for damages caused by their
dog. In addition, from the time of such failure, the dog owner shall have all
dog licenses which he has obtained revoked and may not own a dog within the
City for a period of five (5) years. Failure to take financial responsibility
means not making payments as required by a written agreement or failure to pay
court determined civil damages or court imposed restitution within one year of
the entry of judgment imposing the damages or ordering restitution. (Ord. 19-
01, 1-3-2019)
 
Notes
1 1. UCA § 18-1-1.
5-3-10: IMPOUNDMENT:
   A.   Duty To Impound: The animal control officer, law enforcement official,
or other designated official may apprehend any animal found running at large
and to impound such animal in the City pound or other suitable place. The
animal control officer or other designated official, upon receiving any dog,
shall make a complete registry, entering the breed, color and sex of such dog
and whether licensed. If licensed, he/she shall enter the name and address of
the owner and number of the license.
   B.   Interference With Impounding Prohibited: In addition to subsection 5-3-
2C of this chapter, it shall be unlawful for any person to hinder, delay,
interfere with or obstruct the animal control officer or any of his/her
assistants while engaging in capturing, securing or taking to the dog pound any
dog or dogs required to be impounded, or to break open or in any manner
directly or indirectly aid or abet the breaking open any dog pound or vehicle
used for collecting or conveying dogs to the dog pound.
   C.   Record Of Impounded Animals: The City shall designate an official who
shall keep a record of any impounded animal, the date of receipt of such
animal, the date and manner of its disposal and if redeemed, reclaimed or
purchased, the name and address of such person, the amounts of all fees
received or collected for or because of the impounding, reclaiming or
purchasing thereof, together with the number of any tag and the date of any tag
exhibited or issued upon the redemption or sale of such animal.
   D.   Redemption Of Impounded Animals: Any animal impounded as a licensed or
unlicensed dog may be redeemed and taken from such pound by the owner, the
owner's agent or any other authorized person, upon exhibiting to the person
having charge of said pound, a receipt as provided in section
5-3-3 of this chapter, showing that the license imposed by this chapter has
been paid for such dog and upon paying the person in charge of the pound an
impounding fee as set by the City Fee Policy for each and every day such dog
shall have been impounded or such other amounts as may be set by resolution or
policy of the City Council. All impounded animals not redeemed within five (5)
days may be euthanized.
   E.   Relinquishing Lost Or Stray Dogs:
      1.   It shall be unlawful to harbor or otherwise keep any lost or stray
dog licensed to another and kept without owner's knowledge for more than one
business day without notifying the City animal control officer. A dog shall be
deemed stray if it is not wearing a City license.
      2.   Upon notification or receipt of a lost dog bearing a current year's
license tag, the animal control officer or other authorized person, shall
within two (2) business days contact, by telephone or first class mail, the
owner of record, at the address indicated on the license form.
      3.   After notification as set forth in subsection E2 of this section,
the owner of an impounded dog shall have five (5) business days to collect the
animal and pay all applicable fees for housing and caring for the animal. After
the five (5) day period has expired, if no one has claimed it, the dog may be
returned to the person who found it if that person desires, or adopted by
another person without charge after licensing. Otherwise the animal shall be
destroyed in a humane manner.
   F.   Impound Fees: The owner of any impounded animal must pay, before the
animal is released, all applicable impound fees. All impound fees shall be set
by the City Council through the City Fee Policy. (Ord. 19-01, 1-3-2019)
5-3-11: PUBLIC NUISANCES:
   A.   Declaration Of Public Nuisance: Any animal that violates the provisions
of this chapter, or meets the definition of nuisance, as defined in section
5-3-1 of this chapter, shall be declared a public nuisance. Any owner whose
animal is declared a public nuisance may be cited and the animal may be
impounded. If the owner does not correct the violation within five (5) business
days of impoundment, the animal may be humanely destroyed. (Ord. 19-01, 1-3-
2019)
   B.   Warning Notice: Before issuing a citation, the animal control officer
or other authorized person shall issue a warning notice, describing the alleged
offense, the location, the ordinance or code section involved, and a statement
of what must be done to correct the violation. The notice shall state the date
by which such correction must be completed. Such date shall give five (5)
calendar days from the date of the notice; provided, that a shorter time shall
be specified if there is substantial immediate danger to persons or property. A
longer time than five (5) days shall be stated if there would be practical
physical difficulties in completing the correction within five (5) days and
there is no emergency. (Ord. 19-01, 1-3-2019; amd. 2019 Code)
   C.   Validity: Failure of the City to issue a warning as described in
subsection B of this section, shall not affect the validity of any prosecution
for an offense committed under this chapter.
   D.   Citation: If the condition has not been corrected within the time
specified in the warning notice, the animal control officer or other authorized
person shall issue a citation for the violation and impound the animal. The
citation shall state a date and time for a court appearance, and shall state
that the person accused may avoid the court hearing by correcting the violation
before the time of the hearing and by paying all impound fees in lieu of a fine
set by the court. (Ord. 19-01, 1-3-2019)
5-3-12: PENALTY:
Any person violating the provisions of this chapter shall be guilty of a Class
C misdemeanor, subject to penalty as provided in title 1, chapter 4 of this
Code. (Ord. 19-01, 1-3-2019; amd. 2019 Code)
CHAPTER 4
CRIMES AND OFFENSES
SECTION:
5-4-1: Criminal Code Adopted By Reference
5-4-2: Discharging Guns, Air Guns Or Other Weapons
5-4-1: CRIMINAL CODE ADOPTED BY REFERENCE:
Except insofar as the application thereof is clearly impractical or
inappropriate, in view of the context of purposes or penalty as provided, all
of the definitions, requirements, regulations, prohibitions, penalties,
provisions and sections of the Utah Criminal Code, Utah Code Annotated title
76, as amended, with a corresponding penalty of infraction, Class C misdemeanor
or Class B misdemeanor, are hereby adopted by the City. Any and all violations
thereof shall be considered violations of this section and each such violation
shall be subject to the penalties provided in title 1, chapter 4 of this Code.
(2019 Code)
5-4-2: DISCHARGING GUNS, AIR GUNS OR OTHER WEAPONS:
   A.   Prohibition: Except as otherwise provided herein, it shall be unlawful
for any person to discharge any gun, air gun, propellant type gun (including,
but not limited to, dart guns, etc.) or other dangerous weapons within the
incorporated limits of the City, or upon any City owned property.
   B.   Exceptions: Notwithstanding subsection A of this section, BB guns and
paintball guns may be used on private property within the City as follows:
      1.   By an adult property owner on his/her private property;
      2.   By a minor when accompanied by an adult property owner on his/her
private property;
      3.   By an adult tenant on the premises he/she is renting and with
written consent of the private property owner;
      4.   By a minor when accompanied by an adult tenant on the premises the
adult tenant is renting and with the written consent of the private property
owner.
   C.   City Owned Property:
      1.   Notwithstanding subsection A of this section and subject to the age
limits set forth in subsection B of this section, a person may discharge a
paintball gun on City owned property, provided such City owned property is
identified by the City Council and permission is first given by the City
Council.
      2.   In conjunction with subsection C1 of this section, the City shall
provide, upon request, information as to the locations where a paintball gun
may be properly discharged on City owned property. (Ord. 02-08, 7-16-2002)
   D.   Penalty: A violation of this section is a Class B misdemeanor, subject
to penalty as provided in title 1, chapter 4 of this Code. (Ord. 02-08, 7-16-
2002; amd. 2019 Code)
CHAPTER 5
COST RECOVERY FOR HAZARDOUS MATERIALS EMERGENCIES
SECTION:
5-5-1: Definitions
5-5-2: Recovery Of Expenses
5-5-3: Cost Recovery Procedures
5-5-4: Action To Recover Costs
5-5-5: Expenses Of Other Responding Entities
5-5-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter, the following terms, phrases and words shall
have the following meaning:
EXPENSES: All costs incurred for the response, containment and/or removal and
disposal of hazardous materials on initial remedial action. It includes, but is
not necessarily limited to, the actual labor costs of government and other
personnel, including workers' compensation benefits, fringe benefits,
administrative overhead and any costs of equipment, equipment operation,
materials, disposal and any contract labor or materials.
HAZARDOUS MATERIALS EMERGENCY: A sudden and unexpected release of any substance
that, because of its quantity, concentration, or physical, chemical or
infectious characteristics, presents a direct and immediate threat to public
safety or the environment and requires immediate action to mitigate the threat.
(Ord. 05-10, 8-2-2005)
5-5-2: RECOVERY OF EXPENSES:
   A.   Authorized: Those persons or entities whose negligent or intentional
actions cause or create, in whole or in part, a hazardous materials emergency
within the boundaries of the City is liable to the City for all costs and
expenses incurred in or arising from response to such hazardous materials
emergency by the City and any agency or cooperative entity. The City may
recover all such costs and expenses, including reasonable attorney fees,
litigation expenses and court costs incurred in, related to, or arising out of,
all cost recovery efforts and enforcement of the terms of this chapter.
   B.   Rate: All costs and expenses shall be billed the current rate
recommended by resolution of the Executive Committee of the Interlocal
Agreement for Cooperative Hazardous Materials Protection and Services, or at
the rate determined by the City Council or the City Fire Department, with the
consent of the City Council, on a case by case basis.
   C.   Payment No Admission Of Liability: The payment of expenses under this
section does not constitute an admission of liability or negligence in any
legal action for damages. (Ord. 05-10, 8-2-2005)
5-5-3: COST RECOVERY PROCEDURES:
   A.   Investigation Of Responsible Person: The City shall investigate and
determine the person or entity responsible for causing or creating the
hazardous materials emergency and shall notify the responsible party in writing
of said determination of responsibility and the amount of costs and expenses
incurred by the City in responding to the hazardous materials emergency.
   B.   Notice; Appeal: The notice shall specify that the party determined to
be responsible for causing or creating the hazardous materials emergency has
the right to appeal the decision determining responsibility to the City Council
and shall specify a deadline for filing the notice of appeal and the person or
office in which it must be filed. The deadline for filing the notice of appeal
shall not be less than fifteen (15) days from the date of the notice.
   C.   Hearing On Appeal: In the event a notice of appeal is filed, the
hearing before the City Council shall be an informal public hearing, and the
parties shall not be required to adhere to the Utah Rules of Civil Procedure or
Utah Rules of Evidence. The appealing party and the City shall each be entitled
to present evidence and argument in support of their respective positions, in
accordance with procedures established at the hearing by the City Council.
   D.   Decision Final: The decision of the City Council shall be final. (Ord.
05-10, 8-2-2005)
5-5-4: ACTION TO RECOVER COSTS:
In the event the responsible party fails or refuses to pay all of the costs and
expenses determined by the City related to or arising out of the City's
response to the hazardous materials emergency within thirty (30) days after
assessment, or after the City Council's decision on an appeal, the City may
initiate a legal action to recover such costs, including reasonable attorney
fees and costs. (Ord. 05-10, 8-2-2005)
5-5-5: EXPENSES OF OTHER RESPONDING ENTITIES:
   A.   Recovery Of Costs And Expenses By City: In the event that personnel and
equipment from other political subdivisions, agencies or cooperative entities
shall respond to assist with the hazardous materials emergency, then the City
may seek to recover costs and expenses incurred by such other political
subdivisions, agencies or cooperative entities as part of the City's recovery
efforts.
   B.   Reimbursement: Upon recovery of costs and expenses from the responsible
party, the City is authorized, if sufficient funds are available, to reimburse
such other political subdivisions, agencies or cooperative entities for their
actual costs incurred in responding to the hazardous materials emergency. (Ord.
05-10, 8-2-2005)
CHAPTER 6
CURFEW FOR MINORS
SECTION:
5-6-1: Authorized Adult Defined
5-6-2: Hours Regulated
5-6-3: Exceptions
5-6-4: Penalty
5-6-1: AUTHORIZED ADULT DEFINED:
"Authorized adult" shall mean any person over twenty one (21) years of age
authorized by a minor's parent, guardian or other legal representative, to
accompany said minor on public property after curfew. (Ord. 05-02, 2-15-2005)
5-6-2: HOURS REGULATED:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any minor seventeen (17) years of age and
under to be upon any sidewalk, street, alley or other public place in the City
between the hours of eleven o'clock (11:00) P.M. and five o'clock (5:00) A.M.
of the following day, of any day of the week Sunday through Thursday, unless
such person is accompanied by a parent, guardian or other authorized adult, as
defined in section
5-6-1 of this chapter, or whose employment makes it necessary to be upon the
streets during the night hours otherwise prohibited under this subsection.
   B.   On Friday and Saturday of any week, it shall be unlawful for any minor
seventeen (17) years of age and under to be upon any sidewalk, street, alley or
public place in the City between the hours of twelve o'clock (12:00) midnight
and five o'clock (5:00) A.M., unless such person is accompanied by a parent,
guardian or other authorized adult, or whose employment makes it necessary to
be upon the streets during the hours otherwise prohibited under this
subsection. (Ord. 05-02, 2-15-2005)
5-6-3: EXCEPTIONS:
Exceptions to curfew may be granted on a case by case basis by the City Council
for special events. (1995 Code § 10-6-106)
5-6-4: PENALTY:
It shall be a Class C misdemeanor, subject to penalty as provided in title 1,
chapter 4 of this Code, to violate any provision of this chapter. (1995 Code §
10-6-106; amd. 2019 Code)
TITLE 6
MOTOR VEHICLES AND TRAFFIC
CHAPTER 1
TRAFFIC CODE; GENERAL PROVISIONS
SECTION:
6-1-1: Definitions
6-1-2: Traffic Code Adopted By Reference
6-1-3: Obedience Required
6-1-1: DEFINITIONS:
Whenever the following terms are used in this title, they shall have the
following meanings:
ALLEY: A public way within a block generally giving access to the rear of lots
or buildings, and not used for general traffic circulation.
BICYCLE: Every device propelled by human power upon which any person may ride,
having two (2) tandem wheels, either of which is more than fifteen inches (15")
in diameter.
CROSSWALK: That portion of the roadway included between the sidewalk lines and
street intersections.
CURB: The lateral boundary of the roadway, whether such curb is marked by
curbing construction or not so marked.
DRIVER: Every person who drives or is in actual physical control of a vehicle.
EMERGENCY VEHICLE: Police vehicles, vehicles of the Fire Department,
ambulances, vehicles carrying a State, County or City officer or employee in
response to an emergency call, and emergency vehicles of public service
corporations on an emergency call.
PARK: To stand a vehicle whether occupied or not for a period of time greater
than is reasonably necessary for the actual loading and unloading.
TRICYCLE: Every device propelled by human power upon which any person may ride
having three (3) wheels, either of which is more than fifteen inches (15") in
diameter.
VEHICLE: Every device in, upon or by which any person or property is or may be
transported or drawn upon a highway, except devices moving by human power or
used exclusively upon stationary rails or tracks. (1995 Code § 9-1-101)
6-1-2: TRAFFIC CODE ADOPTED BY REFERENCE:
Except insofar as the application thereof is clearly impractical or
inappropriate, in view of the context of purposes or penalty as provided, all
of the definitions, requirements, regulations, prohibitions, penalties,
provisions and sections of the Utah Traffic Code, Utah Code Annotated title 41,
as amended, with a corresponding penalty of infraction, Class C misdemeanor or
Class B misdemeanor, are hereby adopted by the City. Any and all violations
thereof shall be considered violations of this section and each such violation
shall be subject to the penalties provided in title 1, chapter 4 of this Code.
(1995 Code § 9-2-101; amd. 2019 Code)
6-1-3: OBEDIENCE REQUIRED:
   A.   Authorized Law Enforcement: Members of the authorized law enforcement
agency are hereby authorized to direct all traffic in accordance with the
provisions of this title, or in emergencies as public safety or convenience may
require, and it shall be unlawful for any person to fail or refuse to comply
with any lawful order, signal or direction of a member of that office. Except
in case of emergency, it shall be unlawful for any person not authorized by law
to direct or attempt to direct traffic. (1995 Code § 9-2-102)
   B.   Fire Officials: The Fire Department officer in command, or any
firefighter designated by him, may exercise the powers and authority of a
member of the Sheriff's Office in directing traffic at the scene of any fire or
where the Fire Department has responded to an emergency call for so long as
Fire Department equipment is on the scene in the absence or in assisting the
Sheriff's Office. (1995 Code § 9-2-103)
CHAPTER 2
PARKING REGULATIONS
SECTION:
6-2-1: Prohibited Parking
6-2-2: Alley Parking
6-2-3: Privately Owned Parking Areas Serving Commercial Establishments
6-2-1: PROHIBITED PARKING:
   A.   Posted Restrictions: It shall be unlawful for any person, except
physicians on emergency calls or designated emergency vehicles, when properly
posted, to park any motor vehicle on any street in violation of the posted
restrictions.
   B.   Business Areas: It shall be unlawful to park any vehicle upon the
private parking areas of business owners other than during normal business
hours without the business owner's permission. (1995 Code § 9-3-101)
   C.   Commercial Zone On Main Street: It shall be unlawful to park any
vehicle overnight on Main Street in a Commercial Zone unless the adjoining
property is used for residential purposes or is regularly used in the normal
course of business for overnight guests. (Ord. 17-02, 3-16-2017)
   D.   Main Street Parking:
      1.   It shall be unlawful to park on Main Street in the areas and for the
times designated in the City Streets Policy. (Ord. 14-04, 11-4-2014)
      2.   It shall be unlawful to park on Main Street or other designated
parade route in the areas and for the times designated in the City Parade
Policy. (Ord. 17-02, 3-16-2017)
6-2-2: ALLEY PARKING:
No person shall park a vehicle within an alley in such a manner or under such
conditions as to leave less than ten feet (10') of the width of the roadway
available for the free movement of vehicular traffic. (1995 Code § 9-3-102)
6-2-3: PRIVATELY OWNED PARKING AREAS SERVING COMMERCIAL ESTABLISHMENTS:
   A.   Definitions: As used in this section:
    AUTHORIZED PERSONNEL: Shall include, but not be limited to, owners,
managers, lessors, lessees, employees and those people lawfully on the premises
by invitation or permission of such authorized personnel.
   OFFICIAL TRAFFIC CONTROL DEVICE: All signs, signals, markings and devices
placed or erected by authority of, or at the request of, a public body or
official having jurisdiction, for the purpose of regulating, warning or guiding
traffic.
   B.   Agreement To Allow Enforcement Of Parking Regulations On Private
Property: Those businesses who have agreed to allow enforcement of parking
regulations on private property have executed an agreement with the City,
giving its consent to such enforcement. A copy of each such agreement is on
file in the City office.
   C.   Unauthorized Parking On Certain Privately Owned Parking Lots:
      1.   It shall be unlawful for any person, except authorized personnel, to
stop, stand or park a vehicle, whether occupied or unoccupied, after business
hours, on the parking lots of those businesses who have entered into an
agreement with the City, or who may hereafter enter into an agreement with the
City, for the regulation of such parking on privately owned lots serving
Commercial Districts. (Ord. 98-06, 10-20-1998)
      2.   It shall be unlawful for any person to stop, stand or park a vehicle
any place where official traffic control devices prohibit stopping, standing or
parking on private property. (Ord. 98-06, 10-20-1998; amd. 2019 Code)
   D.   Property Owner Responsible To Post Signs:
      1.   The City may require each property owner, whose business
establishment is subject to this section, to post a sign, approved by the City,
prohibiting the stopping, standing or parking of any unauthorized vehicles on
business premises, after business hours.
      2.   Subsection D1 of this section is directive and is not mandatory.
Nothing shall prohibit law enforcement agencies from enforcing the provisions
of this section relating to those business establishments who have entered into
an agreement with the City, pursuant to subsection B of this section; nor shall
the requirement of posting said sign be deemed an element of an offense under
subsection C1 of this section. (Ord. 98-06, 10-20-1998)
   E.   Penalty: Violation of this section shall be an infraction, punishable
as provided in title 1, chapter 4 of this Code. (Ord. 98-06, 10-20-1998; amd.
2019 Code)
CHAPTER 3
OFF HIGHWAY VEHICLES
SECTION:
6-3-1: Definitions
6-3-2: Vehicles Operated On Public Land
6-3-3: Age Limitations
6-3-4: Protective Headgear Requirements; Owner Duty; Penalty For Violation
6-3-5: Use Of Privately Owned Lands Without Permission; Tampering With Signs Or
Fencing
6-3-6: Vehicles Operated On Designated Lands
6-3-7: Speed And Other Regulations
6-3-8: Penalty For Violation
6-3-1: DEFINITIONS:
The City hereby adopts the definitions set forth in Utah Code Annotated section
41-22-2, Off Highway Vehicles, and any successor statute and amendments thereto
and hereby incorporates same as part of this chapter. (Ord. 19-03, 2-19-2019)
6-3-2: VEHICLES OPERATED ON PUBLIC LAND:
Currently registered off highway vehicles may be operated on all City land,
streets, highways and trails, and the same are hereby designated as open to
such off highway vehicles use. It is unlawful to operate an off highway vehicle
along, across or within the boundaries of an interstate freeway, as defined by
State law. (Ord. 19-03, 2-19-2019)
6-3-3: AGE LIMITATIONS:
   A.   Under Eight Years: A person under eight (8) years of age may not
operate, and an owner may not give another person who is under eight (8) years
of age permission to operate an off highway vehicle on any public land, trail,
street or highway of this City.
   B.   Eight Years And Older: A person who is eight (8) years of age or older,
but under sixteen (16) years of age, may not operate and an owner may not give
that person permission to operate an off highway vehicle on any public land,
trail, street or highway of this City unless the person:
      1.   Has in the person's possession the appropriate safety certificate
issued by the State Division of Parks and Recreation; and, if under eighteen
(18) years of age, is under the direct supervision of a person who is at least
eighteen (18) years; or
      2.   Has in the person's immediate possession a valid motor vehicle
operator's license, as provided by State law.
For purposes of this subsection, the term "direct supervision" means oversight
at a distance: a) of not more than three hundred feet (300'); and b) within
which: 1) visual contact is maintained; and 2) advice and assistance can be
given and received.
   C.   Penalty:
      1.   Any person convicted of a violation of this section is guilty of an
infraction and shall be fined not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00) per
offense.
      2.   It is a defense to a charge under this section, if the person
charged: a) produces in court a license or an appropriate safety certificate
that was valid at the time of the citation or arrest, and issued to the person
operating the off highway vehicle; and b) can show that the direct supervision
requirement under subsection B of this section was not violated at the time of
citation or arrest.
   D.   Exception: The requirements of this section do not apply to an operator
of an off highway implement of husbandry (Ord. 19-03, 2-19-2019)
6-3-4: PROTECTIVE HEADGEAR REQUIREMENTS; OWNER DUTY; PENALTY FOR VIOLATION:
   A.   Headgear: A person under the age of eighteen (18) may not operate or
ride on all-terrain type I vehicles, snowmobiles or motorcycles on public land
unless the person is wearing a property fitted and fastened, United States
Department of Transportation safety rated protective headgear designed for
motorized vehicle use.
   B.   Owner Duty: The owner of an off highway vehicle or any other person may
not give permission for a person who is under eighteen (18) years of age to
operate or ride on an off highway vehicle in violation of this section.
   C.   Exemptions: An operator and passengers of off highway implements of
husbandry operated in the manner prescribed by State law are exempt from the
requirements of this section.
   D.   Penalty: Any person convicted of a violation of this section is guilty
of an infraction and shall be fined not more than fifty dollars ($50.00) per
offense. (Ord. 19-03, 2-19-2019)
6-3-5: USE OF PRIVATELY OWNED LANDS WITHOUT PERMISSION; TAMPERING WITH SIGNS OR
FENCING:
   A.   Privately Owned Land:
      1.   A person may not operate or accompany a person operating an off
highway vehicle upon privately owned land of any other person, firm or
corporation without permission from the owner or person in charge.
      2.   A person operating or accompanying a person operating an off highway
vehicle may not refuse to immediately leave private land upon request of the
owner or person in charge of such land.
      3.   Subsections A1 and A2 of this section do not apply to prescriptive
easements on privately owned land.
      4.   A person who violates subsection A1 of this section is guilty of an
infraction.
      5.   A person who violates subsection A2 of this section is guilty of a
Class C misdemeanor.
      6.   As part of any sentence for a conviction of a violation of
subsection A1 or A2 of this section, the court may:
         a.   Impose a fine of not more than one hundred fifty dollars
($150.00);
         b.   Require the person to pay restitution not to exceed five hundred
dollars ($500.00) for any damage caused by the unlawful motor vehicle travel;
and
         c.   Require the person to perform community service in the form of
repairing any damage caused by the unlawful motor vehicle travel.
   B.   Obstructions: A person operating or accompanying a person operating an
off highway vehicle may not obstruct an entrance or exit to private property
without the owner's permission.
   C.   Destruction Of Signs, Fencing: A person may not:
      1.   Tear down, mutilate or destroy any sign, signboards or other notice
which regulates trespassing for purposes of operating an off highway vehicle on
land; or
      2.   Tear down, deface or destroy any fence or other enclosure or any
gate or bars belonging to the fence or enclosure.
   D.   Violation:
      1.   A violation of subsection B of this section is an infraction;
      2.   A violation of subsection C of this section is a Class C
misdemeanor. (Ord. 19-03, 2-19-2019)
6-3-6: VEHICLES OPERATED ON DESIGNATED LANDS:
No liability may be imposed on the City relating to the designation or
maintenance of any land, trail, street or highway open for off highway vehicle
use. (Ord. 19-03, 2-19-2019)
6-3-7: SPEED AND OTHER REGULATIONS:
Off highway vehicles shall be operated at all times in accordance with all
applicable State laws and regulations and City ordinances. Any person operating
an off highway vehicle is subject to the provisions of Utah Code Annotated
title 41, chapter 6, Traffic Code, unless specifically excluded. (Ord. 19-03,
2-19-2019)
6-3-8: PENALTY FOR VIOLATION:
Unless another penalty is specifically provided for in this chapter, or
elsewhere in the laws of this State, any person who violates any provision of
this chapter, upon conviction, is guilty of an infraction, subject to penalty
as provided in title 1, chapter 4 of this Code. (Ord. 19-03, 2-19-2019; amd.
2019 Code)
TITLE 7
PUBLIC WAYS AND PROPERTY
CHAPTER 1
STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND PUBLIC WAYS
SECTION:
7-1-1: Supervision Of Streets
7-1-2: Applicability
7-1-3: Construction Or Repair Of Public Ways
7-1-4: Encroachments
7-1-5: Encroachments Over Public Sidewalks
7-1-6: Street And Sidewalk Standards
7-1-7: Street Numbering
7-1-8: Private Use, Displays And Signs
7-1-9: Obstructions
7-1-10: Erection Of Poles And Wires Require Permit
7-1-11: Littering
7-1-12: Playing Games
7-1-13: Trees And Shrubs
7-1-14: Burning Of Leaves Or Rubbish
7-1-15: Snow Removal
7-1-16: Nuisances
7-1-17: Conflicting Provisions
7-1-18: Penalty
7-1-1: SUPERVISION OF STREETS:
   A.   Public Works Department: There is hereby created the Department of
Public Works to maintain all public works of the City and all other City
property as set forth in this title. The Public Works Department shall have a
Public Works Superintendent, who shall take charge of the operation and
maintenance of all of the City public works and other property as set forth in
this title.
   B.   Public Works Superintendent: The Public Works Superintendent shall be a
full time employee of the City and shall be appointed by the Mayor, with the
advice and consent of the City Council. All maintenance and repair of public
streets, sidewalks and other public ways shall be under the supervision of the
Public Works Superintendent. He or she shall be charged with the enforcement of
all ordinance provisions relating to such public places (except Traffic
Ordinances) and he or she is hereby authorized to enforce such ordinance
provisions. The Public Works Superintendent shall have charge and care of all
tools, equipment and materials of the City used for City purposes. (1995 Code §
3-8-101; amd. Ord. 06-06, 4-4-2006; 2019 Code)
7-1-2: APPLICABILITY:
Any City property not already covered in this title shall be cared for under
the direction of the Public Works Superintendent. All City ordinances
regulating public buildings shall also regulate buildings of the City. Any
ordinances that regulate vacant land in the City shall also govern all vacant
City property. (1995 Code § 5-5-101)
7-1-3: CONSTRUCTION OR REPAIR OF PUBLIC WAYS:
   A.   Permit Required: It shall be unlawful to construct or lay any pavement
on any public street, sidewalk or other public way, or to repair or alter the
same, without first having secured a permit therefor. Application for such
permit shall be made to the City Recorder, and shall state the location of the
intended pavement or repair, the extent thereof, and the person or firm who is
to do the actual construction work. No permits shall be issued except where the
work will conform to the ordinances of the City.
   B.   Public Safety:
      1.   Any person, firm or corporation laying or repairing any pavement on
a street, sidewalk or other public place, or making excavation of the same,
shall maintain suitable barricades to prevent the injury of any person or
vehicle by reason of the work. Such barricades shall be protected by a light at
nighttime. Any defect in the recessed pavement shall be barricaded to prevent
injury. Any person, firm or corporation properly maintaining any open
excavation while the same remains open shall guard the same with proper
barricades and lights.
      2.   It shall be unlawful to disturb any barricade of lights lawfully
placed to protect or mark any new pavement or new excavation or opening on any
public street, sidewalk or other public way.
      3.   It shall be unlawful for any person knowingly and intentionally and
without legal cause to remove flashing lights or lanterns from the construction
area.
   C.   Conformance With Specifications: All street and sidewalk pavement shall
be made in conformity with specifications laid down or approved by the City
Council.
   D.   Injury Prohibited: It shall be unlawful to walk upon or drive any
vehicle around and upon, or injure any newly laid street or sidewalk while the
same is guarded by warning sign or barricade, or to knowingly injure any soft
or newly laid pavement. (1995 Code § 5-1-102)
7-1-4: ENCROACHMENTS:
   A.   Prohibition: It shall be unlawful to erect or maintain any building or
structure, except as defined in section
7-1-5 of this chapter, which encroaches on any public road, street, street
right-of-way, alley or other public property. (Ord. 11-04, 5-17-2011)
   B.   Personal Property: It shall be unlawful to park or place personal
property, which includes, but is not limited to, RV trailers, utility trailers,
unlicensed vehicles, livestock trailers, livestock feed or firewood for storage
purposes upon any public road, street, street right-of-way or alley for more
than seventy two (72) hours after receiving notice; provided, in the event of
snowstorms, which require snow plows to clear the public streets, such property
shall be removed immediately without notice. For all other types of
emergencies, the City shall dispense with the seventy two (72) hour notice
requirement and provide the best notice practicable to require owners or
renters to remove such personal property. Personal property in violation of
this subsection may be impounded and removed by the City. The cost of
impoundment and removal shall be charged to the owner or person who claims the
impounded property. (Ord. 06-02, 3-7-2006)
   C.   Commercial Diesel Trucks In Residential Areas: It shall be unlawful to
park any commercial diesel truck, which requires the continual or intermittent
operation of any motors, including refrigeration units, in residential areas.
Temporary parking of commercial diesel trucks with no motors running may be
allowed on street right-of-way (not pavement) in residential areas if it does
not obstruct a motorists’ view of an intersection. (1995 Code § 5-1-403; amd.
Ord. 11-04, 5-17-2011)
   D.   Heavy Equipment Requires Permit: It shall be unlawful to encroach upon
any City sidewalk or utility with heavy equipment during construction projects
without first obtaining an encroachment permit from the City. (Ord. 06-02, 3-7-
2006)
7-1-5: ENCROACHMENTS OVER PUBLIC SIDEWALKS:
   A.   Definitions:
    AWNING: A shade structure for which the primary purpose is shelter from the
elements, signage, or an architectural feature that is constructed of canvas,
metal or nylon materials. Excluded materials include, but are not limited to,
plastic and vinyl. Awnings shall not extend more than five feet (5') from the
front of the building over public property.
   ENCROACHMENT: Any structure in the General Commercial District considered to
be permanent in nature, including, but not limited to, wheelchair accessible
ramps, attached signs and flower boxes, and shall not extend more than four
feet (4') from the front of the building over public property.
   STOREFRONT EXPANSION AREA: An area that shall not extend more than four feet
(4') from the front of the building over public property in the General
Commercial District, which may be used by a business to add visual design
elements to increase the charm, character and attractiveness of the storefront
and improve economic viability.
   B.   Authorization Required: It shall be unlawful to place or cause to be
placed any encroachment, as defined in subsection A of this section, on or
above public sidewalks without authorization from the City and in accordance
with this section.
   C.   Permitting Process: Encroachments may be granted, or denied by the City
Council upon completion of the permitting process as required by the City
Encroachment Policy.
   D.   Requirements:
      1.   Encroachments that extend into the airspace over public property
must be placed at least seven feet (7') above the public sidewalk.
      2.   Permanent encroachments shall be designed in a manner that enhances
the aesthetic atmosphere of the General Commercial District. Construction
specifications and suggested design criteria shall be included in the City
Encroachment Policy.
      3.   Permanent encroachments may be located on or above public property
and sidewalks or in storefront expansion areas if attached securely and do not
obstruct the travel area for pedestrians or pose a threat to their health,
safety and welfare.
   E.   Exclusions: Sandstone benches, trash receptacles and light pole banners
placed by the City are excluded from the provisions of this section. (Ord. 11-
04, 5-17-2011; amd. 2019 Code)
7-1-6: STREET AND SIDEWALK STANDARDS:
   A.   Grades: All street paving in the City, except construction of a
temporary nature, shall be constructed to grades as adopted by the City Council
and specified in title 10, article 18A, "Design Standards For Construction And
Development", of this Code.
   B.   Street Classification: Streets shall be classified as arterial/major,
subcollector/minor and collector streets, as designated in the City Public
Works Policy for Streets and Roads and as adopted in the Streets Master Plan on
September 17, 1985.
   C.   Width And Construction Standards: All street construction shall conform
to the standards set forth in the City Public Works Policy for Streets and
Roads. Not all platted streets within the City are uniform and consistent,
therefore the City retains the right to bring them into conformity. An
exception may be made to the street widths and construction standards, in that
all existing streets shall be maintained to their current layout.
   D.   Sidewalk Construction: All sidewalk construction in the City shall:
      1.   Conform to the standards set forth in title 10 of this Code.
Sidewalks shall be installed in each zone based on the specific criteria as
detailed in title 10 of this Code.
      2.   The construction of sidewalks in the City shall be in conformance
with the City sidewalk construction standards as included in the City Sidewalks
Policy. (Ord. 06-06, 4-4-2006)
7-1-7: STREET NUMBERING:
   A.   Uniform Numbering System Established: There is hereby established a
uniform system for numbering buildings and lots fronting all streets and public
ways in the City. All houses and buildings shall be numbered by the City or its
designee, in accordance with the provisions of this section. (1995 Code § 5-1-
301)
   B.   Baseline For Dividing City And Assigning Numbers:
      1.   Specified: The following shall constitute the baseline for dividing
the City:
         a.   Center Street shall constitute the baseline which shall divide
