the City into northern and southern parts. Hereafter, all streets north of this
baseline and running in easterly- westerly directions shall be considered
"north" streets, and all streets south of this baseline running easterly-
westerly direction shall be considered "south" streets.
         b.   Main Street shall be considered the baseline which divides the
City into east and west parts. Hereafter, streets east of this baseline that
run northerly-southerly directions shall be considered "east" streets, and
likewise streets west of and running northerly-southerly directions shall be
considered "west" streets.
         c.   A block interval system of six hundred sixty feet (660') shall be
used.
      2.   Numbering: The number of buildings and lots on such streets shall
begin at the baseline. All buildings and lots on the right side going away from
the baseline of Center and Main Streets shall bear even numbers. Likewise, all
buildings and lots on the left side going away from the baseline of Center and
Main Streets shall bear odd numbers.
         a.   Each building or lot on the right side of the street from the
baseline point of Main and Center Streets and going away from that point shall
be numbered an even number between 2 and 100, and shall carry an address
indicating its easterly, westerly, northerly or southerly location.
         b.   Each building or lot on the left side of the street from the
point of Main and Center Streets and going away from that point shall be
numbered with an odd number between 1 and 99, and shall carry an address
indicating its easterly, westerly, northerly or southerly location.
         c.   All multiple-family dwellings having one front entrance shall be
assigned only one number, and separate apartments in the building shall carry
letter or number designations in addition to the number assigned to the main
entrance of the building.
         d.   Any duplex houses having two (2) entrances shall have a separate
number for each entrance.
         e.   All buildings facing streets not extending through to the
baseline shall be assigned the same relative numbers as if the street had
extended to the baseline. (1995 Code § 5-1-302)
   C.   Number Assignment To Be On Buildings:
      1.   Required: The owner, occupant or agent shall place or cause to be
placed the assigned permanent number upon each house or building controlled by
him or her within thirty (30) days after the assignment.
      2.   Size, Material: The number shall not be less than three inches (3")
in height and shall be made of a durable, visible material.
      3.   Placement: The numbers shall be conspicuously placed so that the
number can be seen plainly from the street. (1995 Code § 5-1-303)
   D.   Naming And Renaming Of Streets:
      1.   Subdivisions: Subdivision plats must show the proposed names, if
any, of all streets and receive the approval of the Planning Commission or the
City Council before streets are officially named.
      2.   Existing Or New Streets: The Mayor and City Council, by resolution,
may change, rename or name an existing or newly established street within the
limits of the City upon the recommendation of the Planning Commission, or any
other City designee. (1995 Code § 5-1-304)
7-1-8: PRIVATE USE, DISPLAYS AND SIGNS:
   A.   Permission Required: It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or
corporation to use any street, sidewalk, or other public place as space for the
display of goods or merchandise for sale without permission from the City
Council; or to write, make or place any sign or advertisement on any such
street or sidewalk without permission from the City Council.
   B.   Distance To Intersection: It shall be unlawful to place any approved
display or sign on City property, including A-frame type signs, within ten feet
(10') of an intersection.
   C.   Pedestrian Traffic On Sidewalks: It shall be unlawful for any approved
private use on City property to obstruct the flow of pedestrian traffic and
must provide a minimum of five feet (5') of unobstructed sidewalk from the
gutter if fronting Main Street and at least four feet (4') of unobstructed
sidewalk on all other sidewalks. (Ord. 11-04, 5-17-2011)
7-1-9: OBSTRUCTIONS:
   A.   Permit Required: It shall be unlawful to cause, create or maintain any
obstruction of any street, sidewalk or other public place, except where it may
be specified by ordinance or by the Public Works Superintendent. Any person,
firm or corporation seeking permission to obstruct any street for any purpose
shall obtain a permit from the Public Works Superintendent authorizing
obstruction of the streets. (1995 Code § 5-1-103)
   B.   Exceptions:
      1.   Chairs may be lawfully set up on Main Street along the Fourth of
July parade route at the times and places set forth in the City Streets Policy.
(Ord. 14-04, 11-4-2014)
      2.   Chairs may be lawfully set up on Main Street or other designated
parade routes for the Fourth of July parade route at the times and places set
forth in the City Parade Policy. (Ord. 17-02, 3-16-2017)
7-1-10: ERECTION OF POLES AND WIRES REQUIRE PERMIT:
It shall be unlawful to erect any poles or wires or maintain any poles or wires
over any public place, street, alley or other public way without first having
secured permission from the City Council. (1995 Code § 5-1-405)
7-1-11: LITTERING:
   A.   Prohibited: It shall be unlawful to deposit on any street or any
sidewalk any material which may be harmful to the pavement thereof, or any
waste material, or any glass, or other articles which do injury to any person,
animal or property.
   B.   Exception For Delivery: Merchandise or other articles may be deposited
on sidewalks preparatory to delivery; provided, that the usable width of the
sidewalk is not thereby reduced to less than four feet (4'); and provided, that
no such article shall remain on such walk for more than one-half (1/2) hour,
unless permission is granted by the City Council. (1995 Code § 5-1-401)
7-1-12: PLAYING GAMES:
It shall be unlawful to play any game upon any street, alley or sidewalk, or
other public place, where such games cause unnecessary noise or interference
with traffic or pedestrians. (1995 Code § 5-1-406)
7-1-13: TREES AND SHRUBS:
   A.   Planting: It shall be unlawful to plant any tree or any bush in any
public street or other public place without having first secured permission
from the City Council. (1995 Code § 5-1-407)
   B.   Removal Or Cutting: It shall be unlawful to remove or cut down any tree
or shrub in any public place without having first secured permission from the
City Council.
   C.   Injury: It shall be unlawful to injure any tree or shrub growing in any
public place.
   D.   Attachments:
      1.   Sign, Advertisement, Notice: It shall be unlawful to attach any
sign, advertisement or notice to any tree or shrub or any such public place.
(1995 Code § 5-1-408)
      2.   Wires, Ropes: It shall be unlawful to attach any wire or rope on any
tree or shrub on any public street, or other public place, without the
permission of the City Council. (1995 Code § 5-1-409)
   E.   Impeding Limbs Removed: Any tree or shrub which overhangs any sidewalk,
street or other public place in the City in such a way as to impede with
traffic or travel, or within ten feet (10') of a street, or seven feet (7') of
a sidewalk level, shall be trimmed by the owner of the premises abutting or of
the premises on which the tree or shrub grows so that the obstruction shall
cease. Any tree or limb of a tree which has become likely to fall on or across
any public way or place shall be removed by the owner of the premises on which
the tree grows or stands. The Public Works Superintendent may trim any tree or
shrub or may remove any tree or shrub or branch thereof so that the obstruction
or danger to traffic or passage shall be done away with. (1995 Code § 5-1-408)
7-1-14: BURNING OF LEAVES OR RUBBISH:
It shall be unlawful to burn any leaves, paper, rubbish or other substances
upon any of the public streets, sidewalks or public ways in the City. (1995
Code § 5-1-410)
7-1-15: SNOW REMOVAL:
   A.   Generally. All occupants of property, whether owner or lessor or agent,
owes a duty to remove snow, sleet or ice from any sidewalk from his or her
property within a reasonable amount of time and in a manner so as not to
interfere with City snow removal or City property.
   B.   Manner of Snow Removal. It shall be unlawful for any person to push,
pile, or place snow or ice so that it unreasonably obstructs or blocks
driveways, streets, intersections or otherwise blocks the visibility of, or
creates a dangerous condition for, motor vehicles or pedestrians. It shall be
unlawful for any person to push, pile, or place snow or ice in such a manner
that it impedes access to a fire hydrant, storm drain, driveway, or lane of
travel. Snow and ice in parking lots should be contained on site and not be
placed in the street. (1995 Code § 5-1-411; amd. Ord. 23-04, 2-21-2023)
7-1-16: NUISANCES:
   A.   Declaration Of Public Nuisance: Items or materials which are on public
property and because of their condition or location cause harm or prejudice to
another, or which obstruct, impair or destroy the reasonable and peaceful
public use of the property, are hereby declared to be public nuisances. This
declaration of public nuisances is in addition to those set forth in title 4,
chapter 2 of this Code. (1995 Code § 5-1-412; amd. 2019 Code)
   B.   Personal Property Items; Exception: Items of personal property that are
caused to be parked, stored or left to encroach upon any City sidewalk or
street right-of-way, except that licensed and operable vehicles are allowed in
accordance with section
7-1-4 of this chapter, are considered a nuisance. (Ord. 09-04, 11-17-2009)
   C.   Abatement: Any item or material found to be a nuisance from the
provisions of this section may be abated by removing or impounding the same, or
by any other appropriate means. The cost of such abatement shall be borne by
the person or party responsible for causing the nuisance.
   D.   Notice: Before an officer or employee of the City may abate the
nuisance, the City shall provide notice that after seven (7) days the City will
remove the nuisance and charge the owner thereof for the reasonable cost of
removal. The owner shall then have the seven (7) day period from the notice
period to begin to remove the nuisance with no consequences to him or her.
After the seven (7) day period has expired, the City shall remove the nuisances
and charge the owner thereof the reasonable costs of removal and for any
storage or disposal fees that may apply. (1995 Code § 5-1-412)
   E.   Severability: If any section, paragraph, clause, or provision of this
title shall be held invalid or unenforceable for any reason, the invalidity or
unenforceability thereof shall not affect any of the remaining provisions of
this title or any provision adopted thereby. (1995 Code § 5-1-414)
7-1-17: CONFLICTING PROVISIONS:
All ordinances, resolutions, orders or other actions of the City Council that
conflict with the provisions of this title are, to the extent of such conflict,
deemed to be amended by this title to conform with the provisions hereof. (1995
Code § 5-1-415)
7-1-18: PENALTY:
Except as may be provided elsewhere in this title, any person who violates or
permits violation of any provision of this title shall be guilty of Class B
misdemeanor, subject to penalty as provided in title 1, chapter 4 of this Code.
(Ord. 09-04, 11-17-2009; amd. 2019 Code)
CHAPTER 2
CEMETERY
SECTION:
7-2-1: Ownership And Name
7-2-2: Cemetery Sexton
7-2-3: Authority Of City Council
7-2-4: Definitions
7-2-5: Applicability
7-2-6: Care And Liability
7-2-7: Sale Of Burial Rights
7-2-8: Fees
7-2-9: Permission To Bury
7-2-10: Burials To Be In Cemetery
7-2-11: Vaults And Caskets Required
7-2-12: Markers
7-2-13: Restrictions On Resale
7-2-14: Prohibited Interments
7-2-15: Disinterments
7-2-16: Burial Of Indigents
7-2-17: Registration Of Burials And Disinterments
7-2-18: Perpetual Care
7-2-19: Injury To Cemetery Property
7-2-20: Theft Of Property
7-2-21: Traffic Regulations
7-2-22: Animals
7-2-23: Private Additions To Cemetery Grounds
7-2-24: Bench Placement
7-2-1: OWNERSHIP AND NAME:
The burial ground is owned by the City and shall be known by the name Fillmore
City Cemetery. (1995 Code § 5-3-202)
7-2-2: CEMETERY SEXTON:
   A.   Office Created; Appointment: There is hereby created the Office of
Cemetery Sexton. The Mayor, with the advice and consent of the City Council,
shall appoint the Cemetery Sexton. (1995 Code § 5-3-101)
   B.   Duties: The Sexton shall:
      1.   Enforce the provisions of this chapter and all policies governing
the cemetery;
      2.   Supervise the operation of the cemetery;
      3.   Maintain the cemetery grounds; and
      4.   Perform such other duties as directed by the Mayor or Public Works
Director.
   C.   Job Description: The complete duties and responsibilities of the
Cemetery Sexton shall be outlined in a written job description that may be
amended from time to time. (1995 Code § 5-3-102)
7-2-3: AUTHORITY OF CITY COUNCIL:
The City Council shall have authority to set rules and regulations regarding
cemetery fees and other details regarding cemetery maintenance and operations
through the City Cemetery Policy, which may be amended as necessary by the City
Council for the efficient and safe operation and maintenance of the cemetery.
(Ord. 99-04, 2-2-1999; amd. 2019 Code)
7-2-4: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this chapter, the following words or phrases shall have the
following meanings:
LOT: Shall include the partial lots or single graves in the cemetery.
LOT OWNER, PURCHASER OR GRAVE OWNER: Refers to the owner of burial rights, not
real estate. These terms shall mean the owner or purchaser of burial privileges
or the collateral right of use of any burial lot evidenced by a deed or burial
right for a described lot, or by proved and recognized descent or devise from
the original owner. (1995 Code § 5-3-201)
7-2-5: APPLICABILITY:
   A.   Scope: All cemeteries owned or maintained by the City shall be subject
to the provisions of this chapter. (1995 Code § 5-3-203)
   B.   Grave Lots Subject To City Regulations: Every lot or single grave is
subject to all rules and regulations that the City Council may adopt through
ordinance or policy and may be amended as necessary for the protection of the
cemetery, lot owners and the remains of the dead. (Ord. 99-04, 2-2-1999; amd.
2019 Code)
7-2-6: CARE AND LIABILITY:
The City reserves the right to enter upon any lot and to perform all work
necessary for the care and upkeep of all lots and graves. The City shall not be
liable for any damage to personal property or loss. (1995 Code § 5-3-208)
7-2-7: SALE OF BURIAL RIGHTS:
   A.   Authorized; Collection Of Perpetual Care Fees: The City Recorder is
hereby empowered to sell burial rights and collect perpetual care fees in the
Fillmore City Cemetery and the proceeds of the sale receipted by the City
Treasurer.
   B.   Regulations Of Sales: The City Council is hereby empowered to regulate,
by resolution and policy, the selling price, number of burial rights to be
sold, and the amount to be paid for each right. The City Recorder shall deliver
to each purchaser a certificate for each lot or partial lot for which burial
rights were purchased, with a description thereof by lot, block and graves, and
stating the price paid.
   C.   Certificates; Nontaxable Personal Property: Cemetery certificates shall
be issued and signed by the City Recorder. Burial rights in the Fillmore City
Cemetery are not taxable personal property.
   D.   Number Purchased: The number of graves that may be purchased by any one
individual may be regulated by the City Council through resolution or policy.
(1995 Code § 5-3-219; amd. Ord. 12-01, 2-21-2012)
7-2-8: FEES:
   A.   All fees pertaining to the Fillmore City Cemetery shall be set by the
City Council through resolution or policy, and may be amended as deemed
necessary by the City Council. (1995 Code § 5-3-221)
   B.   The purchase price for burial rights to graves in the Fillmore City
Cemetery is a one time perpetual care fee for cemetery maintenance. The
purchase price may be fixed by the City Council through resolution or policy
and may be amended as deemed necessary by the City Council. (1995 Code § 5-3-
220)
7-2-9: PERMISSION TO BURY:
It shall be unlawful for any person to bury or disinter the body of a deceased
person in the Fillmore City Cemetery without first obtaining, as herein
provided, a certificate of purchase for the burial right for the grave, or to
file with the City Recorder a written consent from the owner thereof granting
permission to use the grave. (1995 Code § 5-3-210)
7-2-10: BURIALS TO BE IN CEMETERY:
It shall be unlawful to bury the body of any person within the limits of the
City, except in public or private cemeteries. (1995 Code § 5-3-217)
7-2-11: VAULTS AND CASKETS REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to be buried in a cemetery of the City
without a casket and vault made of concrete, steel, wood or brick that covers
the casket on all six (6) sides. (1995 Code § 5-3-206)
7-2-12: MARKERS:
   A.   City To Inform Of Requirement: The City shall inform the owner of any
lot or relatives of deceased persons buried in any lot of the requirement to
place or cause to be placed a suitable marker with the name of the deceased
plainly inscribed thereon upon the grave of every person interred therein
within six (6) months of such interment. (Ord. 03-04, 4-15-2003)
   B.   Placement Of Markers:
      1.   It shall be unlawful for any person to erect or place or cause to be
placed any grave marker in the cemetery without a permit. Placement of the
marker shall be done under the direction of the Cemetery Sexton. The marker
shall be set on a concrete foundation with a mow strip on each side of the
marker as specified in City policy.
      2.   It shall be unlawful to place more than one marker per grave, except
in the case where cremated remains of one individual only are allowed to be
placed on top of an existing burial. In this incidence only, an additional flat
monument marker shall be allowed to be placed on the grave to mark the location
of the cremated remains. If this second flat marker is allowed under these
conditions only, the owner of the monument agrees to waive all responsibility
of the City for damage that may occur in the future to the flat monument placed
as a second marker on a grave site. All monument markers shall be set under the
direction of the Cemetery Sexton. The length of all headstones or markers, to
include the cement surrounding the monument, shall not exceed three feet eight
inches (3'8") for a single, or six feet (6') for a double. (Ord. 08-05, 1-6-
2009)
7-2-13: RESTRICTIONS ON RESALE:
It shall be unlawful to resell any grave rights in the Fillmore City Cemetery
to any entity other than to the City. The City shall buy back any unwanted,
unused grave rights at the original purchase price. (1995 Code § 5-3-218)
7-2-14: PROHIBITED INTERMENTS:
It shall be unlawful:
   A.   Human Remains: To inter anything other than the remains of human bodies
in City cemeteries; and
   B.   Location: To inter a human body in a location that is not a legal
cemetery, whether a private cemetery or a cemetery of the City. (1995 Code § 5-
3-205)
7-2-15: DISINTERMENTS:
   A.   Requirements: It shall be unlawful for any person to disinter any body
buried in the Fillmore City Cemetery, or in any other cemetery within the
limits of the City, except in accordance with the laws of the State and under
the direction of the Cemetery Sexton, with prior approval of the Mayor, or
order of a court of competent jurisdiction. The Cemetery Sexton shall not order
any grave opened unless: (Ord. 03-04, 4-15-2003; amd. 2019 Code)
      1.   A permit from the City-County Health Officer has been issued;
      2.   A written order from the owner of the lot authorizing such removal
has been filed with the City. All such removals shall be recorded in a book
kept for that purpose;
      3.   All applicable fees must be paid and permits obtained prior to the
exhumation. (Ord. 03-04, 4-15-2003)
   B.   Contagious Disease: It shall be unlawful for any person to remove the
body of a person whose death was caused by a contagious disease unless two (2)
years have passed since the burial. This subsection shall not apply to bodies
buried in hermetically sealed coffins. (1995 Code § 5-3-211)
7-2-16: BURIAL OF INDIGENTS:
The City Council may designate a portion of the cemetery to the burial of
indigents. The Mayor shall have authority to determine indigence for purposes
of burial in the Fillmore City Cemetery. The Mayor shall have the duty to
disclose to the City Council all deceased persons declared indigent for
purposes of this section. (1995 Code § 5-3-222)
7-2-17: REGISTRATION OF BURIALS AND DISINTERMENTS:
The City Recorder shall be the registrar of burials for all cemeteries in the
City. All burials or disinterments shall be registered with the City Recorder.
Such registration shall contain:
   A.   Name of the deceased;
   B.   Date and location of birth, if known;
   C.   Date and location of death;
   D.   Cause of death;
   E.   Date of burial;
   F.   Name of the cemetery with the initial letter of the plat as well as the
number of the block, lot and grave; and
   G.   If disinterred, the place of destination if transferred beyond the
limits of Fillmore City Cemetery. (1995 Code § 5-3-213)
7-2-18: PERPETUAL CARE:
   A.   Perpetual Care Fund Created: There is hereby created a Perpetual Care
Fund for the care of the City cemetery pursuant to the laws of the State. (1995
Code § 5-3-301)
   B.   Perpetual Care Monies:
      1.   All funds received from the sale of burial rights and perpetual care
services shall be deposited in a special Perpetual Care Fund and properly
invested in accordance with the laws of the State.
      2.   Interest generated from the Perpetual Care Fund may be used to pay
for the upkeep and development of the Fillmore City Cemetery. The principal
balance of the fund may not be expended for any purpose.
      3.   The City Treasurer shall keep, or cause to be kept, an accurate
record of the Perpetual Care Trust Fund account. (1995 Code § 5-3-302)
   C.   Investment Income: Income from investments held in the Perpetual Care
Fund may be credited to the Cemetery Maintenance Fund or credited back to the
Investment Fund. (1995 Code § 5-3-303)
   D.   Perpetual Care Services: The City shall provide the following services
as its perpetual care:
      1.   Mowing of all lots and graves at reasonable intervals;
      2.   Resodding, seeding and filling in sunken graves;
      3.   Sodding of the surface of the graves to lot level;
      4.   Removing dead flowers and trimming trees and shrubbery when
necessary;
      5.   Raking and cleaning the lots and straightening of tilting stones or
markers (this does not include repairing damaged stones, markers or memorials
not damaged by the City); and
      6.   Any other maintenance deemed necessary by the City Council. (1995
Code § 5-3-304)
7-2-19: INJURY TO CEMETERY PROPERTY:
It shall be unlawful for any person to injure, deface, break or otherwise
damage any headstones, tombstones, monuments, trees, shrubs, flowers or any
other property situated in the cemetery. (1995 Code § 5-3-103)
7-2-20: THEFT OF PROPERTY:
   A.   It shall be unlawful to remove, or cause to be removed, any flowers,
shrubs, trees or any other property from the gravesite of another.
   B.   Violators of this section shall be punished in conformity with the Utah
Code Annotated sections that pertain to theft of property. (1995 Code § 5-3-
204; amd. 2019 Code)
7-2-21: TRAFFIC REGULATIONS:
The provisions of the City Traffic Ordinances relative to the operation of
vehicles and conduct of pedestrians shall be in effect in the City cemetery,
except as otherwise modified by this chapter, or by policy and may be amended
as necessary. Speed limit shall be ten (10) miles per hour. (Ord. 99-04, 2-2-
1999)
7-2-22: ANIMALS:
It shall be unlawful for any dog or other animal, except service dogs, to enter
upon cemetery property. (Ord. 12-01, 2-21-2012)
7-2-23: PRIVATE ADDITIONS TO CEMETERY GROUNDS:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any person to erect or maintain any fence,
corner, post, coping, hedge or boundary of any kind upon any lot or lots,
street, alley or walk in the cemetery or grade the ground or land thereof. The
Cemetery Sexton shall, whenever required, furnish the true lines or any lots
according to official survey, and shall prevent and prohibit any boundary
marking by private individuals of lots.
   B.   It shall be unlawful for any person or entity to plant any shrubs,
trees, lawns, etc., or place any unauthorized monuments or markers upon any lot
or lots in the cemetery. (1995 Code § 5-3-214)
7-2-24: BENCH PLACEMENT:
Placement of private benches in the Fillmore City Cemetery shall be regulated
through resolutions or policies adopted and/or amended by the City Council.
(Ord. 12-01, 2-21-2012)
CHAPTER 3
PARKS
SECTION:
7-3-1: Purpose And Applicability
7-3-2: Definitions
7-3-3: Prohibited Acts And Activities Generally
7-3-4: Vehicle Operation And Parking; Bicycles
7-3-5: Firearms And Weapons
7-3-6: Explosives And Fireworks
7-3-7: Advertising And Public Assemblies
7-3-8: Sales Of Merchandise
7-3-9: Alcoholic Beverages And Controlled Dangerous Substances
7-3-10: Conduct Of Persons
7-3-11: Curfew
7-3-1: PURPOSE AND APPLICABILITY:
   A.   The purpose of this chapter is to provide rules and regulations for the
use of and conduct in the parks and recreation areas of the City.
   B.   This chapter shall apply in all parks and recreation areas under the
jurisdiction of the City, unless expressly exempted. No provision in this
chapter shall make unlawful any action necessarily performed by any officer or
employee of the City in the line of duty or work as such in a proper and
necessary execution of the terms of any agreement with the City. (1995 Code §
5-2-101)
7-3-2: DEFINITIONS:
The following words and phrases used in this chapter shall have the following
meanings unless a different meaning clearly appears from the context:
ANIMALS: Includes cats, dogs, horses, any fowl or birds, and any living
creatures within the jurisdiction of the park or recreation area.
PARK ATTENDANT: Any person employed by the City as a park attendant to perform
duties or tasks within the park area.
PATH: Any foot path, walk or any path maintained for pedestrians.
PEDESTRIAN: A person afoot.
PERSON: A person includes any natural person, corporation, company,
association, firm or partnership.
SOLICITING: A person selling goods or services by sample or taking orders for
future delivery with or without accepting advance payment for the goods shall
be deemed soliciting. Also, persons seeking any form of contributions shall be
soliciting. (1995 Code § 5-2-102)
7-3-3: PROHIBITED ACTS AND ACTIVITIES GENERALLY:
It shall be unlawful for any person in a public park or recreation area to:
   A.   Injury To Structures Or Equipment: Mark, deface, disfigure, injure,
tamper with, or displace or move any buildings, bridges, tables, benches,
fireplaces, railing, pavings or paving materials, or water lines or other
public utilities, or parts thereof, signs, notices, placards, whether temporary
or permanent, monuments, stakes, posts, or other boundary markers, or other
structures or equipment, facilities or park property, whatsoever real or
personal;
   B.   Maintain Restroom Areas: Fail to cooperate in maintaining restrooms and
washrooms in a neat and sanitary condition. No person over the age of six (6)
years shall use the restrooms designated for the opposite sex;
   C.   Excavate Or Remove Materials: Dig or remove any soil, rock, sand,
stones, trees, shrubs or plants, or other wood or materials, or make any
excavation by tool, equipment, blasting or other means;
   D.   Construction: Construct or erect any building or structure of whatever
kind, whether permanent or temporary, or run or string any public service
utility into, upon or across such lands, except with special permission from
the City Council;
   E.   Plantings: Damage, cut, carve, mark, transplant or remove any plant, or
injure the bark or pick flowers or seeds of any tree or plant, dig in or
otherwise disturb grass areas, or in any other way injure the beauty or
usefulness of any area;
   F.   Misuse Of Property: Climb any tree or walk, climb, stand or sit upon
monuments, vases, planters, fountains, railings, fences, or upon any other
property not designated or customarily used for such purpose;
   G.   Polluting Water: Throw, discharge or otherwise place or cause to be
placed in the waters of any fountains, streams or other body of water in or
adjacent to any park, any substance, matter or thing, liquid or solid, which
will or may result in the pollution of water;
   H.   Littering: Leave any rubbish, refuse, garbage or other materials,
except for refuse and rubbish that is deposited in receptacles as provided.
Where receptacles are not provided, such rubbish or waste shall be carried away
from the park by the person responsible for its presence, and properly disposed
of elsewhere;
   I.   Animals At Large: Cause or permit to run loose any animal; and
   J.   Disturb Wildlife: Hunt, molest, harm, frighten, kill, trap, pursue,
chase or tease any wildlife, reptile or bird. (1995 Code § 5-2-103)
7-3-4: VEHICLE OPERATION AND PARKING; BICYCLES:
It shall be unlawful for any person in a public park or recreation area to:
   A.   Driving: Drive any vehicle on any area except the paved park roads or
parking areas, or such areas as may on occasion be suitably designated as
temporary areas;
   B.   Parking: Park a vehicle anywhere except on a permanent or temporary
parking area;
   C.   Leave During Hours Of Closure; Snowstorms: Leave a vehicle standing or
parked in established parking areas or elsewhere in the park and recreation
areas during hours when the park or recreation area is closed. During a
snowstorm and for three (3) days thereafter, established parking areas and
parks and recreation areas may be utilized for parking, but not by trailers of
any kind;
   D.   Bicycle Riding: Ride a bicycle without reasonable regard to the safety
of others. (1995 Code § 5-2-104)
7-3-5: FIREARMS AND WEAPONS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to bring into or have in his possession in
any park or recreation area:
   A.   Any pistol or revolver, or objects upon which loaded or blank
cartridges may be used. Official starters, at authorized City events, are
excepted from this restriction;
   B.   Any burglar tools;
   C.   Any rifle, shotgun, air gun, spring gun, sling shot, bow or other
weapon in which the propelling force is gun powder, a spring or air. (1995 Code
§ 5-2-105)
7-3-6: EXPLOSIVES AND FIREWORKS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to have in his possession or set off any
fireworks, except under the permission and supervision of the City. (1995 Code
§ 5-2-106)
7-3-7: ADVERTISING AND PUBLIC ASSEMBLIES:
No person shall post, paint, affix, distribute, deliver, place, cast or leave
about any bill, billboard, placard, ticket, handbill, circular or
advertisement. No person shall do any of the following without a permit from
the City:
   A.   Operate for any advertising purpose any musical instrument, soundtrack
or drum;
   B.   Hold public assemblages;
   C.   Conduct exhibitions. (1995 Code § 5-2-107)
7-3-8: SALES OF MERCHANDISE:
No person shall offer for sale any article in any park or recreation area
without permission from the City. (1995 Code § 5-2-108)
7-3-9: ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES AND CONTROLLED DANGEROUS SUBSTANCES:
While in a park or recreation area, all persons shall conduct themselves in a
proper and orderly manner and in particular, no person shall bring alcoholic
beverages or controlled dangerous substances, drink or use the same at any
time, nor shall any person be under the influence of intoxicating liquor or
controlled dangerous substance in a park or recreation area. (1995 Code § 5-2-
109)
7-3-10: CONDUCT OF PERSONS:
It shall be unlawful for any person in a park or recreation area to:
   A.   Camping: Camp or stay overnight;
   B.   Disorderly Conduct: Engage in threatening, abusive, insulting or
indecent language, or engage in any disorderly conduct or behavior tending to
breach the public peace;
   C.   Disturbing Persons: Disturb or interfere unreasonably with any person
or party occupying any area or participating in any lawful activity in the park
or recreation period. (1995 Code § 5-2-110)
7-3-11: CURFEW:
   A.   Authorized Adult Defined: "Authorized adult" shall mean any person over
twenty one (21) years authorized by a minor's parent, guardian or other legal
representative to accompany said minor on public property after curfew.
   B.   Time Designated: City parks and properties, including the Statehouse
Park grounds, the American Legion grounds, the City building grounds, the
Wildlife Park, Fillmore City Cemetery, and the North Park shall be closed at
the below listed times to juvenile pedestrians (walk through traffic) for any
minor seventeen (17) years of age and under, unless accompanied by a parent,
guardian or other "authorized adult", as defined in subsection A of this
section:
Sunday - Thursday 11:00 P.M.
Friday - Saturday 12:00 midnight
   (Ord. 05-03, 2-15-2005)
   C.   Exceptions: Exceptions to the curfew may be granted on a case by case
basis by the City Council for special events. (Ord. 03-02, 3-18-2003)
   D.   Penalty: It shall be a Class C misdemeanor, subject to penalty as
provided in title 1, chapter 4 of this Code, to violate any provisions of this
section. (Ord. 03-02, 3-18-2003; amd. 2019 Code)
CHAPTER 4
AIRPORT
SECTION:
7-4-1: Airport Regulations
7-4-1: AIRPORT REGULATIONS:
The City Council shall adopt rules and regulations through an airport policy,
which shall govern the use of the City Airport. The airport policy shall be on
file in the City office. (1995 Code § 5-4-101)
CHAPTER 5
ROAD EXTENSION COST RECOVERY POLICY
SECTION:
7-5-1: Policy For Recovery
7-5-2: Appeal To City Council
7-5-3: Term Of Recovery Period
7-5-4: Nonapplicable To New Subdivisions
7-5-5: City Exempt From Policy
7-5-1: POLICY FOR RECOVERY:
   A.   Specified: Any person who builds a road in the City shall pay all the
costs associated with the construction of the road. A developer who extends a
road beyond what a developer has already constructed, should pay a recovery fee
of the costs the said developer paid in costs for the road they constructed.
When a person recovers said costs from the next subsequent developer who
extends the road, said person shall be deemed compensated in full and no longer
eligible to recover additional costs. Recovery cost reimbursement shall cease
once recovery costs reach a minimum of one hundred dollars ($100.00).
   B.   Illustration: By way of illustration:
      1.   Developer A builds a road extension and pays ten thousand dollars
($10,000.00) for the cost of constructing the road. Developer B extends the
road four hundred feet (400') from the original point of extension, attributing
forty percent (40%) of the road to developer B (1,000 times 40 percent equals
400 feet). Developer A is entitled to fifty percent (50%) of the cost value
from developer B's extension ($10,000.00 times 40 percent equals $4,000.00).
Developer A may continue to recoup from subsequent developers up to fifty
percent (50%) of the costs expended to extend the road. Developer A shall then
be considered fully compensated and become ineligible to recover any additional
costs.
      2.   Developer C extends a section of road from the original road.
Developer B shall be entitled to recovery from developer C and/or subsequent
developers two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00), which is fifty
percent (50%) of the cost developer B paid to developer A ($5,000.00).
Developer B shall then be considered fully compensated and become ineligible to
recover any additional costs.
      3.   Developer B extends the road further, beyond developer A's original
road constructed. Developer A shall be entitled to recover fifty percent (50%)
of his/her total extension costs ($5,000.00) from developer B. Developer B
shall be entitled to recover fifty percent (50%) from developer C and/or
subsequent customers ($2,500.00) of the costs developer B paid to developer A
and in addition thereto, developer B shall be entitled to recover fifty percent
(50%) of the costs from developers who connect to developer B's additional road
extension. Developer B shall then be considered fully compensated and become
ineligible to recover any additional costs.
      4.   This pattern continues until the cost recovery any additional costs.
(Ord. 18-02, 5-15-2018)
7-5-2: APPEAL TO CITY COUNCIL:
If situations arise that make it difficult or inequitable to apply the cost
recovery formula set forth above, the City Council will determine the amount
allowed, on a case by case basis, to the person or entity entitled to cost
recovery. Such a determination shall be made only after such person or entity
appeals to the City Council for consideration of such cost recovery. The City
Council's decision shall be final. (Ord. 18-02, 5-15-2018)
7-5-3: TERM OF RECOVERY PERIOD:
The cost recovery period shall be limited to ten (10) years from the date of
the original section of road construction and ten (10) years from the date of
the first road extension to said original road construction. (Ord. 18-02, 5-15-
2018)
7-5-4: NONAPPLICABLE TO NEW SUBDIVISIONS:
The cost recovery policy set forth in this chapter shall not apply to new
subdivisions as the owners or developers of such subdivisions can pass such
costs on to buyers of subdivided lots. (Ord. 18-02, 5-15-2018)
7-5-5: CITY EXEMPT FROM POLICY:
The City shall be exempt from this policy and may extend roadways for any
purpose at any time without repayment of extension costs. (Ord. 18-02, 5-15-
2018)
TITLE 8
PUBLIC UTILITIES
CHAPTER 1
UTILITY SERVICES
SECTION:
8-1-1: Application For Utility Service
8-1-2: Discontinuance For Nonpayment
8-1-3: Limitations On Discontinuance
8-1-4: Conflicts
8-1-5: Publication Of Related Actions; Severability
8-1-1: APPLICATION FOR UTILITY SERVICE:
Before furnishing water or providing sewer service or electrical service to a
property, the property owner, or an owner's authorized agent, shall submit a
written application to the City, signed by the owner or authorized agent,
agreeing to pay for all water furnished or sewer service or electrical service
provided to the property, whether occupied by a tenant or other occupant. (Ord.
05-01, 1-11-2005)
8-1-2: DISCONTINUANCE FOR NONPAYMENT:
If an owner fails to pay for water furnished or sewer services or electrical
services provided to the owner's property, the City will discontinue furnishing
such water, sewer or electrical services to the property, until all amounts for
such water, sewer and electrical services provided, are paid in full, subject
to section
8-1-3 of this chapter. (Ord. 05-01, 1-11-2005)
8-1-3: LIMITATIONS ON DISCONTINUANCE:
   A.   Transfer Of Ownership: The City may not use an owner's failure to pay
for water furnished or sewer service or electrical service provided to the
owner's property as a basis for not furnishing water or provide sewer or
electrical service to the property after ownership of the property is
transferred to a subsequent owner.
   B.   Nonliability Of New Owner: The City may not require an owner to pay the
water that was furnished or sewer service or electrical service that was
provided to the property before the ownership. (Ord. 05-01, 1-11-2005)
8-1-4: CONFLICTS:
All ordinances, resolutions, orders or other actions of the City Council in
conflict with the provisions of this title are, to the extent of such conflict,
deemed to be amended by this title to conform with the provisions of this
title. (1995 Code § 3-4-302)
8-1-5: PUBLICATION OF RELATED ACTIONS; SEVERABILITY:
Any actions taken by the City Council that relates to this title shall be
recorded with this title. Actions that shall be published with this title
include, but are not limited to, resolutions, policies or franchise agreements.
(1995 Code § 3-4-303)
The provisions of this title are severable, and the invalidity of any phrase,
clause, section, or part of this title shall not affect the validity or
effectiveness or the remainder of the title. (1995 Code § 3-4-301)
CHAPTER 2
ELECTRICAL DEPARTMENT AND SYSTEM REGULATIONS
SECTION:
8-2-1: Organization Of Department
8-2-2: Scope Of System
8-2-3: Ownership Of System
8-2-4: Contract For Management
8-2-5: Service Limits
8-2-6: Application For Service
8-2-7: Deposit Required
8-2-8: Rates And Penalty Fees
8-2-9: Meters
8-2-10: Easements
8-2-11: Wiring
8-2-12: Tampering With System
8-2-13: Penalty
8-2-1: ORGANIZATION OF DEPARTMENT:
   A.   Created; Department Head: There is hereby created the Department of
Electricity. The department shall consist of a department head, who shall be a
member of the City Council, and such other persons as shall be appointed to
serve in the department from time to time. (1995 Code § 3-4-101)
   B.   Appointment Of Officers And Employees: All other officers and employees
in the department shall be appointed by the Mayor, upon the recommendation of
the department head and Personnel Officer, with the advice and consent of the
City Council. (1995 Code § 3-4-102)
   C.   Objectives Of Department: The Department of Electricity is created with
the express objective of providing electricity and electrical services to the
residents of the City and whosoever else the City Council deems appropriate.
(1995 Code § 3-4-103)
8-2-2: SCOPE OF SYSTEM:
   A.   Maintenance: The City Electric System shall be maintained so that the
system may meet both present electrical need and future electrical need of the
residents of the City.
   B.   Electrical Code Compliance: The City Electric System shall be
constructed and maintained in accordance with the most recent edition of the
National Electrical Code.
   C.   Obstruction Of Easements: Construction over or under any City utility
line is prohibited. Utility easements shall remain free of obstruction for
system maintenance and repairs.
   D.   Costs Of Maintenance; Upgrades And Extensions: Normal costs of
electrical system maintenance shall be paid from revenues received from
electrical services and not from taxation of City residents. If a user of the
City electricity requests an upgrade or extension of the system which is not
part of normal maintenance, the cost of such upgrade or extension shall be
borne by the user. (1995 Code § 3-4-201)
   E.   Customer new construction or changes to existing electric systems where
they interconnect to the City distribution system shall meet the standards of
meters, installation and service as set forth in Fillmore City Electric
Policies. (1995 Code § 3-4-207; amd. Ord. 17-01, 3-21-2017)
   F.   All ordinances, resolutions, orders, or other actions of the Fillmore
City Council in conflict with the provisions of this section are, to the extent
of such conflict deemed to be amended by this section to conform with the
provisions of this section. (1995 Code § 3-4-302)
8-2-3: OWNERSHIP OF SYSTEM:
All property used to carry out the objectives stated in subsection 8-2-1C of
this chapter, including, but not limited to, all electrical meters located on
properties served by the Department of Electricity, is the property of the
City. (1995 Code § 3-4-202)
8-2-4: CONTRACT FOR MANAGEMENT:
The City Council shall have authority to contract with a private entity for the
management of the City Electrical System. (1995 Code § 3-4-213)
8-2-5: SERVICE LIMITS:
The City Electrical System shall operate within the City boundaries. The City
may construct electric infrastructure outside City boundaries in certain
circumstances in order to further the City Electrical System; however, the City
will not allow connections to the Fillmore City Electrical System outside of
its City boundaries. (1995 Code § 3-4-203; amd. Ord. 23-01, 2-7-2023)
8-2-6: APPLICATION FOR SERVICE:
Persons desiring service from the City electric distribution system must apply
for such service to the City. Requirements for the application shall be adopted
by the City Council through either policy or resolution. (1995 Code § 3-4-205)
8-2-7: DEPOSIT REQUIRED:
With each application, there shall be a deposit in an amount determined by the
City Council. The City Council shall adopt deposit requirements and procedures
through either policy or resolution. (1995 Code § 3-4-206)
8-2-8: RATES AND PENALTY FEES:
   A.   Billing: Bills for electric service shall be sent at such times as the
City Council designates. The City Council shall adopt procedures concerning
billing through either policy or resolution. (1995 Code § 3-4-210)
   B.   Rate Schedule; Penalty: The City Council shall have the power to
establish electrical rates. The City Council shall adopt rates in the form of
policy or resolution, and such rates shall be included in the fee and rate
schedule. All accounts shall be assessed a penalty of five percent (5%) on the
unpaid balance after the fifteenth of each month. Should the fifteenth fall on
a weekend or City observed holiday, the penalty deadline shall be extended to
the next business day. (Ord. 06-04, 4-4-2006)
8-2-9: METERS:
   A.   Required: All premises served by the City electric distribution system
shall be equipped with an accurate meter, and paid for and installed according
to City Electric Policies. All charges shall be on the appropriate electric
rate.
   B.   Access: All utility meters shall be outside and accessible to
authorized representatives of the City.
   C.   Renewal Power Interconnections: Renewal power interconnections to the
City system shall be as required in the City Electric Policies.
   D.   Customer new construction or changes to existing electric systems where
they interconnect to the City distribution system shall meet the standards of
meters, installation and service as set forth in Fillmore City Electric
Policies. (1995 Code § 3-4-207; amd. Ord. 17-01, 3-21-2017)
8-2-10: EASEMENTS:
Construction over or under any City utility line is prohibited. Utility
easements must remain free of obstruction for system maintenance. The City
Council may authorize relocation of existing utilities and utility easements,
but it shall be the policy of the City that the City not bear such relocation
costs unless such relocation benefits the City as a whole. (Ord. 01-04, 6-5-
2001)
8-2-11: WIRING:
Electrical current shall not be turned on into any new wiring installed after
January 21, 1992 unless:
   A.   The wiring fully complies with the provisions of the most recent
edition of the National Electrical Code; and
   B.   The City building inspector has certified, in writing, that the wiring
complies with the provisions of the most recent edition of the National
Electrical Code. (1995 Code § 3-4-209)
8-2-12: TAMPERING WITH SYSTEM:
It shall be unlawful to tamper, modify, injure or change any part of the City
electric distribution system, or any meter thereon, without authority from the
City Council. A license from the State or the City for electrical contracting
shall be deemed sufficient authority from the City. (1995 Code § 3-4-211)
8-2-13: PENALTY:
Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of this chapter shall
be guilty of an infraction, subject to penalty as provided in title 1, chapter
4 of this Code. A separate offense shall be deemed committed upon each day
during or on which a violation occurs or continues. (1995 Code § 3-4-212; amd.
2019 Code)
ARTICLE A. ELECTRIC UTILITY COST RECOVERY POLICY
SECTION:
8-2A-1: Policy For Recovery
8-2A-2: Appeal To City Council
8-2A-3: Term Of Recovery Period
8-2A-4: Nonapplicable To New Subdivisions
8-2A-5: City Exempt From Policy
8-2A-6: Penalty
8-2A-1: POLICY FOR RECOVERY:
   A.   Specified: Subject to section
8-2A-2 of this article, any person who requests and is qualified to receive
electric service from the City shall pay all the costs associated with
extending the electrical system to the customer's premises; provided, said
person and each customer who connects to the extended electrical system
thereafter, shall be entitled to a recovery of fifty percent (50%) of the costs
he/she pays for connecting to said electrical system from the next subsequent
customer who connects thereon. When a person recovers said costs from the next
subsequent customer who connects to the system, said person shall be deemed
compensated in full and no longer eligible to recover additional costs. Subject
to section
8-2A-3 of this article, recovery cost reimbursement shall cease once recovery
costs reach a minimum of one hundred dollars ($100.00).
   B.   Illustration: By way of illustration:
      1.   Customer A requests and pays ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) for a
one thousand foot (1,000') utility line extension. Customer B hooks up to the
line four hundred feet (400') from the original point of extension, attributing
forty percent (40%) of the line to customer B (1,000 times 40 percent equals
400 feet). Customer A is entitled to fifty percent (50%) of the cost value from
customer B's hookup ($10,000.00 times 40 percent equals $4,000.00). Customer A
may continue to recoup from subsequent customers up to fifty percent (50%) of
the costs expended to extend the line. Customer A shall then be considered
fully compensated and become ineligible to recover any additional costs.
      2.   Customer C is given a connection to the original line extension.
Customer B shall be entitled to recovery from customer C and/or subsequent
customers two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00), which is fifty percent
(50%) of the cost customer B paid to customer A ($5,000.00). Customer B shall
then be considered fully compensated and become ineligible to recover any
additional costs.
      3.   Customer B requests and pays for an additional line extension,
beyond customer A's original line extension. Customer A shall be entitled to
recover fifty percent (50%) of his/her total extension costs ($5,000.00) from
customer B. Customer B shall be entitled to recover fifty percent (50%) from
customer C and/or subsequent customers ($2,500.00) of the costs customer B paid
to customer A and in addition thereto, customer B shall be entitled to recover
fifty percent (50%) of the costs from customers who connect to customer B's
additional line extension. Customer B shall then be considered fully
compensated and become ineligible to recover any additional costs.
      4.   This pattern continues until the cost recovery is less than one
hundred dollars ($100.00). (Ord. 05-11, 10-18-2005)
8-2A-2: APPEAL TO CITY COUNCIL:
If situations arise that make it difficult or inequitable to apply the cost
recovery formula set forth in section
8-2A-1 of this article, the City Council will determine the amount allowed, on
a case by case basis, to the person or entity entitled to cost recovery. Such a
determination shall be made only after such person or entity appeals to the
City Council for consideration of such cost recovery. The City Council's
decision shall be final. (Ord. 05-11, 10-18-2005)
8-2A-3: TERM OF RECOVERY PERIOD:
The cost recovery period shall be limited to ten (10) years from the date of
the first service connection on the original line extension and ten (10) years
from the date of the first service connection on any extension to said original
line extension. (Ord. 05-11, 10-18-2005)
8-2A-4: NONAPPLICABLE TO NEW SUBDIVISIONS:
The cost recovery policy set forth in this article shall not apply to new
subdivisions, as the owners or developers of such subdivisions can pass such
costs on to buyers of subdivided lots. (Ord. 05-11, 10-18-2005)
8-2A-5: CITY EXEMPT FROM POLICY:
The City shall be exempt from this policy and may connect to any electric
system for any purpose at any time without repayment of extension costs. (Ord.
05-11, 10-18-2005)
8-2A-6: PENALTY:
Any person, firm or corporation violating any provisions of this article shall
be guilty of an infraction, subject to penalty as provided in title 1, chapter
4 of this Code. A separate offense shall be deemed committed upon each day
during or on which a violation occurs or continues. (2019 Code)
CHAPTER 3
WATER DEPARTMENT AND SYSTEM REGULATIONS
SECTION:
8-3-1: Organization Of Department
8-3-2: Water System Defined
8-3-3: Water Connections
8-3-4: Rates And Penalty Fees
8-3-5: Meters
8-3-6: Line Construction
8-3-7: Plumbing Service
8-3-8: Resale Of Water
8-3-9: Easements
8-3-10: Reduction In Water Usage
8-3-11: Tampering With System
8-3-12: Unlawful Connections
8-3-13: Penalty
8-3-14: Water Shutoff Authorized When
8-3-1: ORGANIZATION OF DEPARTMENT:
   A.   Water Department Created: There is hereby created the Department of
Water. The department shall consist of a department head, who shall be a member
of the City Council, and such other persons as shall be appointed to serve in
the department from time to time. (1995 Code § 3-5-101)
   B.   Water Superintendent:
      1.   The Mayor shall appoint, with the advice and consent of the City
Council, a person to supervise the City's water system. He or she shall be
known as the Water Superintendent.
      2.   The Water Superintendent shall have charge of all waters and water
sources, water tanks, water mains, fire hydrants, and all equipment pertaining
to the water system.
      3.   He or she shall supervise the laying of water mains and putting in
all service pipes, and shall regulate the supply or water in the City.
      4.   He or she shall also perform such other duties as may be required by
ordinance or by the direction of the Mayor or City Council. (1995 Code § 3-5-
202)
   C.   Appointment Of Officers And Employees: All other officers and employees
in the department shall be appointed by the Mayor, upon the recommendation of
the department head and Personnel Officer, with the advice and consent of the
City Council. (1995 Code § 3-5-102)
   D.   Objectives Of Department: The Department of Water is created with the
express objective of providing culinary water and water service to the
residents of the City and whosoever else the City Council deems appropriate.
(1995 Code § 3-5-103)
8-3-2: WATER SYSTEM DEFINED:
The water system consisting of water rights, tanks, pipelines, fire hydrants,
water meters and all other equipment used with water management, transportation
or consumption owned and maintained by the City is hereby designated as part of
the City Water System. (1995 Code § 3-5-201)
8-3-3: WATER CONNECTIONS:
   A.   Connection Requires Authority: The water from the City water supply
shall not be turned on for service into any premises by any person but the
Water Superintendent or some person authorized by him to perform this service.
(1995 Code § 3-5-203)
   B.   Application; Agreement: Application to have water turned on shall be
made to the City Treasurer, or other City officer or employee, and shall
contain an agreement for the applicant to abide by and accept all provisions of
this chapter and conditions governing the use of the City water supply. (1995
Code § 3-5-203; amd. 2019 Code)
   C.   Special Permission For Additional Users: It shall be unlawful for two
(2) or more families or service users to be supplied from the same service
pipe, connection or water meter unless special permission for such usage has
been granted by the City Council and the premises served is owned by the same
owner. (1995 Code § 3-5-203)
   D.   Service Pipe Defined: Service pipe shall mean any pipe smaller than a
four inch (4") pipe.
   E.   Inadequate Lines: New development in areas with an existing service
line which is four inches (4") or smaller and which the City Water
Superintendent deems inadequate to service the new development, shall be
required to extend a main line at the expense of the developer. Size of main
line to be determined by the City Water Superintendent to provide adequate fire
protection. Main line pipe shall be six inches (6") or larger. (Ord. 99-03, 2-
2-1999)
8-3-4: RATES AND PENALTY FEES:
   A.   Rate Schedule: The City Council shall have the power to establish water
rates. The City Council shall adopt rates in the form of policy or resolution
and such rates shall be included in the fee and rate schedule.
   B.   Collection; Penalty: Policies and procedures of the City for collecting
payment of water bills shall be included in the City Utility Policy as adopted
or amended by the City Council. All accounts shall be assessed a penalty of
five percent (5%) of the unpaid balance after the fifteenth of each month.
Should the fifteenth fall on a weekend or City observed holiday, the penalty
deadline shall be extended to the next business day. (Ord. 06-04, 4-4-2006)
8-3-5: METERS:
   A.   Required: All premises using City water supply must be equipped with an
adequate water meter furnished by the City, but paid for by the consumer;
provided, that such water service may be supplied by the City at a flat rate of
charge until such meter may be installed.
   B.   Location; Access: The meter shall be installed in a location that will
provide easy access to the City.
   C.   Readings: The Public Works Superintendent shall read or cause to be
read all water meters used in the City on a bi-monthly basis and bill the water
user in monthly installments. (1995 Code § 3-5-401)
8-3-6: LINE CONSTRUCTION:
   A.   Installation:
      1.   All service pipes from the mains to the premises served shall be
installed by the owner of the property to be served or the applicant for the
service. Such installation shall be under the inspection of the Water
Superintendent.
      2.   All extension of the water main line shall be made at the expense of
the person or other entity desiring to extend the main line, except that no
main line may be extended without the permission of the City Council.
         a.   Any person or other entity who connects to a water main line
which was extended at the expense of a private property owner shall be liable
to the person or other entity that bore the original expense of extending the
main line.
         b.   Fillmore City shall make all reasonable attempts including
placing a lien on the property of the person who connects to the main line
extended by the original private property owner.
   B.   Service Limits: The City's Culinary Water System shall operate within
the City boundaries. The City may construct culinary water infrastructure
outside City boundaries in certain circumstances in order to further the City's
Culinary Water System; however, the City will not allow connections to the
City's Culinary Water System outside of City boundaries.
   C.   Specifications: No service shall be installed unless it conforms to
specifications drawn up by the City Council and approved thereby.
   D.   Maintenance: All repairs for service pipes and plumbing systems of the
building shall be made by and at the expense of the owners of the premises
served. The City may, in case of emergency, repair any service pipes and if
this is done, the cost of such repairs shall be repaid to the City by the owner
of the premises served.
   E.   Excavations: Excavations for installing service pipes or repairing the
same shall remain in compliance with the ordinance provisions relating to
making excavations in the streets; provided, that it shall be unlawful to place
any service pipe in the same excavation with, or directly over, any drain pipe
or sewer pipe.
   F.   Shutoff Boxes: Shutoff boxes or service boxes shall be placed on every
service pipe and shall be located between the curb line and the sidewalk line
where this is practicable. Such boxes shall be so located so that they are
easily accessible and shall be protected from frost. (1995 Code §§ 3-5-301
through 3-5-306; amd. 2019 Code; Ord. 23-01, 2-7-2023)
8-3-7: PLUMBING SERVICE:
No water shall be turned on temporarily for service in premises in which the
plumbing does not comply with the ordinances of the City; provided, that water
may be turned on temporarily for construction work in an unfinished building,
subject to the provisions of this chapter. (1995 Code § 3-5-204)
8-3-8: RESALE OF WATER:
No water shall be resold or distributed by the recipient thereof from the City
water supply to any premises other than that for which application has been
made and the meter installed, except in case of emergency. (1995 Code § 3-5-
205)
8-3-9: EASEMENTS:
Construction over or under any City utility line is prohibited. Utility
easements must remain free of obstruction for system maintenance. The City
Council may authorize relocation of existing utilities and utility easements,
but it shall be the policy of the City that the City not bear such relocation
costs unless such relocation benefits the City as a whole. (Ord. 01-04, 6-5-
2001)
8-3-10: REDUCTION IN WATER USAGE:
   A.   Authority: The Mayor is hereby empowered pursuant to title 1, chapter 6
of this Code to ration water when in his or her judgment such need exists.
   B.   Water Usage Reduction: In the event it becomes necessary to reduce
water usage in the City due to water scarcity, drought or other unforeseen
conditions, the Mayor is hereby directed to reduce water usage in the following
order:
      1.   Outdoor Water Usage: The Mayor may proclaim the number of hours of
water usage and/or the time of outdoor water usage, up to and including no
outdoor water usage.
      2.   Large Water Users: Water users who use in excess of fifteen thousand
(15,000) gallons per month, shall be required to reduce usage to the number of
gallons proclaimed by the Mayor.
      3.   City Property: The Mayor may proclaim the number of hours of water
usage or the time for water usage for City property, up to and including no
water usage.
   C.   Prioritization Of Categories: The City Council may, by separate policy
or regulation, prioritize under each category set forth under subsection B of
this section, a reduction of the types of water uses and if pertinent, the
location of water use.
   D.   Exigent Circumstances: Notwithstanding subsection B of this section,
the Mayor may direct a reduction in water use other than as set forth in this
section if in his/her judgment a different priority schedule is warranted under
the circumstances.
   E.   Additional Remedies: In addition to and apart from any criminal
proceeding initiated hereunder, the Mayor is hereby authorized to take any
enforcement measures he/she deems necessary to protect the City water supply,
including, but not limited to, refusing water service to any person or entity
who fails to comply with any water reduction schedule mandated by the Mayor or
City Council. The City may also pursue any other remedy available at law or in
equity. In furtherance thereof, the City Council may adopt rules or policies,
from time to time, governing the procedure to be used by the City in pursuing
such remedies. (Ord. 02-15, 8-20-2002)
   F.   Penalty: Any violations of this section shall be a Class B misdemeanor,
subject to penalty as provided in title 1, chapter 4 of this Code. (Ord. 02-15,
8-20-2002; amd. 2019 Code)
8-3-11: TAMPERING WITH SYSTEM:
It shall be unlawful for any person not authorized by the City to tamper with,
alter or injure any part of the City waterworks or supply system, or any meter.
(1995 Code § 3-5-206)
8-3-12: UNLAWFUL CONNECTIONS:
Any person, firm or corporation shall not make any connection to the City
waterworks system without the permission of the City. (1995 Code § 3-5-403)
8-3-13: PENALTY:
   A.   Nothing in this chapter shall be interpreted as prohibiting institution
of criminal charges against any person stealing water from the City by
bypassing a meter, tampering with a meter or by any other means.
   B.   Any person found violating any provision of this chapter shall be
guilty of a Class C misdemeanor upon conviction of a first offense. A second
conviction under this chapter shall be a Class B misdemeanor. A third
conviction under this section shall be a Class “A” Misdemeanor. A fourth
conviction under this section shall be a third degree felony. (1995 Code § 3-5-
404; amd. 2019 Code)
8-3-14: WATER SHUTOFF AUTHORIZED WHEN:
Fillmore City reserves the right at any time, without notice, to shut off the
water from its mains for the purpose of making repairs or extensions, or for
other purposes, and no claim shall be made against the city, by reason of any
breakage whatsoever, or for any damage that may result from shutting off the
water for repairing, laying or relaying mains, hydrants or other connections,
or for any other reason whatsoever. (Ord. 14-16, 5-7-2024)
ARTICLE A. BACKFLOW AND CROSS CONNECTIONS
SECTION:
8-3A-1: Title
8-3A-2: Purpose
8-3A-3: Definitions
8-3A-4: City Responsibility
8-3A-5: Consumer Responsibility
8-3A-6: Building Inspector Responsibility
8-3A-7: Certified Backflow Technicians, Surveyors And Repair Persons
Responsibility
8-3A-8: Pollution Control Requirements
8-3A-9: Discontinuance Of Service
8-3A-1: TITLE:
This article shall be known as the CROSS CONNECTIONS ORDINANCE OF FILLMORE
CITY. (1995 Code § 3-5-501)
8-3A-2: PURPOSE:
The purposes of this article are to:
   A.   Protect the safe drinking water supply of the City from the possibility
of contamination or pollution by adopting codes, health regulations, OSHA and
other applicable industry standards for water system safety within the water
system. Compliance with these minimum Safety Codes will be considered
reasonable vigilance for prevention of contaminants or pollutants which could
backflow into the public drinking water systems; and
   B.   Promote reasonable elimination or control of cross connections in the
plumbing fixtures and industrial and local Plumbing Codes, health regulations,
OSHA and other applicable industry standards to assure water system safety; and
   C.   Provide for the administration of a continuing program of backflow
prevention which will systematically and effectively prevent the contamination
or pollution of all drinking water systems. (1995 Code § 3-5-502)
8-3A-3: DEFINITIONS:
The following words and phrases used in this chapter shall have the following
meanings unless a different meaning clearly appears from the context:
APPROVED BACKFLOW ASSEMBLY: Accepted by the Utah Department of Health, Bureau
of Drinking Water and Sanitation, as meeting an applicable specification or as
suitable for the proposed use.
AUXILIARY WATER SUPPLY: Any water supply on or available to the premises other
than the purveyor's public water supply will be considered as an auxiliary
water supply. These auxiliary waters may include water from another purveyor's
public potable water supply or any natural sources, such as a well, spring,
river, stream, harbor, etc., or "used waters" or "industrial fluids". These
waters may be contaminated or polluted, or they may be objectionable and
constitute an unacceptable water source over which the water purveyor does not
have authority for sanitary control.
BACK PRESSURE: The flow of water or other liquids, mixtures or substances under
pressure into the feeding distribution pipes of a potable water supply system
from any source, other than the intended source.
BACK SIPHONAGE: The flow of water or other liquids, mixtures or substances
under pressure into the feeding distribution pipes of a potable water supply
system.
BACKFLOW: The reversal of the normal flow of water caused by either back
pressure or back siphonage.
BACKFLOW PREVENTION ASSEMBLY: An assembly or means designed to prevent
backflow. Specifications for backflow prevention assemblies are contained
within the Utah Plumbing Code, and the Cross Connection Control Program for
Utah.
CONTAMINATION: A degradation of the quality of the potable water supply by
sewage, industrial fluids or waste liquids, compounds or other materials.
CROSS CONNECTION: Any physical connection or arrangement of piping or fixtures
which may allow nonpotable water or industrial fluids or other materials of
questionable quality to come in contact with potable water inside a
distribution system. This would include any temporary connections, such as
swing connections, removable sections, four way plug valves, spools, dummy
sections of pipe, swivel or change over devices or sliding multiport tubes or
other plumbing arrangements.
CROSS CONNECTION CONTAINMENT: The installation of an approved backflow assembly
at the water service connection to any customer's premises where it is
physically and economically infeasible to find and permanently eliminate or
control all actual or potential cross connections within the customer's water
system, or it shall mean the installation of an approved backflow prevention
assembly on the service line leading to and supplying a portion of a customer's
water system where there are actual or potential cross connections which cannot
be effectively eliminated or controlled at the point of the cross connection
(isolation).
CROSS CONNECTION, CONTROLLED: A connection between a potable water system and a
nonpotable water system with an approved backflow prevention assembly properly
installed and maintained so that it will continuously afford the protection
commensurate with the degree of hazard.
WATER PURVEYOR: Fillmore City and the Water Superintendent are vested with the
authority and responsibility for the implementation of an effective cross
connection control program and for the enforcement of the provisions of this
article. (1995 Code § 3-5-508; amd. 2019 Code)
8-3A-4: CITY RESPONSIBILITY:
   A.   System Protection: The City shall be responsible for the protection of
the drinking water distribution system from foreseeable conditions leading to
possible contamination or pollution of the drinking water system due to the
backflow of contaminants or pollutants into drinking water supply.
   B.   Surveys Or Inspections: Drinking water system surveys or inspections of
the consumer's water distribution system shall be conducted or caused to be
conducted by individuals deemed qualified by and representing the City. Survey
records shall indicate compliance with the aforementioned health and safety
standard. All such records will be maintained by the City.
   C.   Notice Of Survey Requirement: The City shall notify in writing all
consumers of the need for the periodic system survey to ensure compliance with
existing applicable minimum health and safety standards.
   D.   Type Of Assembly: Selection of an approved backflow prevention assembly
for containment control required at the service entrance shall be determined
from the results of the system survey. (1995 Code § 3-5-503)
8-3A-5: CONSUMER RESPONSIBILITY:
   A.   Compliance: It shall be the responsibility of the consumer to comply
with this article as a term and condition of supply and consumer's acceptance
of service is admittance of his or her awareness.
   B.   Device Or Assembly: It shall be the responsibility of the consumer to
purchase, install, test and maintain any backflow prevention device or assembly
required to comply with this article. (1995 Code § 3-5-504)
8-3A-6: BUILDING INSPECTOR RESPONSIBILITY:
   A.   Begins At Point Of Service: The building inspector's responsibility to
enforce the applicable sections of the Plumbing Code begins at the point of
service (downstream or consumer side of the meter) and continues throughout the
developed length of the consumer's water system.
   B.   Plan Review: The building inspector will review all plans to ensure
that unprotected cross connections are not an integral part of the consumer's
water system. If a cross connection cannot be eliminated, it must be protected
by the installation of an air gap or an approved backflow prevention device or
assembly, in accordance with the Utah Plumbing Code.
   C.   Approved Assembly: Water vacating the drinking water supply must do so
via approved air gap or approved mechanical backflow prevention assembly,
properly installed and in accordance with the Utah Plumbing Code. (1995 Code §
3-5-505)
8-3A-7: CERTIFIED BACKFLOW TECHNICIANS, SURVEYORS AND REPAIR PERSONS
RESPONSIBILITY:
   A.   Specified: Whether employed by the consumer or a utility to test,
repair or maintain backflow prevention assemblies, the certified backflow
technicians, surveyors or repair persons will have the following
responsibilities:
      1.   Ensuring acceptance testing equipment and procedures are used for
testing, repairing or overhauling backflow prevention assemblies.
      2.   Make reports of such testing and/or repair to the consumer, water
purveyor, and the Bureau of Drinking Water and Sanitation on forms approved for
such use by the Bureau of Drinking Water and Sanitation, and within the time
frame prescribed by the Bureau of Drinking Water and Sanitation.
      3.   The report shall include the list of materials or replacement parts
used.
      4.   Ensuring replacement parts are equal in quality to the parts
originally supplied by the manufacturer of the assembly being repaired.
      5.   Not changing the design, material or operational characteristics of
the assembly during testing, repair or maintenance. (1995 Code § 3-5-506)
   B.   Commercial Assembly: In the case of a consumer requiring a commercially
available technician, any certified technician is authorized to make the test
and report of results of that test to the consumer, water purveyor and the
Bureau of Drinking Water and Sanitation. If such a commercially test assembly
is in need of repair, a licensed plumber shall make the actual repair. (1995
Code § 3-5-506; amd. 2019 Code)
8-3A-8: POLLUTION CONTROL REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Policy: No water service connection to any premises shall be installed
or maintained by the public water purveyor unless the water supply is protected
as required by State laws, regulations, codes, other State requirements, and
this article. Services of water to a consumer found to be in violation of this
article shall be discontinued by the water purveyor after due process of
written notification of violation and an appropriate time suspense for
voluntary compliance if: (1995 Code § 3-5-507; amd. 2019 Code)
      1.   A backflow prevention assembly required by this article for control
of backflow and cross connections is not installed, tested and maintained; or
      2.   If it is found that a backflow prevention assembly has been removed
or by passed; or
      3.   If an unprotected cross connection exists on the premises; or
      4.   If the periodic system survey has not been conducted.
   B.   Inspections: The customer's system shall be open for inspection at all
reasonable times to authorized representatives of the water purveyor to
determine whether cross connections or other structural or sanitary hazards,
including violation of this article, exist and to audit the results of the
required survey. (1995 Code § 3-5-507)
   C.   Assembly Required: Whenever the public water purveyor deems a service
connection's water usage contributes a sufficient hazard to the water supply,
an approved backflow prevention assembly shall be installed on the service line
of the identified consumer's water system, at or near the property line, or
immediately inside the building being serviced as requested by the water
purveyor; but, in all cases, before the first branch line leading off the
service line. (1995 Code § 3-5-507; amd. 2019 Code)
   D.   Type Of Assembly: The type of protective assembly required shall depend
upon the degree of hazard which exists at the point of cross connection
(whether direct or indirect), applicable to local and State requirements or
resulting from the required survey.
   E.   Presently Installed Assemblies: All presently installed backflow
prevention assemblies which do not meet the requirements of this section but
were approved assemblies for the purposes described herein at the time of
installation and which have been properly maintained, shall, except for the
inspection and maintenance requirements, be excluded from the requirements of
these rules so long as the water purveyor is assured that they will
satisfactorily protect the public water system. Whenever more than minimum
maintenance or when the water purveyor finds that the operation or maintenance
of this assembly constitutes a hazard to health, the unit shall be replaced by
an approved backflow prevention assembly meeting the local and State
requirements.
   F.   Surveys Or Inspections: It shall be the responsibility of the consumer
at any premises where backflow prevention assemblies are installed to have
certified surveys or inspections and operational tests made at least once per
year at the consumer's expense. In those instances where the public water
purveyor deems the hazard to be great, he may require certified surveys and
inspections and tests at a more frequent interval. It shall be the duty of the
public water purveyor to see that these tests are made according to the
standards set forth by the State Department of Health, Bureau of Drinking Water
and Sanitation.
   G.   Time Of Testing: All backflow prevention assemblies shall be tested
within ten (10) working days of initial installation.
   H.   Safety Hazards: No backflow prevention assembly shall be installed so
as to create a safety hazard. Example: Installed over an electrical panel,
steam pipes, boilers, pits or above ceiling level. (1995 Code § 3-5-507)
8-3A-9: DISCONTINUANCE OF SERVICE:
If violations of this article exist, or if there has not been any corrective
action taken by the consumer within ten (10) days of the written notification
of deficiencies noted within the survey, then the public water purveyor shall
deny or immediately discontinue service to the premises by providing a physical
break in the service line until the customer has corrected the conditions in
conformance with the State and City Statutes relating to the regulations
adopted pursuant hereto. (1995 Code § 3-5-509)
ARTICLE B. WATER UTILITY COST RECOVERY POLICY
SECTION:
8-3B-1: Policy For Recovery
8-3B-2: Appeal To City Council
8-3B-3: Term Of Recovery Period
8-3B-4: Nonapplicable To New Subdivisions
8-3B-5: City Exempt From Policy
8-3B-6: Penalty
8-3B-1: POLICY FOR RECOVERY:
   A.   Specified: Subject to section
8-3B-2 of this article, any person who requests and is qualified to receive
water service from the City shall pay all the costs associated with extending
the water system to the customer's premises; provided, said person and each
customer who connects to the extended water system thereafter, shall be
entitled to a recovery of fifty percent (50%) of the costs he/she pays for
connecting to said water system from the next subsequent customer who connects
thereon. When a person recovers said costs from the next subsequent customer
who connects to the system, said person shall be deemed compensated in full and
no longer eligible to recover additional costs. Subject to section
8-3B-3 of this article, recovery costs reimbursement shall cease once recovery
costs reach a minimum of one hundred dollars ($100.00).
   B.   Illustration: By way of illustration, see section 8-2A-1B of this
title, the Electric Utility Cost Recovery Policy. (Ord. 05-11, 10-18-2005)
8-3B-2: APPEAL TO CITY COUNCIL:
If situations arise that make it difficult or inequitable to apply the cost
recovery formula set forth in this article, the City Council will determine the
amount allowed, on a case by case basis, to the person or entity entitled to
cost recovery. Such a determination shall be made only after such person or
entity appeals to the City Council for consideration of such cost recovery. The
