City Council's decision shall be final. (Ord. 05-11, 10-18-2005)
8-3B-3: TERM OF RECOVERY PERIOD:
The cost recovery period shall be limited to ten (10) years from the date of
the first service connection on the original line extension and ten (10) years
from the date of the first service connection on any extensions to said
original line extension. (Ord. 05-11, 10-18-2005)
8-3B-4: NONAPPLICABLE TO NEW SUBDIVISIONS:
The cost recovery policy set forth in this article shall not apply to new
subdivisions as the owners or developers of such subdivisions can pass such
costs on to buyers of subdivided lots. (Ord. 05-11, 10-18-2005)
8-3B-5: CITY EXEMPT FROM POLICY:
The City shall be exempt from this policy and may connect to any water system
for any purpose at any time without repayment of extension costs. (Ord. 05-11,
10-18-2005)
8-3B-6: PENALTY:
Any person, firm or corporation violating any provisions of this section shall
be guilty of an infraction, subject to penalty as provided in title 1, chapter
4 of this Code. A separate offense shall be deemed committed upon each day
during or on which a violation occurs or continues. (Ord. 05-11, 10-18-2005;
amd. 2019 Code)
ARTICLE C. CONVEYANCE OF ADEQUATE WATER FOR NEW DEVELOPMENT
SECTION:
8-3C-1: Title
8-3C-2: Purpose
8-3C-3: Timing
8-3C-4: Amount Or Quantity Required
8-3C-5: Fee
8-3C-6: Quality Of Water Resource
8-3C-1: TITLE:
This article shall be known as the CONVEYANCE OF WATER FOR NEW DEVELOPMENT
ORDINANCE OF FILLMORE CITY. (Ord. 24-19, 8-6-2024)
8-3C-2: PURPOSE:
The purposes of this article are as follows:
A.   The City's primary purpose for establishing this article is to acquire
municipal water rights and resources to serve its future population with
culinary water.
B.   In consideration of the current City water rights and resources,
anticipated growth and expansion of service area, pending studies, and
considering the reasonable future requirements of the City, the City finds that
new development and annexed property must provide the City with sufficient
municipal water rights to satisfy all future anticipated culinary uses.
C.   The City Council shall determine the sufficient acre feet for each single-
family residence, multi-family, industrial or commercial installation based on
anticipated water use, in a quality, quantity and priority as advised and
considering the requirements of the Utah Division of Drinking Water and the
Utah Division of Water Rights. (Ord. 24-19, 8-6-2024)
8-3C-3: TIMING:
A.   New Development: Prior to final approval of a plat map, if required, or
prior to issuance of a building permit, when no plat map is required, all new
development must convey water right(s) to the City in an amount sufficient to
meet anticipated demand for the proposed use(s) or pay a fee in lieu of
conveying water as provided herein. No plat will be recorded, no building
permit will be approved, and no certificate of occupancy will be issued until
the City accepts or receives such contribution or payment as provided herein.
B.   Annexation: Prior to final approval of any annexation, including the
approval of an annexation ordinance, the petitioner of such annexation petition
must convey to the City by warranty deed all water right(s) required herein.
The details regarding the transfer of water will be included within an
annexation agreement between the petitioner and the City and shall be recorded
at the office of the Millard County Recorder.
C.   Notwithstanding the provisions of this code, no additional water will be
required for any existing dwelling or structure within the City as of the date
of approval of this article. This includes constructed dwellings or structures
and valid, approved building permits for dwellings or structures. (Ord. 24-19,
8-6-2024)
8-3C-4: AMOUNT OR QUANTITY REQUIRED:
A.   The amount (number of acre-feet) of water required to be conveyed to the
City shall be the amount considered sufficient to meet the water use
requirements of the proposed use, to be determined in accordance with the
following table:
 
                      Based on Equivalent
Use                   Residential Connections Acre-Feet Required per ERC
                      (ERC)
                                              The average annual ERC use as
Residential Uses      1.00 per dwelling unit  established in the current
                                              Division Of Drinking Water for
                                              Fillmore City1
Non-residential Uses  An amount sufficient to meet the projected needs of the
(including, but not   proposed development based on an evaluation of demand
limited to Industrial characteristics for similar uses as determined by the
and Commercial Uses)  City’s engineering department
 
Subject to change to follow the average annual ERC use as established in the
current Division of Drinking Water for Fillmore City.
B.   Unless otherwise mitigated, the priority date of any contributed water
right(s) relied upon to meet these ordinances must have sufficient seniority to
be deemed a reliable source of water in perpetuity without risk of a priority
call.
C.   Subsequent to a determination of water requirement, if the use of an
existing development is modified and results in an increased use of water,
additional water right(s) sufficient to meet the projected needs of the
modified use shall be required to be conveyed to the City before a building
permit is issued. If a building permit is not required for the expanded use of
water, the owner of the land shall provide additional water right(s) to the
City to meet the expanded use within thirty (30) days of the expanded use.
D.   Any person or entity desiring to extend the water system of the City to a
project or development, including extensions for annexations, shall submit a
description of the project, engineered drawings and projections for the
development and culinary water use. For an annexation petition, this
information will provide a basis for an annexation agreement between the
developer and the City.
1.   Currently 0.90 per ERC for combined indoor/outdoor use for a single family
home, but subject to change in accordance with the average annual ERC use as
established in the current Division of Drinking Water for Fillmore City.
(Ord. 24-19, 8-6-2024)
8-3C-5: FEE:
For all developments within City limits, a developer shall pay a fee of three
thousand dollars ($3,000.00) per equivalent residential connection ("ERC") in
lieu of conveying water for all developments. If the demand for a development
exceeds one hundred fifty (150) ERCs, the developer is not eligible to pay a
fee and must convey water right(s) as provided herein. (Ord. 24-19, 8-6-2024)
8-3C-6: QUALITY OF WATER RESOURCE:
Water right(s) conveyed to the City in satisfaction of this article shall meet
the following requirements:
A.   The City shall have opportunity to review such water right(s) and any
document deemed relevant to the City's review in order to indicate its
willingness to accept the water right(s).
B.   The water right(s) shall have a priority date with sufficient seniority to
be deemed a reliable source of water in perpetuity without risk of a priority
call as determined by the City.
C.   Any applicant for annexation must have complied with any water provisions
in the Annexation Agreement entered for said purpose.
D.   The executed warranty deed of the water right(s) and the executed
Annexation Agreement must be duly recorded with the Millard County Recorder's
Office.
E.   The water right(s) must be approved without appeal or reconsideration from
the Utah Division of Water Rights for diversion of the water for year-round
municipal purposes from the City's sources and beneficial use within the City's
service area.
F.   If a former well(s) is required to be abandoned, the applicant or
developer must abandon the well and provide evidence of that act to the Utah
Division of Water Rights before acceptance of water right(s) by the City. (Ord.
24-19, 8-6-2024)
CHAPTER 4
SEWER DEPARTMENT AND SYSTEM REGULATIONS
SECTION:
8-4-1: Organization Of Department
8-4-2: Sewer Policy
8-4-3: Connection Required; Exception
8-4-4: Rates And Penalty Fees
8-4-5: Easements
8-4-6: Pipes In Good Repair
8-4-7: Quality Of Service Pipe
8-4-8: Maintenance And Access
8-4-9: Harmful Substances
8-4-1: ORGANIZATION OF DEPARTMENT:
   A.   Sewer Department Created: There is hereby created the City Sewer
Department. The department shall consist of a department head, who shall be a
member of the City Council. The Sewer Department shall be maintained and
supervised by the Sewer Superintendent. The Sewer Superintendent shall be
appointed by the Mayor, with the advice and consent of the City Council. He or
she shall have charge of all sewer operations, including sewer installations,
repairs and other sewer maintenance. He or she shall also have charge over all
City property that pertains to the sewer system. (1995 Code § 3-6-101)
   B.   Appointment Of Officers And Employees: All other officers and employees
in the department shall be appointed by the Mayor, upon the recommendation of
the department head and Personnel Officer, with the advice and consent of the
City Council. (1995 Code § 3-6-102)
   C.   Objectives Of Department: The Department of Sewer is created with the
express objective of providing sewer service to the residents of the City and
whosoever else the City Council deems appropriate. (1995 Code § 3-6-103)
8-4-2: SEWER POLICY:
Rules and regulations governing application to use the sewer system, connection
fees and other related rules and regulations shall be set forth by policy
through the City Sewer Policy, a copy of which shall be on file in the City
office. (1995 Code § 3-6-202; amd. 2019 Code)
8-4-3: CONNECTION REQUIRED; EXCEPTION:
All structures in the City that are plumbed with toilets or other water
facilities shall be connected to the City sewer system unless the structure is
further than three hundred feet (300') from a main sewer line. Structures which
are more than three hundred feet (300') from a main sewer line shall be
connected to an alternate method of sewage disposal. Any alternate disposal
method must be approved by the Sewer Superintendent in the same manner as he or
she approves connections to the main sewer line. (1995 Code § 3-6-201)
8-4-4: RATES AND PENALTY FEES:
The City Council shall have the power to establish sewer rates. The City
Council shall adopt rates in the form of policy or resolution and such rates
shall be included in the fee and rate schedule. All accounts shall be assessed
a penalty of five percent (5%) of the unpaid balance after the fifteenth of
each month. Should the fifteenth fall on a weekend or City observed holiday,
the penalty deadline shall be extended to the next business day. (Ord. 06-04,
4-4-2006)
8-4-5: EASEMENTS:
Construction over or under any City utility line is prohibited. Utility
easements must remain free of obstruction for system maintenance and repairs.
The City Council may authorize relocation of existing utilities and utility
easements, but it shall be the policy of the City that the City not bear such
relocation costs unless such relocation benefits the City as a whole. (Ord. 01-
04, 6-5-2001)
8-4-6: PIPES IN GOOD REPAIR:
All users of the sewer service shall keep their service pipes, connections and
other apparatus in good repair and protected from frost at their own expense.
No person, except under the direction of the Sewer Superintendent, shall be
allowed to dig into the streets for the purpose of removing or repairing any
sewer service pipe or main. (1995 Code § 3-6-204)
8-4-7: QUALITY OF SERVICE PIPE:
All service and other pipes used in conjunction with the sewer services of the
City shall be of such material, quality and specifications as the City Council
may from time to time by resolution provide. It shall be installed at such
distances belowground as may be specified by regulations relating to the Sewer
Department. All work, alterations or extensions affecting sewer pipes shall be
subject to the approval of the Sewer Superintendent, and no connections with
sewer mains shall be made without first obtaining a permit therefor from the
City Recorder. (1995 Code § 3-6-205; amd. 2019 Code)
8-4-8: MAINTENANCE AND ACCESS:
The Sewer Superintendent and his or her agents shall at all ordinary hours have
free access upon reasonable notice to places supplied with sewer service from
the Municipal system for the purpose of examining the apparatus, ascertaining
the service being used, and the matter of its use. (1995 Code § 3-6-206)
8-4-9: HARMFUL SUBSTANCES:
It shall be unlawful to permit or cause the flow of any of the following
substances into the sewer system of the City:
   A.   Any blood, grease, fatty material or garbage.
   B.   Any stone dust, sand, dirt, gravel, sawdust, metal fillings, broken
glass or any material which may cause or create an obstruction in the sewer.
   C.   Gasoline, benzene, fuel oil or any petroleum products or volatile
liquids.
   D.   Milk or any milk waste products in quantities in excess of ten (10)
gallons during a twenty four (24) hour period.
   E.   Rainwater, surface water, acids, alkalis, lye or other injurious
liquids. (1995 Code § 3-6-203; amd. Ord. 98-04, 5-19-1998)
ARTICLE A. SEWER UTILITY COST RECOVERY POLICY
SECTION:
8-4A-1: Policy For Recovery
8-4A-2: Appeal To City Council
8-4A-3: Term Of Recovery Period
8-4A-4: Nonapplicable To New Subdivisions
8-4A-5: City Exempt From Policy
8-4A-6: Penalty
8-4A-1: POLICY FOR RECOVERY:
   A.   Specified: Subject to section
8-4A-2 of this article, any person who requests and is qualified to receive
sewer service from the City shall pay all the costs associated with extending
the sewer system to the customer's premises; provided, said person and each
customer who connects to the extended sewer system thereafter, shall be
entitled to a recovery of fifty percent (50%) of the costs he/she pays for
connecting to said sewer system from the next subsequent customer who connects
thereon. When a person recovers said costs from the next subsequent customer
who connects to the system, said person shall be deemed compensated in full and
no longer eligible to recover additional costs. Subject to section
8-4A-3 of this article, recovery cost reimbursement shall cease once recovery
costs reach a minimum of one hundred dollars ($100.00).
   B.   Illustration: By way of illustration, see section 8-2A-1B of this
title, Electric Utility Cost Recovery Policy. (Ord. 05-11, 10-18-2005)
8-4A-2: APPEAL TO CITY COUNCIL:
If situations arise that make it difficult or inequitable to apply the cost
recovery formula set forth in this article, the City Council will determine the
amount allowed, on a case by case basis, to the person or entity entitled to
cost recovery. Such a determination shall be made only after such person or
entity appeals to the City Council for consideration of such cost recovery. The
City Council's decision shall be final. (Ord. 05-11, 10-18-2005)
8-4A-3: TERM OF RECOVERY PERIOD:
The cost recovery period shall be limited to ten (10) years from the date of
the first service connection on the original line extension and ten (10) years
from the date of the first service connection on any extensions to said
original line extension. (Ord. 05-11, 10-18-2005)
8-4A-4: NONAPPLICABLE TO NEW SUBDIVISIONS:
The cost recovery policy set forth in this article shall not apply to new
subdivisions as the owners or developers of such subdivisions can pass such
costs on to buyers of subdivided lots. (Ord. 05-11, 10-18-2005)
8-4A-5: CITY EXEMPT FROM POLICY:
The City shall be exempt from this policy and may connect to any sewer system
for any purpose at any time without repayment of extension costs. (Ord. 05-11,
10-18-2005)
8-4A-6: PENALTY:
Any person, firm or corporation violating any provisions of this article shall
be guilty of an infraction, subject to penalty as provided in title 1, chapter
4 of this Code. A separate offense shall be deemed committed upon each day
during or on which a violation occurs or continues. (Ord. 05-11, 10-18-2005;
amd. 2019 Code)
CHAPTER 2
ELECTRICAL DEPARTMENT AND SYSTEM REGULATIONS
ARTICLE A. ELECTRIC UTILITY COST RECOVERY POLICY
SECTION:
8-2A-1: Policy For Recovery
8-2A-2: Appeal To City Council
8-2A-3: Term Of Recovery Period
8-2A-4: Nonapplicable To New Subdivisions
8-2A-5: City Exempt From Policy
8-2A-6: Penalty
8-2A-1: POLICY FOR RECOVERY:
   A.   Specified: Subject to section
8-2A-2 of this article, any person who requests and is qualified to receive
electric service from the City shall pay all the costs associated with
extending the electrical system to the customer's premises; provided, said
person and each customer who connects to the extended electrical system
thereafter, shall be entitled to a recovery of fifty percent (50%) of the costs
he/she pays for connecting to said electrical system from the next subsequent
customer who connects thereon. When a person recovers said costs from the next
subsequent customer who connects to the system, said person shall be deemed
compensated in full and no longer eligible to recover additional costs. Subject
to section
8-2A-3 of this article, recovery cost reimbursement shall cease once recovery
costs reach a minimum of one hundred dollars ($100.00).
   B.   Illustration: By way of illustration:
      1.   Customer A requests and pays ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) for a
one thousand foot (1,000') utility line extension. Customer B hooks up to the
line four hundred feet (400') from the original point of extension, attributing
forty percent (40%) of the line to customer B (1,000 times 40 percent equals
400 feet). Customer A is entitled to fifty percent (50%) of the cost value from
customer B's hookup ($10,000.00 times 40 percent equals $4,000.00). Customer A
may continue to recoup from subsequent customers up to fifty percent (50%) of
the costs expended to extend the line. Customer A shall then be considered
fully compensated and become ineligible to recover any additional costs.
      2.   Customer C is given a connection to the original line extension.
Customer B shall be entitled to recovery from customer C and/or subsequent
customers two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00), which is fifty percent
(50%) of the cost customer B paid to customer A ($5,000.00). Customer B shall
then be considered fully compensated and become ineligible to recover any
additional costs.
      3.   Customer B requests and pays for an additional line extension,
beyond customer A's original line extension. Customer A shall be entitled to
recover fifty percent (50%) of his/her total extension costs ($5,000.00) from
customer B. Customer B shall be entitled to recover fifty percent (50%) from
customer C and/or subsequent customers ($2,500.00) of the costs customer B paid
to customer A and in addition thereto, customer B shall be entitled to recover
fifty percent (50%) of the costs from customers who connect to customer B's
additional line extension. Customer B shall then be considered fully
compensated and become ineligible to recover any additional costs.
      4.   This pattern continues until the cost recovery is less than one
hundred dollars ($100.00). (Ord. 05-11, 10-18-2005)
8-2A-2: APPEAL TO CITY COUNCIL:
If situations arise that make it difficult or inequitable to apply the cost
recovery formula set forth in section
8-2A-1 of this article, the City Council will determine the amount allowed, on
a case by case basis, to the person or entity entitled to cost recovery. Such a
determination shall be made only after such person or entity appeals to the
City Council for consideration of such cost recovery. The City Council's
decision shall be final. (Ord. 05-11, 10-18-2005)
8-2A-3: TERM OF RECOVERY PERIOD:
The cost recovery period shall be limited to ten (10) years from the date of
the first service connection on the original line extension and ten (10) years
from the date of the first service connection on any extension to said original
line extension. (Ord. 05-11, 10-18-2005)
8-2A-4: NONAPPLICABLE TO NEW SUBDIVISIONS:
The cost recovery policy set forth in this article shall not apply to new
subdivisions, as the owners or developers of such subdivisions can pass such
costs on to buyers of subdivided lots. (Ord. 05-11, 10-18-2005)
8-2A-5: CITY EXEMPT FROM POLICY:
The City shall be exempt from this policy and may connect to any electric
system for any purpose at any time without repayment of extension costs. (Ord.
05-11, 10-18-2005)
8-2A-6: PENALTY:
Any person, firm or corporation violating any provisions of this article shall
be guilty of an infraction, subject to penalty as provided in title 1, chapter
4 of this Code. A separate offense shall be deemed committed upon each day
during or on which a violation occurs or continues. (2019 Code)
TITLE 9
BUILDING REGULATIONS
CHAPTER 1
BUILDING CODE AND REGULATIONS
SECTION:
9-1-1: Codes Adopted
9-1-2: Subsequent Updates Adopted
9-1-3: Availability For Public Inspection
9-1-4: City Ordinance Prevails
9-1-5: Permits And Inspections
9-1-1: CODES ADOPTED:
   A.   International Building Code: The regulations contained in the most
recent edition of the International Building Code, as printed under authority
of the International Conference of Building Officials in book form, are hereby
adopted as the regulations governing the construction of buildings and other
structures in the City; and it shall be unlawful to erect or construct any
building or structure in the City in violation of, or without complying with,
the appropriate provisions of such regulations. (1995 Code § 17-2-101)
   B.   International Mechanical Code: The regulations contained in the most
recent edition of the International Mechanical Code, as printed under authority
of the International Association of Plumbing and Mechanical Officials in book
form and approved by the Utah Department of Health, are hereby adopted as the
regulations governing the design, installation, maintenance or repair of
heating, cooling, refrigeration or other ventilation systems; and it shall be
unlawful to design, install, maintain or repair such a system in the City in
violation of, or without complying with, the appropriate provisions of such
regulations. (1995 Code § 17-2-102)
   C.   National Electrical Code: The regulations contained in the most recent
edition of the National Electrical Code, as printed under authority of the
National Electrical Contractors Association in book form, are hereby adopted as
the regulations governing any interior or exterior electrical wiring, or any
electrical construction, electrical installation or alteration of any
electrical wiring; and it shall be unlawful to perform any interior or exterior
electrical wiring, or any electrical construction, electrical installation or
alteration of any electrical wiring in the City in violation of, or without
complying with, the appropriate provisions of such regulations. (1995 Code §
17-2-103)
   D.   International Plumbing Code: The regulations contained in the most
recent edition of the International Plumbing Code and the International Private
Sewage Disposal Code, as adopted by the State, are hereby adopted as the
regulations governing any plumbing connected or to be connected to any pipe or
pipes in the City, or to any private plumbing or any sewer system of the City;
and it shall be unlawful to repair or install any plumbing connected or to be
connected to any pipe or pipes in the City, or to any private plumbing or any
sewer system of the City in violation of, or without complying with, the
appropriate provisions of such regulations. (Ord. 99-13, 10-5-1999; amd. 2019
Code)
   E.   International Fire Code: The regulations contained in the most recent
edition of the International Fire Code, as printed under authority of the
International Conference of Building Officials and Western Fire Chiefs
Association in book form, are hereby adopted as the regulations governing fire
prevention in the City; and it shall be unlawful to construct, install,
maintain or repair anything in the City in violation of, or without complying
with, the appropriate provisions of such regulations. (1995 Code § 17-2-105)
   F.   Abatement Of Dangerous Buildings Code: The regulations contained in the
most recent edition of the Uniform Code for the Abatement of Dangerous
Buildings are hereby adopted as the regulations affording reasonable procedures
for the classification and abatement of dangerous buildings. (Ord. 99-14, 12-
21-1999; amd. 2019 Code)
   G.   National Electrical Safety Code: The regulations contained in the most
recent edition of the National Electrical Safety Code are hereby adopted. (Ord.
01-03, 4-17-2001; amd. 2019 Code)
   H.   International Energy Conservation Code: The regulations contained in
the most recent edition of the International Energy Conservation Code are
hereby adopted. (1995 Code § 17-2-108; amd. 2019 Code)
9-1-2: SUBSEQUENT UPDATES ADOPTED:
All subsequent updates to all Code books adopted in this chapter are hereby
adopted. (1995 Code § 17-2-110)
9-1-3: AVAILABILITY FOR PUBLIC INSPECTION:
At least one hard copy and an electronic copy of all adopted codes shall be
available for public inspection at the office of the building inspector. A link
to the electronic copies shall be available to the public from the City
website. (1995 Code § 17-2-109)
9-1-4: CITY ORDINANCE PREVAILS:
This chapter shall supersede any contradiction between this chapter and any
national or International Code adopted herein. (Ord. 01-03, 4-17-2001)
9-1-5: PERMITS AND INSPECTIONS:
   A.   Permits Required:
      1.   It shall be unlawful to construct or alter any building or structure
in the City, excepting fences, where the affect of such construction or
alteration is to enlarge the capacity or affect the bearing walls of any
building, or the roof thereof, without having first secured a permit therefor.
      2.   It shall be unlawful to do any interior or exterior electrical
wiring, or any electrical construction, electrical installation or alteration
of any electrical wiring without first having obtained an electrical
construction permit for the anticipated work from the City Recorder.
      3.   It shall be unlawful to proceed with any plumbing connected or to be
connected to any pipe or pipes in the City, or to any private plumbing or any
sewer system of the City, until a permit has been obtained from the City
Recorder. No permit shall be required for the making of minor repairs. A repair
shall not be deemed minor if a portion or a section of the plumbing or drain
line is cut, removed or replaced in such a way as to alter the basic design or
use of the original system. (1995 Code § 17-1-101)
      4.   It shall be unlawful to encroach upon any City sidewalk or utility
with heavy equipment during construction projects without first obtaining an
encroachment permit from the City. (Ord. 99-08, 4-20-1999)
      5.   Subsections A1, A2, A3 and A4 of this section shall not apply in the
case of an emergency repair. For this subsection, a repair that required
immediate completion in order to avoid substantial injury to persons or
property shall constitute an emergency repair. In such cases, a permit must be
obtained as soon as is reasonably possible. Applicants meeting requirements for
permits under this subsection shall not be penalized under subsection F of this
section. (1995 Code § 17-1-101; amd. 2019 Code)
   B.   Application For Permit:
      1.   Applications for any permit required under subsection A of this
section shall be made to the City Recorder. Applicants shall submit, as part of
the permit applications, plans and specifications showing the work to be done.
The building inspector may, at his or her discretion, request that plans be
submitted in duplicate as a condition for the permit. All work plans shall be
verified by the signature of either the owner of the premises or by the
architect or contractor in charge of the operations.
      2.   Such applications with plans shall be referred to the building
inspector, who shall examine the plans to determine whether the proposed
construction or alteration will comply with the relevant ordinance provisions.
Upon approval, the set of plans shall be returned to the applicant with a
permit. If duplicate plans were submitted, the other shall be retained by the
building inspector. No permit shall be issued until after approval of the
plans. (1995 Code § 17-1-102)
   C.   Unlawful To Vary From Plans: It shall be unlawful to vary materially
from the submitted plans and specifications unless such variations are
submitted in an amended plan to the building inspector and approved by the
building inspector. (1995 Code § 17-1-103)
   D.   Inspections: The building inspector shall make or cause to be made such
inspections as are necessary to ensure the enforcement of the provisions of
this chapter, and to make any tests or examinations of materials or methods to
be used for the purpose of seeing that they comply with the provisions of this
chapter. (1995 Code § 17-1-104)
   E.   Fees: The City Council shall have power to determine and change
building permit fees through policy or resolution. (1995 Code § 17-1-105)
   F.   Failure To Secure Permits Before Commencing Work:
      1.   Any owner, architect, contractor or handyman that commences work
without first securing a permit required under subsection A of this section
shall be guilty of the offense of starting construction without a building
permit. When the building inspector or other authorized person learns of a
violation of subsection A of this section, he or she shall have authority to
require that the work stop immediately and that it not continue until an
authorized person acquires a building permit. The fee for the building permit
obtained after work has commenced shall be double the amount it would have cost
if the applicant had complied with subsection A of this section. (1995 Code §
17-1-106)
      2.   Any work requiring a permit under this section that is completed
before a permit is obtained, the owner, handyman or contractor shall be guilty
of an infraction, subject to penalty as provided in title 1, chapter 4 of this
Code. A separate offense shall be deemed committed upon each day during or on
which a violation occurs or continues. (1995 Code § 17-1-106; amd. 2019 Code)
   G.   Variation From Submitted Plan:
      1.   Any owner, architect, contractor or handyman that performs work that
materially varies from the plan submitted as required under subsection B of
this section, or that performs work that does not comply with any relevant
ordinance, shall be guilty of an infraction, subject to penalty as provided in
title 1, chapter 4 of this Code, and shall be required to correct the
violation. (1995 Code § 17-1-107; amd. 2019 Code)
      2.   Before issuing a citation for an infraction, the building inspector
or other authorized person shall issue a warning notice, describing the alleged
offense, the location, the ordinance or code section involved, and a statement
of what must be done to correct the violation. The notice shall state the date
by which such correction must be completed. Such date shall give five (5)
calendar days from the date of the notice, provided that a shorter time shall
be specified if there is substantial immediate danger to persons or property. A
longer time than five (5) days shall be stated if there would be practical
physical difficulties in completing the correction within five (5) days and
there is no emergency.
      3.   Failure of the City to issue a warning as described in subsection G2
of this section shall not affect the validity of any prosecution for an
infraction.
      4.   If the condition has not been corrected within the time specified in
the warning notice, the building inspector or other authorized person shall
issue a citation for the infraction. The citation shall state a date and time
for a court appearance, and shall state that the person accused may avoid the
court hearing by paying, before the time of the hearing, the sum of two hundred
dollars ($200.00) in lieu of a fine set by the court. (1995 Code § 17-1-107)
   H.   Interpretation Of Regulations: Wherever in the regulations of this
chapter or in the regulations adopted in this chapter it is provided that
anything must be done to the approval of or subject to the direction of the
building inspector, this shall be construed to give the building inspector only
the discretion of determining whether the rules and standards established by
ordinance have been complied with; and no such provisions shall be construed as
giving the building inspector or any officer discretionary powers as to what
such regulations or standards shall be, or power to require conditions not
prescribed by ordinance or to enforce ordinance provisions in an arbitrary or
discriminatory manner. (1995 Code § 17-1-108)
CHAPTER 2
RESIDENTIAL HOUSING
ARTICLE A. ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT
SECTION:
9-2A-1: Title
9-2A-2: Definitions
9-2A-3: Purpose And Scope
9-2A-4: Alternate Materials And Methods Of Construction
9-2A-5: Authority
9-2A-6: Right Of Entry
9-2A-7: Notices And Orders
9-2A-8: Vacating And Closing To Occupancy
9-2A-9: Removal Of Placards And Posted Notices
9-2A-10: Certificate Of Occupancy
9-2A-11: Appeals
9-2A-12: Violation; Penalty
9-2A-1: TITLE:
This chapter shall be known as the FILLMORE CITY HOUSING ORDINANCE, and is
referred to herein as "this chapter". (Ord. 95-142, 3-7-1995)
9-2A-2: DEFINITIONS:
   A.   Construction Of Terms:
      1.   For the purpose of this chapter, certain terms, phrases, words and
their derivations shall be construed as specified in this section. Words used
in the singular include plural, and words in the plural include the singular.
Words used in the masculine gender include the feminine, and words in the
feminine gender include the masculine.
      2.   Whenever the words "apartment house", "building", "dormitory",
"dwelling unit", "habitable room", "hotel", "housing unit" or "structure" are
used in this chapter, such words shall be construed as if followed by the words
"or any portion thereof".
      3.   References to codes, ordinances, chapters, sections or subsections
shall include any successor to such code, ordinance, chapter, section or
subsection.
   B.   Defined Terms:
ADMINISTRATIVE HEARING BOARD: The Planning Commission, which has been appointed
by the City Council to conduct administrative appeal.
AGENT: Any person, firm, partnership, association, joint venture, corporation
or other entity who acts for or on behalf of others.
APARTMENT HOUSE: Any building which contains two (2) or more dwelling units
and, for the purpose of this chapter, includes residential condominiums.
APPROVED: As to a given material, mode of construction or repair, piece of
equipment or device means approved by the building official as the result of
investigation and tests conducted by the building official, or by reason of
accepted principles or tests by recognized authorities or technical or
scientific organizations.
ATTIC: That portion of a building included between the upper surface of the top
most floor and the ceiling or roof above.
BASEMENT: Any floor level below the first story in a building, except that a
floor level in a building having only one floor level shall be classified as a
basement, unless such floor level qualifies as a first story, as defined
herein.
BATHROOM: A room containing at least one of each of the following fixtures:
lavatory, toilet, and tub or shower.
BEDROOM: Any space designed or used for sleeping.
BUILDING: Any structure which is used, designed or intended to be used for
human habitation or an accessory structure thereto.
BUILDING CLOSURE OR CLOSED TO ENTRY OR CLOSED TO UNAUTHORIZED ENTRY OR BOARDED
BUILDING: A building which is closed to occupancy.
BUILDING ENVELOPE: The space defined by existing floors, walls, ceiling
structures, basement and attic.
BUILDING OFFICIAL: The officer or other designated authority charged with the
administration and enforcement of this chapter, or the officer's duly
authorized representative.
CEILING HEIGHT: The vertical distance from the finish floor to finish ceiling,
or to the lowest point of the ceiling framing members. Where projections below
the ceiling exist, the height shall be measured from the projection to the
finished floor.
CERTIFICATE OF OCCUPANCY: A certificate issued by the building official
authorizing occupancy of building.
COMMON ROOM: A room available for the joint use of occupants of two (2) or more
housing units other than common hallways and exit passages. These shall include
cooking facilities and game rooms.
CONDOMINIUM: Property or portions thereof conforming to the definition set
forth in Utah Code Annotated section 57-8-3, as amended, or its successor.
CONGREGATE HOUSING: Any building which contains facilities for living, sleeping
and sanitation, as required by this chapter, and may include facilities for
eating and cooking, for occupancy by other than a family. A congregate
residence includes an SRO (single room occupancy) convent, a monastery,
dormitory, fraternity, or sorority house. Congregate housing does not include
shelters, jails, hospitals, nursing homes, hotels or lodging houses.
CROSS CONNECTION: Any connection or arrangement, physical or otherwise, between
a potable water supply system and any plumbing fixture, or any tank,
receptacle, equipment or device, through which unclean or polluted water or
other substances may contaminate such potable water supply system.
DWELLING UNIT: Any building which contains living facilities, including
provisions for sleeping, eating, cooking and sanitation, as required by this
chapter, for no more than one family, or a congregate residence for ten (10) or
fewer persons.
EFFICIENCY DWELLING UNIT: A dwelling unit containing only one habitable room.
EXISTING: In existence prior to adoption of this chapter.
EXIT: A continuous and unobstructed means of egress to a public way and
includes any intervening aisles, doorways, gates, corridors, exterior exit
balconies, ramps, stairways, smoke proof enclosures, horizontal exits, exit
passageways, exit courts and yards as these terms are defined in the
International Building Code (IBC).
FAMILY: Any one of the following:
   A.   Up to three (3) unrelated persons;
   B.   Immediate family;
   C.   Any number of persons related by blood or marriage, so long as the
square footage requirements of the Utah State Building Code are met, which are:
Chapter 12, Section 1207. (b). Floor Area. Dwelling units and congregate
residences shall have at least one room which shall have not less than 120
square feet of floor area. Other habitable rooms except kitchens shall have an
area of not less than 70 square feet.
FIRE RESISTANCE OR FIRE RESISTIVE: Construction that resists the spread of
fire, as specified in the International Building Code (IBC).
GARAGE: A building or portion thereof designed, used or intended to be used for
parking or storage of a motor vehicle containing flammable or combustible
liquids or gas in its tank.
HABITABLE ROOM: A room in a building for living, sleeping, eating or cooking,
in accordance with the International Building Code (IBC) and is safe, as
defined therein. Bathrooms, toilet rooms, closets, corridors, storage or
utility space, and similar areas are not habitable rooms.
HAZARD: A condition that exposes any person to the risk of illness, bodily harm
or loss of or damage to possessions.
HEADROOM CLEARANCE: For stairs, means the vertical distance from the leading
edge of each tread to the lowest projection of any construction, piping,
fixture or other object above such tread.
HISTORIC BUILDING: Any building or structure which has been designated for
preservation by the Utah State Historical Society or has been listed on the
National Register of Historical Places or on the Utah State Register of
Historic Places.
HOTEL: Any building containing rooms intended or designed to be used, rented or
hired out to be occupied, or which are occupied for sleeping purposes by guests
on a daily basis.
INFESTATION: The presence of insects, rodents or other pests in or around a
building in numbers that are or may be detrimental to the health, safety or
general welfare of the occupants.
INTERNATIONAL BUILDING CODE (IBC): The edition of the International Building
Code currently adopted by the City.
INTERNATIONAL MECHANICAL CODE (IMC): The edition of the International
Mechanical Code currently adopted by the State and City.
INTERNATIONAL PLUMBING CODE (IPC): The edition of the International Plumbing
Code currently adopted by the State and City.
KITCHEN: A space or room used, designed or intended to be used for the
preparation of food, which includes a permanently installed sink, cooking range
with oven and/or microwave oven, and a refrigerator.
LANDLORD: The owner, lessor or sublessor of a residential rental unit. A
managing agent, leasing agent or resident manager is considered a landlord for
purposes of notice and other communication required or allowed under this
chapter.
LICENSING: The authority to conduct business and is administered by the
Fillmore City Recorder.
MONUMENTAL STAIRS: A stairway, exceeding four feet (4') in width, at the main
entrance on the exterior of a building.
MULTIPLE-FAMILY DWELLING UNIT: A residential duplex, triplex, four-plex, etc.,
apartment building or condominium. A multiple-family dwelling unit is one
structure divided, internally sharing a common wall or walls with the adjoining
units and a common roof over the entire structure; each unit has cooking and
sanitary facilities that meet Housing Codes. Each unit shall be occupied by no
more than one "family", as defined in this section.
MULTIPLE-FAMILY STRUCTURE DWELLING UNIT: A residential building containing two
(2) or more dwelling units as defined in "multiple-family dwelling unit" of
this section.
NATIONAL ELECTRICAL CODE (NEC): The edition of the National Electrical Code
currently adopted by the City.
OCCUPANT: A person occupying or having possession of a dwelling unit.
OPENING: An exterior opening capable of being closed to the weather, including
a window, a door, and an openable glazed skylight, which opens upon a yard,
courtyard, street, alley, or recesses from a courtyard.
OWNER: Any person, firm, partnership, association, joint venture or
corporation, who has title or interest in any building, with or without
accompanying actual possession, and including any person who as agent or
executor, administrator, trustee or guardian of an estate has charge, care or
control of any building.
PATTERN OF CIRCULATION: Any area in a room or group of rooms where the occupant
is likely to walk because of the location of doors, fixtures or furniture
placement.
PERSONS: Any individual, firm, corporation, association or partnership and its
agents or assigns.
PLUMBING SYSTEM: Any potable water distribution piping, and any drainage piping
within or below any building, including all plumbing fixtures, traps, vents and
devices appurtenant to such water distribution or drainage piping and including
potable water treating or using equipment, and any lawn sprinkling system.
PREMISES: A lot, plot or parcel of land, including the buildings or structures
thereon.
PUBLIC WAY: Any street, alley or similar parcel of land essentially
unobstructed from the ground to the sky which is deeded, dedicated or otherwise
permanently appropriated to the public use and having a clear width of not less
than ten feet (10').
RESIDENTIAL RENTAL UNIT: A tenant's principal place of residence and includes
the appurtenances, grounds and facilities held out for the use of the
residential tenant generally, and any other area provided to the tenant in a
rental agreement. It does not include facilities contained in a boarding or
rooming house, or similar facility, mobile home lot, or recreational property
rented on an occasional basis.
RISE: The vertical portion of a stair step.
RUN: The horizontal portion of a stair step.
SRO: A single room occupancy dwelling unit within congregate housing with one
combined sleeping and living room, and which may include a kitchen and/or a
separate private bathroom.
SECURED BUILDING: Means a building where all windows and doors are intact and
locked against unauthorized entry.
SMOKE DETECTOR: An approved device which senses visible or invisible particles
of combustion.
STORY: That portion of a building included between the upper surface of any
floor and the upper surface of the floor next above. If the finished floor
level directly above a usable or unused under floor space is more than six feet
(6') above grade, as defined herein, for more than fifty percent (50%) of the
total perimeter, or is more than twelve feet (12') above grade, as defined
herein, at any point, such usable or unused under floor space shall be
considered as a story.
STORY, FIRST: The lowest story in a building which qualifies as a "story", as
defined in this section, except that floor level in a building having only one
floor level shall be classified as a first story, provided such floor level is
not more than four feet (4') below grade, as defined herein, for more than
fifty percent (50%) of the total perimeter, or not more than eight feet (8')
below grade, as defined herein, at any point.
STRUCTURE: Anything that is built or constructed, an edifice or building of any
kind, or any piece of work artificially built up or composed of parts jointed
together.
TENANT: Any person entitled to occupy a residential rental unit to the
exclusion of others.
TOILET ROOM: A room containing a toilet and may contain a sink, but does not
contain a tub or shower.
UL LISTED AND UL LISTING: Terms referring to equipment and materials which are
shown in a list published by Underwriters Laboratories, or other approved
testing and certifying agencies.
UNFIT FOR HUMAN OCCUPANCY: A condition of a premises which has been found by
the building official to be an unsafe structure or because of the degree in
which it is in disrepair or lacks maintenance, fails to meet the sanitation
requirements of the authorized Health Department regulations, contains filth
and contamination, or lacks ventilation, illumination, sanitary facilities or
heating facilities, or other essential equipment, is dangerous to life, health,
property or the safety of occupants.
UNIFORM CODE FOR THE ABATEMENT OF DANGEROUS BUILDINGS (UCADB): The edition of
the Uniform Code for the Abatement of Dangerous Buildings currently adopted by
the City.
UNSAFE STRUCTURES: One in which all or part thereof is found to be dangerous to
life, health, property or the safety of the public or occupants by not
providing minimum safeguards for protection from any danger as required by the
IBC or because such structure contains unsafe equipment or is so damaged,
dilapidated or structurally unsafe that partial or complete collapse is likely.
WASHABLE SURFACE: A surface which is not adversely affected by moisture.
YARD: An open space, other than a courtyard, unoccupied by any structure on the
lot on which a building is situated, unobstructed from the ground to the sky,
except as specifically permitted by the IBC. (Ord. 95-142, 3-7-1995; amd. Ord.
97-156, 8-19-1997; Ord. 05-05, 3-1-2005; 2019 Code)
9-2A-3: PURPOSE AND SCOPE:
   A.   Purpose: The purpose of this chapter is to provide for the health,
safety and welfare, and promote the prosperity, peace and good order, comfort
and aesthetics of the City and its present and future inhabitants and business,
to protect the tax base, to protect both urban and nonurban development, and to
protect property values with the City. This purpose shall be accomplished by
regulating the maintenance, repair and remodeling of all residential structures
existing as of the date of enactment of this chapter by:
      1.   Establishing minimum housing standards for all buildings or portions
thereof used, or designed or intended to be used, for human habitation;
      2.   Establishing minimum standards for safety from fire and other
hazards;
      3.   Promoting maintenance and improvement of structures by permitting
distinctions in the application of standards based on the year a structure was
built as long as an equivalent level of safety can be achieved;
      4.   Avoiding the closure or abandonment of housing and the displacement
of occupants where such can be done without sacrificing the public health,
safety and welfare;
      5.   Providing for the administrative, enforcement and penalties for this
chapter.
   B.   Scope: The scope of housing standards covered by this chapter includes
all existing and future residential structures, equipment and facilities for
light, ventilation, space, heating, sanitation and protection from the
elements, and for safe and sanitary maintenance.
   C.   Application To Remodeling Of Existing Residential Buildings: This
chapter shall apply to remodeling, renovation, moving or repair of all
residential buildings existing as of the date of enactment of this chapter,
regardless of valuation of repairs, remodeling and renovation, unless otherwise
noted in this chapter. All additions to existing buildings shall comply with
the City standards for new construction.
   D.   Dangerous Buildings: Residential buildings which pose such a danger as
to fall within the scope of section 302 of the UCADB shall be governed by the
UCADB and not by this chapter.
   E.   Change Of Use: Any building undergoing a change in use, as defined in
the IBC, shall comply with the provisions of the IBC.
   F.   Permits Required: No building or structure regulated by the IBC shall
be erected, constructed, enlarged, altered, repaired, moved, improved, removed,
converted or demolished unless a separate permit for each building or structure
has first been obtained.
   G.   Exception: The requirements of the IBC notwithstanding, permits are not
required for the following:
      1.   Floor covering installation;
      2.   Painting and attaching wall coverings and similar finish work;
      3.   Replacement of glazing, except where safety glazing is required by
the IBC;
      4.   Patching of wall surfaces;
      5.   Replacement of light fixtures;
      6.   Replacement of electrical wall outlets and switches;
      7.   Replacement of plumbing fixtures as long as main drains and vents
are not disturbed;
      8.   General placements of air heating and cooling systems filters, belts
and motors in these systems;
      9.   Installation of any number of battery operated smoke detectors;
      10.   Replacement of sidewalks or private driveways on private property.
(Ord. 95-142, 3-7-1995)
9-2A-4: ALTERNATE MATERIALS AND METHODS OF CONSTRUCTION:
   A.   The provisions of this chapter are not intended to prevent the use of
any material or method of construction not specifically prescribed by this
chapter and the IBC, provided any such alternate has been approved and its use
authorized by the building official in conformance with the IBC, nor is it the
intention of this chapter to exclude any sound method of structural design or
analysis not specifically provided for in this chapter. (Ord. 95-142, 3-7-1995)
   B.   Manufactured or modular units imported into the City shall have a HUD
label attached to the exterior certifying compliance with HUD manufacturing
standards. All such units shall be brought to current Electrical, Building,
Plumbing, Mechanical and Energy Efficiency Code standards, and shall be used
for the purpose which the units were originally intended when constructed.
Imported manufactured or modular units shall meet roof pitch, snow load
requirements, and be placed upon a permanent cement or cinder block foundation
with footings that meet the frost depth specifications. (Ord. 97-156, 8-19-
1997; amd. 2019 Code)
9-2A-5: AUTHORITY:
   A.   The building official is hereby authorized and directed to enforce all
the provisions of this chapter. For such purposes, the building official shall
authorize inspections by the Fire Department and the Health Department. The
building official shall also authorize law enforcement to issue and deliver
criminal citations as provided by State law. (Ord. 95-145, 10-3-1995)
   B.   The building official shall have the power to render interpretations of
this chapter and to adopt and enforce rules to clarify the application of its
provisions. (Ord. 95-142, 3-7-1995)
9-2A-6: RIGHT OF ENTRY:
   A.   Whenever it becomes necessary to make an inspection to enforce any
provisions of this chapter, or whenever the building official has reasonable
cause to believe there exists in any building or upon any premises a code
violation which makes such building or premises unsafe, dangerous or hazardous,
he/she may singly or with a representative of the Fire Department and/or the
Health Department as deemed appropriate and necessary, and upon obtaining
permission of the owner or other person having charge or control of the
building or premises, or upon obtaining a warrant, enter a residential property
or premises to inspect it or to perform duties imposed by this chapter. If such
building or premises be occupied, he/she shall first present proper credentials
and request entry; and if such building or premises be unoccupied, he/she shall
first make a reasonable effort to locate the owner or other person having
charge or control of the building or premises and request entry. If such entry
is refused, the building official shall have recourse to every remedy provided
by law to secure entry. (Ord. 95-145, 10-3-1995)
   B.   If an unoccupied dwelling unit is open and unattended and the owner or
other person having charge or control of the building or premises cannot be
located after reasonable effort, the building official or his/her authorized
representative may, upon obtaining a warrant, enter the building. He/she shall
issue a notice and order that the dwelling unit be immediately secured or
boarded against the entry of unauthorized persons.
   C.   In nonemergencies or when authorization to enter has not previously
been granted by a tenant, the owner shall give the tenant a minimum of twenty
four (24) hours notification of an inspection of the tenant's premises by the
building official. (Ord. 95-142, 3-7-1995)
9-2A-7: NOTICES AND ORDERS:
   A.   Substandard Buildings: All buildings or portions thereof which are
determined to be substandard, as defined in this chapter, are declared to be
public nuisances and shall be abated by repair, rehabilitation, demolition or
removal in accordance with the procedures specified in this chapter.
   B.   Violations: It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to
erect, construct, enlarge, alter, repair, move, improve, remove, convert or
demolish, equip, use, occupy or maintain any building or structure, or cause or
permit the same to be done, in violation of this chapter.
   C.   Issuance:
      1.   Whenever the building official has inspected a building and found it
to be substandard, the building official shall commence action to cause the
repair, rehabilitation, vacation or demolition of the building.
      2.   The building official shall notify the owner or the owner's agent of
the existence of the violations in writing, giving the section number and a
description of each violation.
      3.   This notice shall be informal and shall set a period of not less
than twenty four (24) hours nor more than thirty (30) days in which the
violations are to be corrected, depending upon the urgency of such violations.
A formal notice shall be issued in the following instances:
         a.   When a structure is found unfit for human occupancy or when
violations pose a serious life safety danger to occupants and require
correction; or
         b.   When a building poses an immediate threat to the safety of the
public and must be demolished immediately; or
         c.   When an owner has not complied with an informal notice.
      4.   All notices and orders shall be directed to the owner of record or
authorized or acting manager or agent of any building. The formal notice shall
contain the following:
         a.   The street address or legal description of the parcel upon which
the building is located;
         b.   The action required to be taken by the owner;
         c.   The date or dates by which the work is to be accomplished;
         d.   Actions the building official is empowered to take if the order
is not obeyed in the time allotted; and
         e.   An explanation of the owner's right to appeal.
   D.   Method Of Service Of Formal Notice And Order:
      1.   Service of all formal notices and orders will be made by mailing a
copy of such notice and order by certified mail, return receipt requested.
      2.   A notice shall be posted on the property stating that a formal
notice and order has been issued against the property for which the action is
being taken.
      3.   Formal notices and orders to vacate shall be posted on the property
and on every dwelling unit door affected thereby.
   E.   Extension Of Time To Perform Work: Extensions of time may be granted by
the building official. (Ord. 95-142, 3-7-1995)
9-2A-8: VACATING AND CLOSING TO OCCUPANCY:
   A.   Authority Of Building Official:
      1.   When a structure is found by the building official to be unsafe to
occupy or unfit for human occupancy or use, he/she may require the building or
portion thereof and/or premises immediately vacated and closed to entry. At the
discretion of the building official, a portion of a vacated building may be
occupied if the occupied portion meets the standards for habitable buildings.
(Ord. 95-142, 3-7-1995)
      2.   Any vacated structure inspected prior to occupancy which is found to
be unsafe may not be occupied, and no utility services may be connected until
the structure meets the standards for habitable buildings.
   B.   Removal Of Fixtures; Exception:
      1.   When the building official orders the termination of the occupancy
of a dwelling unit, the owner shall remove the bathroom and kitchen plumbing
fixtures and all cooking appliances.
      2.   When the kitchen and/or bathroom is incorporated into a unit allowed
by this chapter, the kitchen and/or bathroom fixtures may remain.
   C.   Post Premises: The building official shall post the premises or
structure with a placard bearing the words:
   Fillmore City
   Building Inspection Department
   DO NOT ENTER
   UNSAFE TO OCCUPY
It is a misdemeanor to occupy this building, or to remove or deface this
notice.
                                                     
Date         Building Official
Fillmore City
   D.   Unlawful Occupation: It shall be unlawful for any person to use or
occupy, or cause or permit any person to use or occupy any portion of any
building which portion has been declared unsafe to occupy after the vacation
date until the building official certifies that the conditions described in the
vacation order have been corrected.
   E.   Stay Of Enforcement: The building official may stay enforcement for
buildings that are and remain vacated and secured, provided the lot is kept
free of debris and weeds. Such stay of enforcement may continue so long as the
building remains vacant and secured and does not pose further danger. (Ord. 95-
142, 3-7-1995)
9-2A-9: REMOVAL OF PLACARDS AND POSTED NOTICES:
The removal of placards or posted notice shall be done by the building official
or his/her designated representative. Any other persons who deface or remove a
closure placard shall be subject to penalties provided by this chapter. (Ord.
95-142, 3-7-1995)
9-2A-10: CERTIFICATE OF OCCUPANCY:
Following correction of deficiencies and prior to reoccupying of any structure
closed in occupancy, the building official shall issue a certificate of
occupancy. (Ord. 95-142, 3-7-1995)
9-2A-11: APPEALS:
   A.   Housing Advisory And Appeals Board; Scope Of Authority: The Planning
Commission is hereby appointed as the Housing Advisory and Appeals Board, and
shall have power to:
      1.   Interpret the provisions of this chapter;
      2.   Hear and decide appeals where it is alleged there is an error on any
order, requirement, decision or determination made by an administrative
official in the enforcement of this chapter;
      3.   Modify the impact of specific provisions of this chapter which
create practical difficulties in their enforcement, so long as the means by
which the mitigation is employed accomplish the purpose of the original
requirement;
      4.   Extend time deadlines provided in this chapter, for good cause;
      5.   Recommend new procedures to the building official and new ordinances
regulating housing to the City Council;
      6.   Conduct abatement hearings.
   B.   Filings Of Appeals:
      1.   All appeals shall be filed within thirty (30) days from the date of
the service of the formal notice and order. The property owner or agent shall
file the appeal with the building official. The appeal shall go before the
Planning Commission.
Exception: Appeals of formal notices and orders to vacate must be filed within
ten (10) days of service of the notice.
      2.   Appeals must be submitted on an appeal form provided by the building
official. The appellant shall state the specific order or action protested and
a statement of the relief sought, along with the reasons why the order or
action should be reversed, modified or otherwise set aside.
      3.   Failure of any person to file an appeal in accordance with the
provisions of this section shall constitute a waiver of his/her right to an
appeal.
   C.   Stay Of Enforcement: The timely filing of an appeal shall stay further
action by the building official to enforce correction of the specific
violations being appealed.
Exception: There shall be no stay of enforcement when the building official
determines that the condition of the premises poses an immediate danger to the
occupants or to public safety. When such cases arise, the building official
shall convene a special Planning Commission hearing as soon as possible, which
shall consider possible ratification, reversal or modification of the building
official's action.
   D.   Procedures For Conduct Of Hearing Appeals:
      1.   Each appeal shall be reviewed by the Planning Commission, no later
than thirty (30) days from the date of filing of a written appeal. At least
four (4) members of the Planning Commission shall inspect the property and
review the notice and determine if it is accurate and attempt to develop, in
consultation with the appellant, possible methods of complying with the code
consistent with the purpose of this chapter.
      2.   The Planning Commission Secretary shall maintain complete and
permanent records of all inspections and decisions. Resolutions of disputed
issues, agreeable to the Planning Commission and the property owner, shall be
presented at the next meeting of the Planning Commission meeting for its
consent or modification.
   E.   Appeal Of Planning Commission Decisions: Any person aggrieved by a
decision of the Planning Commission made under this section may appeal such
decision to the City Council within ten (10) days of the written decision of
the Planning Commission. The City Council may consider testimony from any
interested party, and shall render a written decision within thirty (30) days
of the filing of the appeal to the Council. If the City Council determines that
the decision of the Planning Commission is supported by the evidence and is not
arbitrary or capricious, the City Council shall affirm the decision of the
Planning Commission. An appeal from the decision of the City Council shall be
made to a court of competent jurisdiction no later than thirty (30) days from
the date of issuance of such decision. (Ord. 95-142, 3-7-1995)
9-2A-12: VIOLATION; PENALTY:
   A.   Remedies: If, after any formal notice and order of the Building
Department has become final, the person to whom such orders have directed shall
fail, neglect or refuse to correct such order, the building official may pursue
one or more of the following remedies:
      1.   Cause such person to be prosecuted under subsection B of this
section.
      2.   Institute any appropriate action to abate such public nuisance as
provided by this chapter. (Ord. 95-142, 3-7-1995)
   B.   Misdemeanor: Failure of any person to comply with the requirements of
this chapter or to comply with any vacation order or any notice and order shall
constitute a Class B misdemeanor and shall be subject to penalty as provided in
title 1, chapter 4 of this Code. (Ord. 95-142, 3-7-1995; amd. 2019 Code)
ARTICLE B. MINIMUM HOUSING AND MAINTENANCE STANDARDS
SECTION:
9-2B-1: Substandard Buildings
9-2B-2: Exterior Standards
9-2B-3: Environmental Or Sanitary Standards
9-2B-4: Interior Standards
9-2B-5: Exterior And Interior Doors, Trim And Hardware
9-2B-1: SUBSTANDARD BUILDINGS:
Any building covered by this chapter shall be deemed substandard if there
exists a condition which places the safety of the occupants or the public at
risk. A building shall be deemed substandard if it does not meet the minimum
housing and maintenance standards of this chapter. (Ord. 95-142, 3-7-1995)
9-2B-2: EXTERIOR STANDARDS:
   A.   Sidewalks And Driveways: Sidewalks on private property shall be of hard
even surfaces, such as concrete or blacktop and shall be kept in graded even
surfaces. Settlement holes exceeding two inches (2") elevation shall be
repaired.
Exception: Gravel driveways and paths shall be groomed and kept level.
   B.   Chimneys: Loose bricks and cracks in chimneys shall be repaired and
missing chimney caps shall be replaced.
   C.   Structural Repair: All roofs, floors, walls, chimneys, foundations and
other structural components shall be repaired when they no longer retain their
structural integrity.
   D.   Exterior Surfaces: Exposed materials that require weather protection
and exterior surfaces that are deteriorating shall be sealed to the extent
necessary to keep cold, wind, water or dampness from the interior of the
structure.
   E.   Drainage: All surface water shall drain away from the structure.
   F.   Windows And Doors: Windows that are required by this chapter for light
and ventilation are to be glazed with approved glazing as specified in the IBC.
   G.   Rain Gutters And Downspouts: Rain gutters and downspouts, when
provided, shall be kept in good repair and clear of debris. (Ord. 95-142, 3-7-
1995)
9-2B-3: ENVIRONMENTAL OR SANITARY STANDARDS:
   A.   Garbage and refuse storage and removal shall meet the requirements of
the City ordinance.
   B.   There shall be no insect or rodent infestation in violation of the City
ordinance. (Ord. 95-142, 3-7-1995)
9-2B-4: INTERIOR STANDARDS:
   A.   Finishes, Washable Surfaces: In kitchens and bathrooms, floors and
walls adjacent to sinks, lavatories, toilets and tubs shall be finished with a
material that is not adversely affected by moisture.
Exception: In single-family dwellings, carpet may be installed on kitchen and
bathroom floors.
   B.   Floor Coverings: All floor and stair coverings shall be maintained so
that tripping hazards are minimized.
   C.   Wall And Ceiling Coverings: All wall and ceiling coverings shall be
maintained so that they are secure and substantially intact. (Ord. 95-142, 3-7-
1995)
9-2B-5: EXTERIOR AND INTERIOR DOORS, TRIM AND HARDWARE:
   A.   Maintenance: All doors, trim and hardware shall be kept in good working
condition. Each dwelling unit shall have approved locks for exterior doors
which are keyed from the exterior and are operable from the interior without
the use of a key or other special equipment or knowledge.
   B.   Hinges: Hinges for out swinging doors shall be equipped with
nonremovable hinge pins or a mechanical interlock to preclude removal of the
door from the exterior by removing the hinge pins. (Ord. 95-142, 3-7-1995)
ARTICLE C. MINIMUM SPACE AND OCCUPANCY STANDARDS
SECTION:
9-2C-1: Space And Occupancy Standards
9-2C-2: Light And Ventilation
9-2C-3: Fire Safety; Egress
9-2C-1: SPACE AND OCCUPANCY STANDARDS:
   A.   Ceiling And Window Sill Heights:
      1.   Stairs, Interior And Exterior: Existing reconstructed stairways
shall have a headroom clearance height of six feet four inches (6'4").
Exception: There shall be no minimum requirement for stairs to nonhabitable
rooms or areas.
      2.   Habitable Rooms: The minimum height for all habitable rooms shall be
six feet four inches (6'4"). (Ord. 95-142, 3-7-1995)
Exception: Projections shall be allowed to six feet zero inches (6'0") when: a)
the projection is not in the pattern of circulation; b) projections are not
greater than twenty percent (20%) of the floor area of the room; c) the window
requirements of this chapter for light and ventilation are met; and d) a one
hundred twenty (120) volt electrical powered smoke detector is installed in
such room, with the exception of a kitchen. Battery operated smoke detectors
are permitted in the existing structures when major wiring has not been
affected. (Ord. 95-142, 3-7-1995; amd. 2019 Code)
      3.   Nonhabitable Rooms: The minimum ceiling height for nonhabitable
rooms shall be six feet four inches (6'4").
Exceptions: Laundry rooms, shops and storage rooms or storage areas shall have
no minimum ceiling height requirement.
The bathroom shall have a minimum ceiling height of six feet zero inches (6'0")
with no projections.
The bathroom ceiling height at the back of a lavatory, toilet or tub without
shower may be sloped to a minimum height of five feet zero inches (5'0") at the
wall when the ceiling height is not less than six feet zero inches (6'0") at a
point two feet zero inches (2'0") from said wall.
      4.   Sloping Ceilings: In any room with a sloping ceiling, at least one-
half (1/2) the floor area shall have a minimum ceiling height as required by
subsection B of this section, or its successor. No portion of the room with a
ceiling height below five feet zero inches (5'0") may be used in the floor area
computation.
      5.   Corridors: A ceiling height of six feet four inches (6'4") shall be
required in corridors, and the minimum width of corridors shall be thirty six
inches (36").
Exception: In dwelling units constructed prior to 1983, a minimum corridor
width of thirty inches (30") shall be permitted.
      6.   New Construction: Additions made to the exterior of an existing
building envelope shall meet the requirements of the IBC. New construction
within the existing building envelope shall meet the requirements of this
chapter.
   B.   Room Size:
      1.   Floor Area And Room Dimensions: Dwelling units and congregate
housing shall have at least one room with not less than one hundred twenty
(120) square feet of floor area. Other habitable rooms except kitchens shall
have an area not less than seventy (70) square feet. Habitable rooms other than
a kitchen shall not be less than seven feet (7') in length or width.
      2.   Sleeping Room Dimensions: Every room used for sleeping shall not
have less than seventy (70) square feet of floor area. Where more than two (2)
persons occupy a room used for sleeping, the required floor area shall be
increased at the rate of fifty (50) square feet for each occupant in excess of
two (2).
      3.   Floor Area Computation: No portion of a room with a ceiling height
below five feet zero inches (5'0") may be used in the floor area computation.
   C.   Efficiency Dwelling Units: An efficiency dwelling unit shall:
      1.   Living Room: Have a living room of not less than one hundred ninety
(190) square feet of floor area. An additional one hundred (100) square feet of
floor area shall be provided for each occupant in excess of two (2).
      2.   Closet: Be provided with a closet.
      3.   Kitchen: Be provided with a kitchen sink, cooking range with oven
and/or microwave oven and refrigeration facilities, each having a clear working
space of not less than thirty inches (30") in front.
      4.   Bathroom: Be provided with a bathroom containing a toilet, lavatory
and bathtub or shower.
   D.   SRO Room Size: An SRO room shall have an area of not less than seventy
(70) square feet. For SRO rooms less than one hundred twenty (120) square feet
serving no more than ten (10) units, with a minimum of one common room per
floor, the common room may be a common kitchen when separate rooms are not
provided with cooking facilities.
   E.   Cook Facilities For Individual Units In Hotels, Motels And Congregate
Housing: As long as such cooking facilities for individual units in hotels,
motels and congregate housing do not encroach into the required floor area,
each individual unit may have cooking and eating facilities, provided all the
following items are supplied:
      1.   Range, Oven: A cooking range with oven and/or microwave oven. Hot
plates, electric fry pans and similar heating units shall not meet this
requirement.
      2.   Sink: An approved sink, with a minimum dimension of twelve inches by
twelve inches by four inches deep (12" x 12" x 4").
      3.   Counter Space: A minimum of four (4) square feet of counter space.
      4.   Refrigerator: A refrigerator.
   F.   Common Kitchens In Congregate Housing: When cooking facilities are not
provided with individual units, congregate housing shall have provided a common
kitchen area which shall contain the following minimum facilities: a sink for
each twenty (20) tenants or portion thereof, a range and oven for each twenty
(20) tenants or portion thereof, and a refrigerator for each ten (10) tenants
or portion thereof. The minimum kitchen area shall be seventy (70) square feet
for the first ten (10) occupants or portion thereof, and an additional thirty
(30) square feet for each additional ten (10) persons or portion thereof.
   G.   Kitchens And Bathrooms In Dwelling Units: Each dwelling unit shall have
a kitchen and bathroom within the dwelling unit. The bathroom shall have a
tight fitting door when the entry to the room is through the kitchen. Every
bathroom shall be provided with a means to ensure privacy.
   H.   Cooking Facilities In Dwelling Units: Each dwelling unit shall have a
kitchen. All cooking appliances shall be maintained in good working condition.
(Ord. 95-142, 3-7-1995)
9-2C-2: LIGHT AND VENTILATION:
   A.   Natural Light:
      1.   Every habitable room shall have at least one window facing directly
to the outdoors to provide natural light. The minimum total window area shall
equal one-twentieth (1/20) or more of the floor area, with a minimum of three
(3) square feet.
      2.   The glazed area of an exterior door may be used for purposes of
computing window size for natural light when an appropriate size window is
installed in the door.
      3.   For the purpose of meeting light or ventilation requirements, as
well as emergency egress, a room may be considered as a portion of an adjoining
room when one-half (1/2) of the area of the common wall is open and
unobstructed and provides an opening of not less than one-tenth (1/10) of the
floor area of the interior room or twenty five (25) square feet, whichever is
greater.
   B.   Ventilation:
      1.   Habitable Rooms:
         a.   Except as provided below, all habitable rooms shall be provided
with natural ventilation by means of openings to the exterior which have the
capability of being closed to the weather. Total openings shall have an area at
least one-twentieth (1/20) of the floor area or three (3) square feet,
whichever is greater.
         b.   Habitable rooms containing a mechanical ventilation system shall
be allowed in lieu of openings for natural ventilation. Such system shall
create a positive pressure in the room and the air intake shall be connected
directly to the outside and be capable of two (2) air exchanges per hour. The
air intake source shall be located at least three feet (3') above any vent
which is within ten feet (10') of the air intake.
         c.   Exterior doors may be used for the purpose of natural
ventilation. When used as such, a screen shall be installed thereon.
      2.   Nonhabitable Rooms:
         a.   Except as provided below, all bathrooms, toilet rooms, laundry
and similar rooms shall be provided with natural ventilation by means of
openings to the exterior which have the capability of being closed to the
weather. Such openings shall have a total area not less than one-twentieth (1/
20) of the floor area of the room, with a minimum of one and one-half (11/2)
square feet.
         b.   Bathrooms and laundry rooms containing a mechanical exhaust
system connected directly to the outside shall be allowed if such system is
capable of providing five (5) air exchanges per hour. The exhaust air shall
discharge at least three feet (3') above or ten feet (10') away from any air
intake source. Toilet room may be ventilated with an approved recirculation fan
or similar device designed to remove odors from the air.
         c.   Mechanical venting of bathrooms into the attic shall be
acceptable as long as provisions of the IBC are met.
         d.   Bathrooms constructed prior to 1970, vented with gravity vent
opening extending to the outside, shall meet the ventilation requirement as
long as the walls, ceiling and floor are not adversely affected by moisture.
(Ord. 95-142, 3-7-1995)
9-2C-3: FIRE SAFETY; EGRESS:
   A.   Fire Safety: All buildings, premises, equipment and apparatus shall be
in a condition such that no hazard of fire exists.
   B.   Exit And Emergency Egress:
      1.   Egress Required: Every dwelling unit or guestroom shall have a safe,
continuous and unobstructed means of egress of a minimum height of six feet
four inches (6'4") and a minimum width of thirty inches (30") directly to the
public way.
      2.   Emergency Egress: Every sleeping room located below the fourth story
shall have at least one openable window or exterior door approved for emergency
egress or rescue. The opening shall have a minimum of three (3) square feet of
openable space or clear opening dimensions of at least eighteen inches (18")
high and twenty four inches (24") wide.
Exception: Either height or width may be reduced to a minimum of fourteen
inches (14") when the corresponding dimension is increased by three inches (3")
for each one inch (1") the first dimension is diminished.
      3.   Window Sill Height: There shall be a maximum window sill height of
forty four inches (44") for at least one window in bedrooms or other rooms used
for sleeping. If the distance from the floor to the window sill is more than
forty four inches (44") for such window, a permanent platform of substantial
construction attached to the floor or wall may be installed to meet the maximum
height requirement. The minimum dimensions of such platform shall be twelve
inches (12") deep and the same width as the openable portion of the window, but
in no case less than twenty four inches (24") in width.
Exception 1: If minimum light and ventilation requirements are met, the
requirement of this subsection B3 shall not apply if there are two (2) approved
exit doors from the room leading to separate exitways.
Exception 2: If minimum light and ventilation requirements are met, there is no
minimum sill height requirement in bedrooms of dwelling units constructed
before 1970, except for bedrooms in basement areas.
      4.   Below Grade Windows: For windows that are below grade, a window well
shall be provided whose length is the width of the window and which extends at
least eighteen inches (18") out from the exterior of the building. When the
distance from the top of the window well to its bottom exceeds forty eight
inches (48"), it shall have a permanently mounted platform or ladder. Grates
