are permitted over window wells if hinged to pivot away from the structure and
not weighing over fifteen (15) pounds per section of the grate.
      5.   Additional Devices: Bars, grills, grates or similar devices may be
installed on emergency escape or rescue windows or doors, provided such devices
are equipped with approved release mechanisms which are operable from the
inside without the use of a key or special knowledge or effort.
   C.   Stairs And Handrails: Stairs and handrails shall meet the requirements
of the IBC or its successor with the following modifications:
      1.   Handrail: If there are four (4) or more risers, a handrail shall be
required. Two (2) handrails shall be required when the width of the stairs is
forty eight inches (48") or more, except that no handrail shall be required for
monumental stairs.
      2.   Placement: Handrails shall be placed not less than thirty inches
(30") nor more than thirty eight inches (38") above the outermost edge of the
tread. (Ord. 95-142, 3-7-1995)
      3.   Prior To 1970: Existing interior stairs and exterior stairs
constructed before 1970 are not required to meet current code minimum width
standards. (Ord. 95-142, 3-7-1995; amd. 2019 Code)
      4.   Rise Required: Existing interior and exterior stairs shall have a
rise of no more than eight inches (8") and a run of not less than nine inches
(9"). Within any flight of stairs, the greatest riser height shall not exceed
the smallest by more than one inch (1"), nor shall the largest tread run exceed
the smallest by more than one inch (1").
Exception 1: Monumental stairs without a handrail shall be restricted to one
inch (1") variation in the rise and run.
Exception 2: On winder, circular or spiral stairs as defined in the IBC, the
width of the tread may be less than six inches (6") on the inside edge, if six
inches (6") is maintained at a distance no less than thirty inches (30") from
the outside edge of the stairs.
Exception 3: There shall be no minimum rise or run requirement nor maximum
variation in the rise and run for stairs leading only to mechanical, storage
and utility rooms, provided the stairs are structurally sound.
      5.   Rebuilding: Stairs in the interior or exterior of an existing
building which are completely rebuilt shall meet the requirement of the IBC.
   D.   Guardrails:
      1.   Required: Guardrails shall be required for all balconies, porches,
patios and open stairs more than thirty inches (30") above or below grade.
Guardrails shall also be required for any grade change more than thirty inches
(30") next to a walking surface. Guardrails shall not be less than forty two
inches (42") in height, except for guardrails serving private dwelling units,
which shall have a minimum height of thirty six inches (36").
Exception 1: Public guardrails may have a minimum height of thirty six inches
(36") if the building was built before 1970.
Exception 2: Guardrails having a height less than thirty six inches (36") shall
be allowed if they were installed as part of the building's original
construction and are not a replacement.
      2.   Open Guardrails: Open guardrails shall have intermediate rails or an
ornamental pattern such that there is no open area in excess of four inches
(4") in diameter. The foregoing notwithstanding, the diameter of such open
space may be nine inches (9") for buildings built before 1985, and six inches
(6") for those built between 1985 and 1991.
   E.   Smoke Detector Requirements:
      1.   Required: Smoke detectors shall be required in all dwelling units.
Such detectors shall be mounted on the ceiling or wall at a point centrally
located in the corridor and all sleeping rooms. In efficiency dwelling units,
hotel sleeping rooms and hotel suites, the detector shall be centrally located
on the ceiling or wall of the main room or hotel sleeping room.
      2.   Upper Level Sleeping Rooms: Where sleeping rooms are on an upper
level, the detector shall be placed at the ceiling or wall directly above the
stairway immediately outside the bedrooms. Wall mounted detectors shall be
mounted as near to the ceiling as possible, but no detector shall be mounted
within twelve inches (12") of any corner formed by the meeting of walls,
ceilings, beams or structure. When activated, the detector shall provide an
alarm in the dwelling unit or guestroom.
      3.   Repairs, Additional Sleeping Rooms Added: When repairs to a
structure are made which exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) or when one or
more sleeping rooms are added or created to a structure, smoke detectors shall
be installed in compliance with the IBC.
   F.   Wall And Ceiling Separations: Except as provided below, any wall or
ceiling separating dwelling units shall be maintained in its original condition
with all penetrations sealed or covered with an approved material. Walls and
ceilings separating a garage or carport from a dwelling unit or common area
shall be maintained in their original condition with all penetrations sealed or
covered with an approved material as specified by the IBC.
Exception: When fifty percent (50%) or more of a wall or ceiling is removed for
any reason, the entire wall or ceiling shall be reconstructed to meet the
requirements of the IBC for one hour occupancy separation. (Ord. 95-142, 3-7-
1995)
ARTICLE D. PLUMBING, MECHANICAL, AND ELECTRICAL
SECTION:
9-2D-1: Plumbing
9-2D-2: Mechanical Equipment
9-2D-3: Electrical
9-2D-1: PLUMBING:
   A.   Minimum Requirements:
      1.   Unless provided otherwise in this chapter, plumbing, piping and
fixtures shall be in accordance with the code in effect at the time of
installation.
      2.   Plumbing, piping, and fixtures shall not contain leaks and all waste
lines must be connected to an approved sewer system and shall be maintained in
good condition.
      3.   The minimum plumbing fixtures required for congregate housing are a
lavatory, toilet and tub or shower for each ten (10) occupants, or portion
thereof, and a kitchen sink as required in this chapter.
      4.   There shall be cold running water plumbed to each toilet and hot and
cold running water plumbed to each lavatory, tub, shower and kitchen sink.
      5.   The minimum plumbing fixtures for dwelling units are a lavatory,
toilet, tub or shower, and kitchen sink.
      6.   There shall be a space without obstruction from floor to ceiling of
not less than twelve inches (12") in front of all toilets. Toilets shall be
located in a space without obstruction from floor to ceiling of not less than
twenty two inches (22") in width. No encroachments of these dimensions are
permitted.
      7.   Where vents do not exist for plumbing fixtures meeting the
applicable codes in effect at the time of their installation, vents need not be
installed when the plumbing fixture or trap and trap arm is replaced providing
the sewer line is not altered.
      8.   Every motel and hotel that does not provide private toilets,
lavatories, bathtubs or showers shall have on each floor, accessible from a
public hallway, at least one toilet, one lavatory, and one bathtub with shower
or one separate shower for each ten (10) occupants, or portion thereof, an
additional one toilet, one lavatory and one bathtub or shower accessible from a
public hallway shall be provided for each additional ten (10) occupants.
   B.   Water Heaters: Water heaters and boilers shall have an approved
combination temperature and pressure relief valve and relief valve discharge
pipe. All new installations of water heaters and boilers, when located above an
occupied space, shall include a safe pan with a drain piped to an approved
drainage system. Existing water heaters and boilers shall have a temperature
and pressure valve. The valve shall have a discharge pipe which discharges
within six inches (6") of the floor.
Exception: A temperature and pressure relief valve shall be required for water
heaters only when a water heater was designed for such valve.
   C.   Cross Connections: In order to protect against contamination of the
water supply through cross connections, all water inlets for plumbing fixtures
shall be located above the flood level rim of the fixture as defined in the
IPC. Hoses or hand held shower heads shall not be attached in any manner that
would permit water contamination during reverse pressure.
Exception 1: Water supply pipes provided with an approved backflow preventer or
antisiphon device as regulated in the IPC shall be permitted.
Exception 2: Hand held shower heads shall be permitted when provided with a
permanently mounted holder attached to the wall or shower pipe, or when an
antisiphon device is installed.
Exception 3: For dwelling units built before 1970, water faucet outlets below
the overflow rim of the fixture shall be permitted until the faucet is
replaced. A new fixture shall not be installed where it would create a cross
connection.
   D.   Drains:
      1.   Drain traps shall meet standards of the IPC.
Exception: For dwelling units built in 1969 and before, existing traps shall be
allowed as originally designed. If the trap has been modified it shall be
replaced with an approved trap, and a vent shall be added as required by the
IPC.
      2.   All open untrapped sewer lines and unused trapped outlets shall be
capped with an approved cap.
   E.   Fixture Requirements:
      1.   Showers shall be finished to a height of seventy inches (70") above
the fixture drain outlet with nonabsorbent material.
Exception: Freestanding tubs with shower risers may utilize a shower curtain
that totally encloses all sides of the tub.
      2.   Every kitchen sink, lavatory, tub and shower shall be provided with
hot water of at least one hundred twenty degrees Fahrenheit (120oF) with cold
water.
      3.   Every kitchen sink, lavatory, tub, shower and toilet shall be
provided with a minimum of fifteen (15) psi of water pressure. (Ord. 95-142, 3-
7-1995)
9-2D-2: MECHANICAL EQUIPMENT:
   A.   Mechanical Equipment:
      1.   All mechanical equipment shall be in accordance with the code in
effect at the time of installation.
      2.   All mechanical equipment shall be properly maintained and shall be
operated in a safe manner.
   B.   Heating:
      1.   Heating is to be provided by a permanently installed heating system
capable of heating all habitable rooms and bathrooms to a minimum of sixty
eight degrees Fahrenheit (68oF).
      2.   A return air duct shall not be permitted which serves more than one
dwelling unit.
Exceptions: A common air return shall be permitted if the heating system was
installed prior to 1960. A common air return shall be permitted for equipment
installed after 1959 and before 1969 and for furnace replacements using
existing ducts if a listed smoke detector is installed in the return air vent
which will shut down the furnace fan in the event of fire.
   C.   Fuel Burning Appliances:
      1.   Gas furnaces and water heaters shall not be permitted in bedrooms,
in bathrooms, or in closets with access only from a bedroom or a bathroom.
      2.   Gas shutoff valves are required on all gas appliances. Shutoff
valves shall be installed in accordance with the IMC.
      3.   All fireplaces, wood burning stoves and all other appliances
producing combustible gas byproducts shall be connected to an operating chimney
or approved flue. All flues and vents shall be installed per requirements of
the IMC in effect at the time of installation.
      4.   All fuel burning appliances shall be provided with combustion air
per the requirement of their listing and with the IMC.
      5.   All fuel burning appliances shall be provided with listed clearances
and maintained in good working condition.
      6.   All ventilation fans shall be installed according to their listing
and maintained in good working condition.
      7.   All ducts and vents shall be maintained according to original
installation requirements.
   D.   Asbestos: Asbestos, regardless of the date of installation, shall meet
the requirements of the State of Utah Department of Environmental Quality.
(Ord. 95-142, 3-7-1995)
9-2D-3: ELECTRICAL:
   A.   Minimum Requirements:
      1.   Unless provided otherwise in this chapter, all electrical wiring and
equipment shall be in accordance with the code in effect at the time of
installation.
      2.   All electrical panels, boxes and outlets are to have proper covers.
Every habitable room, including an SRO room, shall contain at least two (2)
electrical receptacles or one receptacle and one electric light fixture. Every
toilet room, bathroom, laundry room, furnace room and public hallway shall
contain at least one electrical light fixture. Electrical equipment shall not
exceed the load capacity of the service, and branch circuits shall be properly
fused.
      3.   Grounding type receptacles shall only be used when connected to a
grounding system. Existing nongrounding type receptacles may be replaced with
grounding type receptacles where protected by a ground fault circuit
interrupter.
   B.   Minimum Service: Existing dwelling units with electrical service less
than sixty (60) amps per dwelling unit which have no special electrical service
loads, such as air conditioners, stoves, heating units and refrigerators, may
continue to be operated without upgrading.
Exceptions: In structures built before 1970, residential units that are
remodeled at a cost exceeding three thousand dollars ($3,000.00) per unit
(excluding cabinets, painting and carpet) shall have their electrical systems
upgraded to meet the requirements of the NEC.
   C.   Circuits: Circuits supplying air conditioners, cooking stoves and
heating appliances shall meet the requirements of the NEC.
   D.   Replacement Of Existing Electrical Fixtures: Electrical outlets and
switches may be replaced without upgrading electric wiring which was installed
in accordance with the applicable code at the time of installation.
   E.   New Installations: When new circuits, outlets, switches, wiring and
service panels are being installed, all work shall meet the NEC requirements.
   F.   Lighting: Lighting in common areas of apartment structures, congregate
housing, hotels and motels shall meet the following:
      1.   Aisles, passageways, stairwells, corridors, entryways and recesses
related to and within the building complex shall be illuminated with minimum of
forty watt (40 W) light bulb or equivalent for each two hundred (200) square
feet of floor area; provided, that the spacing between lights shall not be
greater than thirty feet (30').
Exception: Structures containing no more than three (3) dwelling units shall
not be required to provide exit lighting when no lighting outlet has been
previously provided.
      2.   Open parking lots and carports shall be provided with a minimum of
one foot-candle of light on the parking surface during the hours of darkness.
Lighting devices shall be protected by weather resistant covers. (Ord. 95-142,
3-7-1995)
ARTICLE E. RENTAL HOUSING - FIT PREMISES ACT
SECTION:
9-2E-1: Short Title
9-2E-2: Administration And Enforcement
9-2E-3: Duties Of Owners And Renters Generally
9-2E-4: Owner's Duties
9-2E-5: Renter's Duties
9-2E-6: Remedies For Renters
9-2E-1: SHORT TITLE:
This article is known as the RENTAL HOUSING - FIT PREMISES ACT. (Ord. 95-142,
3-7-1995)
9-2E-2: ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT:
   A.   Purpose: The purpose of this article is to provide for administration
and enforcement of this article.
   B.   Regulations: Regulations for owners of rental units, including three-
plex, apartment housing, group homes and apartment hotel include:
      1.   A business license or regulatory business license shall be required
of anyone who receives rental income from rental space for living quarters in
the above mentioned properties.
      2.   A certificate of occupancy may be required at the time the business
license is applied for. This certificate shall be issued by the building
inspector after the rental units have been inspected and found to meet the
requirements of this chapter.
      3.   The application for a regulatory business license shall be
accompanied by a special rental inspection fee, if a special inspection is
performed or a certificate of occupancy is issued, as specified by resolution
of the City Council. If an inspection is performed, an inspection fee shall be
required for the inspection of each rental dwelling owned by that owner. This
fee will be in addition to the business license fee.
      4.   If an inspection of a rental dwelling approves the rental dwelling
for purposes of a regulatory business license, the City may not inspect that
rental dwelling during the next thirty six (36) months, unless the City has
reasonable cause to believe that a condition in the rental dwelling is in
violation of an applicable law or ordinance.
      5.   Nothing in this article shall be construed to affect the rights and
duties established under this Rental Housing - Fit Premises Act, or to restrict
the City's ability to enforce its generally applicable Health Ordinances or
Building Codes or other Health and Safety Codes. (Ord. 05-05, 3-1-2005)
9-2E-3: DUTIES OF OWNERS AND RENTERS GENERALLY:
   A.   Fit Premises: Each landlord and his agent renting or leasing a
residential rental unit shall maintain that unit in a condition fit for human
habitation and in accordance with local ordinances and the rules of the Board
of Health having jurisdiction in the area in which the residential rental unit
is located. Each residential rental unit shall have electrical systems,
heating, plumbing, and hot and cold water.
   B.   Tenant Cooperation: Each tenant shall cooperate in maintaining his
residential unit in accordance with this chapter.
   C.   Exceptions: This article does not apply to breakage, malfunctions or
other conditions which do not materially affect the physical health or safety
of the ordinary tenant.
   D.   Agreement Required For Allocation Of Duty: Any duty in this article may
be allocated to a different party by explicit written agreement signed by the
parties. (Ord. 95-142, 3-7-1995)
9-2E-4: OWNER'S DUTIES:
   A.   Health And Safety Standards: To protect the physical health and safety
of the ordinary tenant, each owner shall:
      1.   Not rent the premises unless they are safe, sanitary and fit for
human occupancy;
      2.   Maintain common areas of the residential rental unit in a sanitary
and safe condition;
      3.   Maintain electrical systems, plumbing, heating, and hot and cold
water;
      4.   Maintain other appliances and facilities as specifically contracted
in the lease agreement; and
      5.   For buildings containing more than two (2) residential rental units,
provide and maintain appropriate receptacles for garbage and other waste and
arrange for its removal, except to the extent that renters and owners otherwise
agree.
   B.   Notice Of Noncompliance: In the event the renter believes the
residential rental unit does not comply with the standards for health and
safety required under this article, the renter shall give written notice of the
noncompliance to the owner. Within a reasonable time after receipt of this
notice, the owner shall commence action to correct the condition of the unit.
   C.   Renter Caused: The owner need not correct or remedy any condition
caused by the renter, the renter's family, or the renter's guests or invitees
by inappropriate use or misuse of the property during the rental term or any
extension of it.
   D.   Refusal To Correct: The owner may refuse to correct the condition of
the residential rental unit and terminate the rental agreement if the unit is
unfit for occupancy.
      1.   If the owner refuses to correct and intends to terminate the rental
agreement, he shall notify the renter in writing within a reasonable time after
receipt of the notice of noncompliance. If the rental agreement is terminated,
the rent paid shall be prorated to the date the agreement is terminated, and
any balance shall be refunded to the renter along with any deposit due. (Ord.
95-142, 3-7-1995)
      2.   If the owner refuses to correct the conditions, and the tenant
vacates the unit, the rental unit may not be inhabited by any other renter
until the deficiencies have been corrected and inspected by the building
official. (Ord. 96-146, 2-6-1996)
   E.   Nonliability: The owner is not liable under this article for claims for
mental suffering or anguish. (Ord. 95-142, 3-7-1995)
9-2E-5: RENTER'S DUTIES:
   A.   Specified: Each renter shall:
      1.   Comply with the rules of the Board of Health having jurisdiction in
the area in which the residential rental unit is located which materially
affect physical health and safety;
      2.   Maintain the premises occupied in a clean and safe condition and
shall not unreasonably burden any common area;
      3.   Dispose of all garbage and other waste in a clean and safe manner;
      4.   Maintain all plumbing fixtures in as sanitary a condition as the
fixtures permit;
      5.   Use all electrical, plumbing, sanitary, heating, and other
facilities and appliances in a reasonable manner;
      6.   Occupy the residential rental unit in the manner for which it was
designed, but the renter may not increase the number of occupants above that
specified in the rental agreement without written permission of the owner;
      7.   Be current on all payments required by the rental agreement; and
      8.   Comply with all appropriate requirements of the rental agreement
between the owner and the renter.
   B.   Prohibitions: No renter may:
      1.   Intentionally or negligently destroy, deface, damage, impair or
remove any part of the residential rental unit or knowingly permit any person
to do so;
      2.   Interfere with the peaceful enjoyment of the residential unit of
another renter; or
      3.   Unreasonably deny access to, refuse entry to, or withhold consent to
enter the residential rental unit to the owner, agent or manager for the
purpose of making repairs to the unit. (Ord. 95-142, 3-7-1995)
9-2E-6: REMEDIES FOR RENTERS:
   A.   Compliance: A renter is not entitled to the remedies set forth in this
article unless the renter is in compliance with all provisions of section
9-2E-5 of this article.
   B.   Notice To Repair Or Correct: If a reasonable time has elapsed after the
renter has served written notice on the owner under section
9-2E-4 of this article and the condition described in the notice has not been
corrected, the renter may cause a "notice to repair or correct condition" to be
prepared and served on the owner. This notice shall:
      1.   Recite the previous notice served;
      2.   Recite the number of days that have elapsed since the notice was
served and state that under the circumstances such a period of time constitutes
the reasonable time allowed;
      3.   State the conditions included in the previous notice which have not
been corrected;
      4.   Make demand that the uncorrected conditions be corrected; and
      5.   State that in the event of failure of the owner to commence
reasonable corrective action within three (3) days, the renter will seek
redress in the courts.
   C.   Failure To Comply:
      1.   If the owner has not corrected or due diligence to correct the
conditions following the notice under this section, the renter is entitled to
bring an action in Circuit or District Court.
      2.   The court shall endorse on the summons the number of days within
which the owner is required to appear and defend the action, which shall not be
less than three (3) nor more than twenty (20) days from the date of service.
      3.   Upon a showing of an unjustified refusal to correct or the failure
to use due diligence to correct a condition described in this article, the
renter is entitled to damages and injunctive relief as determined by the court.
(Ord. 95-142, 3-7-1995)
CHAPTER 3
CONDOMINIUMS
SECTION:
9-3-1: Short Title
9-3-2: Purpose
9-3-3: Definitions
9-3-4: Application And Approval
9-3-5: Condominium Conversion
9-3-6: Design And Management Requirements
9-3-7: Enforcement
9-3-8: Penalty
9-3-1: SHORT TITLE:
This chapter shall be known as the FILLMORE CITY CONDOMINIUM ORDINANCE. (Ord.
02-04, 3-5-2002)
9-3-2: PURPOSE:
Condominium ownership differs in numerous respects from conventional building
ownership. It is in the interest of the public health, safety and welfare that
condominium projects be reviewed and approved by the City and appropriately
regulated for the protection of the community, displaced tenants and
prospective purchasers of condominium units. The procedures set forth herein
are intended to recognize the unique characteristics of condominiums and
condominium conversions. These procedures are adopted to provide a review
process and a set of standards which will address these unique characteristics
and to reduce any negative impacts upon the community, neighborhood areas, or
prospective owners which may result from the creation of a condominium or from
a condominium conversion. The procedure and requirements of this chapter shall
apply to and govern the construction and conversion of condominium projects
within the City. The provisions of this chapter shall supplement zoning,
health, building or other ordinances which may be applicable to a particular
condominium project, and shall apply to the approval of all condominium
projects involving new construction as well as conversion of existing
structures. (Ord. 02-04, 3-5-2002)
9-3-3: DEFINITIONS:
The following terms, as used in this chapter, shall have the respective
meanings hereinafter set forth. Whenever any words or phrases used in this
chapter are not defined herein, but are defined in related sections of the Utah
Code Annotated or this Code, such definitions are incorporated herein and shall
apply as though set forth herein in full, unless the context clearly indicates
a contrary intention:
BUILDING: A single structure containing, or intended to contain, individual
condominium units, and comprising all or part of a condominium project.
CITY: Fillmore City.
COMMON AREAS AND COMMON FACILITIES: Unless otherwise provided in the
declaration or lawful amendments thereto, shall mean and include:
   A.   The land included within the condominium project, whether leasehold or
in fee simple;
   B.   The foundations, columns, girders, beams, supports, main walls, roofs,
halls, corridors, lobbies, stairs, stairways, fire escapes, and entrances and
exits of the building or buildings;
   C.   The basements, yard, gardens, parking areas and storage spaces located
on the property upon which the condominium project is situated;
   D.   The premises for lodging of employees of the condominium project, such
as janitors, maintenance personnel or property managers;
   E.   Installations of central services, such as power, light, gas, hot and
cold water, heating, refrigeration, air conditioning and incinerating;
   F.   The elevators, tanks, pumps, motors, fans, compressors, ducts and, in
general, all apparatus and installations existing for common use;
   G.   Such community and commercial facilities as may be provided for in the
declaration; and
   H.   All other parts of the property necessary or convenient to its
existence, maintenance and safety, or normally in common use.
COMMON EXPENSES: Means and includes:
   A.   All sums lawfully assessed against the unit owners;
   B.   Expenses of administration, maintenance, repair or replacement of the
common areas and facilities;
   C.   Expenses agreed upon as common expenses by the homeowners'
associations; and
   D.   Expenses declared common expenses by provisions of this chapter, or by
the condominium project declaration or bylaws, as amended from time to time.
CONDOMINIUM OR CONDOMINIUM UNIT: A single unit in a multi-unit condominium
project, where the single unit is owned separately from the other units in the
condominium project, together with an undivided interest in the common areas
and facilities associated with the condominium project.
CONDOMINIUM PROJECT: A building project or a planned building project
consisting of two (2) or more units, whether situated in existing apartments or
proposed structures, which are separately offered or proposed to be offered for
sale. Condominium project shall also mean the real property upon which the
building project is situated when the context so requires.
CONVERSION: A proposed change in the type of ownership of a parcel or parcels
of land and/or existing structures from single ownership, such as an apartment
house or multi-family dwelling, into a condominium project, with arrangements
involving separate ownership of individual condominium units and joint
collective ownership of common areas or facilities.
DECLARANT: Any person who executes a condominium declaration or on whose behalf
a condominium declaration is executed. From the time of the recordation of any
amendment to the declaration expanding an expandable condominium, all persons
who execute that amendment or on whose behalf that amendment is executed shall
also come within this definition. Any successors of the persons referred to in
this definition who come to stand in the same relation to the condominium
project as their predecessors did shall also come within this definition.
DECLARATION CONTAINING COVENANTS, CONDITIONS AND RESTRICTIONS: Relating to the
condominium project which is required under Utah Code Annotated section 57-8-
10, or any subsequent amendment or enactment thereof.
OPEN SPACE: Landscaped areas that are not occupied by buildings, structures,
parking areas, streets or alleys and are devoted to recreation use or
preservation of natural features.
PERSON: Any person, firm, corporation, partnership or association.
PROPERTY: Means and includes the land, whether leasehold or in fee simple, the
building or buildings situated on the land, and all other improvements to the
land, all easements, rights and appurtenances belonging to the land, and all
articles of personal property intended for use in connection therewith.
RECORD OF SURVEY MAP: A plat or plats originating from a survey of the property
and setting forth the locations of existing and proposed buildings and other
structures, units within buildings, open space, parking space, recreational
space, utility and service connections, and any other information needed by the
Planning Commission to evaluate an application for a conditional use permit.
UNIT NUMBER: The number or letter, or a combination of numbers and letters,
designating the unit in the declaration and on the record of survey map.
UNIT OWNER: The person or persons owning a unit in fee simple and an undivided
interest in the fee simple estate of the common areas and facilities in the
percentage specified and established in the declaration. (Ord. 02-04, 3-5-2002)
9-3-4: APPLICATION AND APPROVAL:
   A.   Approval Required: Prior to the construction or conversion of any
building to be used as a condominium, the record of survey map and the
condominium declaration, executed pursuant to Utah Code Annotated section 57-8-
10, or any subsequent amendment or enactment thereof, shall be submitted, along
with an application for a conditional use permit, to the Planning Commission
pursuant to the requirements of this chapter and section
10-3-4 of this Code. The Planning Commission shall review the application and
information and shall deny the application or approve the application,
conditioned on the approval of the application by the City Council. If the
Planning Commission denies the application, it shall notify the applicant in
writing within ten (10) days of its decision. If the Planning Commission
approves the application, the application and accompanying information shall be
submitted to the City Council. If the City Council denies the application, it
shall notify the applicant in writing within ten (10) days of its decision. If
the City Council approves the application, it shall notify the applicant in
writing within ten (10) days of its decision. Upon the approval of the City
Council, the applicant may proceed with construction or conversion pursuant to
the requirements and restrictions imposed by this Code and all codes or rules
adopted by this Code.
   B.   Appeals:
      1.   An applicant whose application has been denied by the Planning
Commission may appeal to the City Council by filing with the City Recorder a
notice of appeal in writing within ten (10) days of receipt of notice of the
adverse decision. Such notice of appeal shall set forth in detail the action
appealed and grounds for the appeal.
      2.   The City Recorder shall set the appeal for hearing before the City
Council within forty five (45) days of receipt of the notice of appeal. Written
notice of the date set for hearing the appeal shall be mailed to the appellant
at least ten (10) days before the appeal hearing date. After hearing the
appeal, the City Council may affirm, modify or overrule the Planning
Commission's decision. If the Planning Commission's decision is overruled by
the City Council, the City Council may direct the Planning Commission to grant
the conditional use permit sought by the applicant.
      3.   The appellant may appeal any decision of the City Council by filing
an action in the District Court pursuant to the Utah Rules of Civil Procedure.
   C.   Recording Declaration And Record Of Survey Map: Upon approval of the
condominium project by the City Council, and pursuant to Utah Code Annotated
section 57-8-10, or any subsequent amendment or enactment thereof, the
condominium declaration and record of survey map shall be presented by the City
Recorder to the County Recorder for recording on the public records. (Ord. 02-
04, 3-5-2002)
9-3-5: CONDOMINIUM CONVERSION:
   A.   Report Of Property Condition: As an element of any application for a
conditional use permit seeking to convert an existing structure or structures
to a condominium project, the owner/developer shall submit a report of property
condition which is intended to ensure that the declaration appropriately
addresses existing and future conditions related to maintenance, upkeep and
operation. The report of property condition, which may be referred back to the
applicant by the Planning Commission or City Council for additional detail as
is necessary, shall be submitted on a form provided by the City and shall
contain the following information:
      1.   The age of the buildings with copies of original building plans and
a disclosure of whether or not the actual building conforms to the plans;
      2.   Condition of structural elements, including roof, foundations,
walls, mechanical system, electrical system, plumbing system and heating
system;
      3.   A plan showing which parts of the system are maintained in common
and which are maintained by individual units;
      4.   Size of water service lines from meter to main and from main to
buildings;
      5.   Size and location of sewer lateral;
      6.   Capacity of electrical service for each unit measured in amps;
      7.   Condition of paving materials on private streets, if any;
      8.   Condition of paving or surfacing material on driveways, parking
areas, sidewalks, curbs, etc.;
      9.   Detailed plan of parking and traffic circulation;
      10.   Condition of paint (including disclosure of any known lead based
paint) and/or exterior surfaces of all buildings and structures;
      11.   All known conditions constituting defect or deficiencies; and
      12.   All known conditions which may require repair or replacement within
the next succeeding five (5) year period.
   B.   Report Of Building Inspector: At the time of submission of an
application for a conditional use permit seeking to convert existing building
or buildings to a condominium project, the building inspector shall make an
inspection of the proposed condominium project to determine compliance with the
safety provisions and other requirements of the City. The building inspector
shall submit a written report of his findings to the Planning Commission for
its consideration.
   C.   Tenant Notice Of Conversion: Whenever a proposed condominium project
involves the conversion of an existing residential structure which has been
occupied by residential tenants prior to application for conversion, the owner/
developer shall provide notice of the intended conversion to said tenants by
certified mail. This notice requirement shall not apply to nonresidential
structures or to a residential structure that was vacant upon acquisition by
the owner/developer and remained vacant until filing of the application for
conversion. The notice of conversion shall include the following:
      1.   Notice of the owner/developer's plans for the conversion of the
building to a condominium project;
      2.   The estimated dates of termination of occupancy by tenants, which
shall not be less than ninety (90) days from the date of notice, and the
estimated date of the commencement of construction, which shall not be less
than one hundred twenty (120) days from the date of notice;
      3.   A statement informing the tenant that he or she shall be given first
right to purchase their respective unit upon at least as favorable terms and
conditions as the units are offered to the general public; and
      4.   Relocation information for the tenants specifying available
alternative housing relocation resource agencies and organizations, and a plan
of any services to be voluntarily provided by the owner/developer.
   D.   Tenant Notice Verification: Prior to, and as a condition of, issuance
of a conditional use permit by the Planning Commission, the owner/developer
shall submit to the City Recorder a copy of the notice provided to tenants,
together with a list identifying the names and apartments or unit numbers of
each tenant within the proposed condominium project. The notice and list shall
be accompanied by an affidavit certifying that all tenants within the proposed
condominium project have been served, by registered or certified mail, copies
of the notice. (Ord. 02-04, 3-5-2002)
9-3-6: DESIGN AND MANAGEMENT REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Utilities: Each condominium unit within a condominium development shall
be separately metered for gas, electricity and water, and shall be provided
with readily accessible individual shutoff valves for each utility service, and
safety devices or switches for such services unless the declaration provides
that the homeowners' association is required to pay the cost of any such
services. If the homeowners' association is required to pay the costs of any
such services, the declaration must disclose to the unit owners that nonpayment
of utility bills by the homeowners' association may result in loss of those
services.
   B.   Heating System: Each condominium unit shall be equipped with its own
heating system, except where a central water or steam heating system is
present. Where a central water or steam heating system is present, each
condominium unit shall be provided with its own means of controlling
temperature in that unit.
   C.   Construction:
      1.   Construction shall proceed only upon issuance of a conditional use
permit and only in accordance with the plans and specifications approved by the
Planning Commission and the City Council, and in conformity with any additional
conditions attached by the Planning Commission or City Council. (Ord. 02-04, 3-
5-2002)
      2.   Amendments to approved plans and specifications for any condominium
project shall be recommended for approval by the Planning Commission to the
City Council. If approved, such approval shall be shown on the approved plans.
(Ord. 02-04, 3-5-2002; amd. 2019 Code)
      3.   The building inspector shall not issue any building or occupancy
permit for any proposed building or structure within a condominium project
unless such building or structure is constructed in accordance with the
approved development plan and any conditions imposed in conjunction with its
approval.
   D.   Additional Design And Layout:
      1.   A proposed condominium project, including the land upon which it is
to be situated, shall be owned by a single person or entity during development
in order to ensure full supervision and control of the condominium project and
to ensure conformance with these provisions and all conditions imposed upon the
preliminary and final project plans.
      2.   Where appropriate, the owner/developer of a condominium project
shall provide pedestrian and bicycle paths that are physically separated from
vehicular traffic in or adjacent to the condominium project.
      3.   All condominium projects shall provide reasonable visual and
acoustical privacy for dwelling units. Fences, insulation, walks, barriers,
landscaping and sound reducing construction techniques shall be used for the
enhancement of the privacy of the occupants.
      4.   A minimum of one thousand (1,000) square feet of playground area
shall be provided by the owner/developer of any condominium project consisting
of five (5) individual units or more, plus an additional two hundred (200)
square feet for each additional unit over five (5).
      5.   The declaration, bylaws or subsequent action by the homeowners'
association may prescribe limits on the total number of individual units that
may be leased at any given time.
   E.   Homeowners' Association: The declaration of any condominium project
shall provide for the organization of a homeowners' association to govern the
affairs of the condominium project and for the election or appointment of a
board of trustees and officers. A homeowners' association shall be organized
under the laws of the State and may take the legal form of a nonprofit
corporation or any other lawful business entity form. (Ord. 02-04, 3-5-2002)
9-3-7: ENFORCEMENT:
The City shall have the authority to enforce the provisions of this chapter
against violations thereof by actions including, but not limited to, the
following:
   A.   Denial of condominium initiation and maintenance of an action for
injunctive relief to restrain, abate or cause the correction of such violation;
or
   B.   Initiation and maintenance of an action for injunctive relief to
restrain, abate or cause the correction of such violation; or
   C.   Initiation of criminal proceedings. (Ord. 02-04, 3-5-2002)
9-3-8: PENALTY:
It shall be unlawful for any person to sell any unit of any condominium or any
other portion thereof until the final declaration and record of survey map, in
full compliance with the provisions of this chapter, have been finally approved
by the City Council and duly recorded in the Office of the County Recorder, and
a conditional use permit has been issued by the Planning Commission. Any
developer, agent of a developer, owner, successor in interest of a developer or
owner, tenant, purchaser, builder, contractor, or other person who violates any
of the provisions of this chapter, or any conditions imposed pursuant to this
chapter, shall be deemed guilty of a Class C misdemeanor, subject to penalty as
provided in title 1, chapter 4 of this Code. Each day of violation shall
constitute a separate violation. (Ord. 02-04, 3-5-2002; amd. 2019 Code)
CHAPTER 4
IMPACT FEES AND EXACTIONS
SECTION:
9-4-1: Exactions
9-4-2: Amendments
9-4-3: Penalty
9-4-1: EXACTIONS:
   A.   Authority: The City Council is hereby authorized to establish and
require exactions as a condition of granting subdivision plat approval and/or
as a condition of the issuance of a building permit from an individual or a
developer when the proposed development will impact any public facility.
   B.   Definitions:
EXACTION: An in-kind contribution or donation (i.e., construction of sidewalk,
granting of easements, etc.).
IMPACT FEE: Direct fees assessed to cover public facilities improvements costs.
   C.   Determination: In order to protect and provide for the health, safety,
and general welfare of the residents, reasonable infrastructure exactions may
be required of individuals and developers based upon existing infrastructure or
lack of infrastructure in the area in which the construction is proposed in
order to provide adequate public facilities necessary to service new
development, the need for such facilities having been created by the new
development.
   D.   Method Of Assessing: The City Council may establish exaction
requirements by resolution based on infrastructure needs to adequately provide
for the health, safety and general welfare of the citizens. Exaction
determination shall be made by the City Council on a case-by-case basis of
which public facility improvements shall be required, which shall include, but
not be limited to, water, sewer, electric, fire hydrants, streets, sidewalks,
curbs and storm drainage.
   E.   Annexation Exactions: A condition of annexation shall not be limited
to, but may include an exaction of water rights based on the equivalent
residential connection usage formula as adopted by resolution. (Ord. 96-147, 6-
18-1996)
9-4-2: AMENDMENTS:
This chapter or the articles contained herein shall never be interpreted or
advanced to preclude or restrict the right of the City to amend this chapter
(or the individual articles therein) or to adopt future impact fees. (Ord. 08-
02, 5-6-2008)
9-4-3: PENALTY:
Commencement of construction without payment of impact fees shall be punishable
as a Class C misdemeanor, subject to penalty as provided in title 1, chapter 4
of this Code. (Ord. 96-147, 6-18-1996; amd. 2019 Code)
ARTICLE A. WATER IMPACT FEES
SECTION:

9-4A-1: FINDINGS AND PURPOSE:
The City Council hereby finds and determines:
   A.   There is a need for public facilities for development activity, which
need be consistent with the City General Plan and to protect the public health,
safety and welfare.
   B.   The continuing growth of the City necessitates the imposition and
collection of impact fees that requires development to pay its fair share of
the cost of providing public facilities occasioned by the demands and needs of
the development project as service levels necessary to promote and preserve the
public health, safety and welfare. (Ord. 00-03, 3-7-2000; amd. Ord. 22-25, 12-
20-2022; Ord. 22-26, 12-20-2022)

9-4A-3: WASTEWATER SYSTEM IMPACT FEE ANALYSIS ADOPTED:
The City Council hereby adopts the report from Sunrise Engineering, Inc., dated
November 10, 2022, entitled, "Fillmore City Wastewater System Impact Fee
Analysis." Said Fillmore City Wastewater System Impact Fee Analysis and
Amendment are set forth as Exhibit B on file in the City and is incorporated
herein by reference. (Ord. 00-03, 3-7-2000; amd. Ord. 22-25, 12-20-2022; Ord.
22-26, 12-20-2022)
9-4A-4: SERVICE AREA ESTABLISHED:
The City shall constitute a single service area and all real property located
within the corporate boundaries of the City shall be included within such
service area as well as adjacent areas, as approved by the City Council, that
are served by the Fillmore City Wastewater System. (Ord. 00-03, 3-7-2000; amd.
Ord. 22-25, 12-20-2022; Ord. 22-26, 12-20-2022)
9-4A-5: IMPACT FEES LEVIED:
The impact fees for the Service Area are hereby established and levied and will
be contained in the City fee schedule as follows:
 
              ERC1 Impact Fee - Wastewater
Residential   1    $9,583.59
Commercial    For non-residential connections, the ERC will be determined based
Industrial    up the higher of anticipated volume or concentration of loads
Institutional (e.g., if a commercial connection discharges four times the
              amount of wastewater of four times as concentrated discharge as a
City          residential connection, the impact fee will total $38,334.36)

1   "In [the Fillmore City Wastewater System Impact Fee Analysis], reference
will be made to Equivalent Residential Connections (ERCs). One ERC is defined
as the amount of wastewater [that] is generated by an average residential
connection. In accordance with the City's wastewater master plan, an average
residential connection is expected to use 300 gallons per day for ERC. Because
an ERC relates to the amount of water required for the average residential
connection, use of this term allows commercial, institutional, or other water
users to be equated to a residential connection. An ERC is also anticipated to
have a wastewater strength equivalent to the average municipal loading waste.
Users that discharge wastewater containing higher concentrations of BOD will be
equated to an ERC based upon the anticipated loadings. ERCs are factored into
calculations for impact fees, user rates, and other analyses as required for
design purposes. The wastewater master plan analysed wastewater production per
connection type. Commercial connections are assigned an ERC value of 4.
Industrial connections are assigned an ERC value of 16." Fillmore City
Wastewater System Impact Fee Analysis, § 6.2, Calculation of ERC, p. 8.
 
(Ord. 00-03, 3-7-2000; amd. Ord. 22-25, 12-20-2022; Ord. 22-26, 12-20-2022)
9-4A-6: TIME OF COLLECTION:
Unless otherwise provided by the City Council, impact fees shall be payable
prior to or at the time of the issuance of a building permit by the City. In no
event can a developer prepay impact fees prior to applying for a building
permit. (Ord. 00-03, 3-7-2000; amd. Ord. 22-25, 12-20-2022; Ord. 22-26, 12-20-
2022)
9-4A-7: USE OF FEES:
The fees shall be used solely as allowed under the Impact Fees Act. (Ord. 00-
03, 3-7-2000; amd. Ord. 22-25, 12-20-2022; Ord. 22-26, 12-20-2022)
9-4A-8: ADJUSTMENTS, CREDITS, AND REIMBURSEMENTS:
   A.   Adjustments. The City may, upon a proper showing, adjust (but not above
the maximum allowable fee) the standard impact fee at the time the fee is
charged:
      1.   To respond to unusual circumstances in specific cases or a request
for a prompt and individualized impact fee review for the development activity
of the state, a school district, or a charter school and an offset or credit
for a public facility for which an impact fee has been or will be collected;
and ensure that the impact fees are imposed fairly;
      2.   Upon the City's review and approval of studies and data submitted by
a developer showing a substantial discrepancy between the fee being assessed
and the actual impact of the development activity on the system.
   B.   Credits/Reimbursements. A developer, including a school district or
charter school, may be allowed a credit against or proportionate reimbursement
of impact fees if the developer dedicates land for a system improvement; builds
and dedicates some or all of a system improvement; or dedicates a public
facility that Fillmore City and the developer agree will reduce the need for a
system improvement. A credit against impact fees shall be granted for any
dedication of land for, improvement to, or new construction of, any system
improvements provided by the developer if the facilities are system
improvements to the respective utilities, or are dedicated to the public and
offset the need for an identified future improvement. (Ord. 00-03, 3-7-2000;
amd. Ord. 22-25, 12-20-2022; Ord. 22-26, 12-20-2022)
9-4A-9: EXEMPTIONS:
The following may be exempted from payment of the impact fee:
   A.   Alterations or expansion of an existing building where no additional
residential units or equivalent residential units are created and where the use
is not changed.
   B.   The construction of accessory buildings or structures where no
additional units or equivalent residential units are created and where the use
is not changed.
   C.   The replacement of a destroyed or partially destroyed building or
structure where no additional residential units or equivalent residential units
are created and where the use is not changed. (Ord. 00-03, 3-7-2000; amd. Ord.
22-25, 12-20-2022; Ord. 22-26, 12-20-2022)
9-4A-10: ACCOUNTING, EXPENDITURES AND REFUND:
The City shall account for, expend and refund impact fees in accordance with
the provisions of the Impact Fees Act. (Ord. 00-03, 3-7-2000; amd. Ord. 22-25,
12-20-2022; Ord. 22-26, 12-20-2022)
9-4A-11: CHALLENGES AND APPEALS:
The City adopts and incorporates herein Part 7, Challenges, of the Impact Fees
Act. (Ord. 00-03, 3-7-2000; amd. Ord. 22-25, 12-20-2022; Ord. 22-26, 12-20-
2022)
9-4A-12: ADMINISTRATIVE DEVELOPMENT FEES:
   A.   In addition to construction and dedication of any required public
improvements and the payment of impact fees, fees may also be established by
the City for building permits, excavation permits, filing of various
applications, inspection of improvements, site plan reviews, connection to
water facilities and other similar purposes. The amounts of these fees shall be
listed in the City fee schedule and may hereafter be set or amended by
resolution of the City Council.
   B.   No application or request shall be accepted or application taken
thereon until the applicant has paid to the City the required fees listed in
the City fee schedule applicable to such application or request. (Ord. 00-03,
3-7-2000; amd. Ord. 22-25, 12-20-2022; Ord. 22-26, 12-20-2022)
ARTICLE B. WASTEWATER IMPACT FEES
SECTION:
9-4B-1: Title
9-4B-2: Intent And Purpose
9-4B-3: Rules Of Construction
9-4B-4: Definitions
9-4B-5: Impact Fee District
9-4B-6: Imposition Of Impact Fee
9-4B-7: Computation Of Amount
9-4B-8: Biannual Fee Schedule Review
9-4B-9: Payment Of Fee
9-4B-10: Service Outside City Limits
9-4B-11: Trust Fund Established
9-4B-12: Use Of Funds
9-4B-13: Refund Of Fees Paid
9-4B-14: Exemptions And Credits
9-4B-15: Challenges And Appeals
9-4B-16: Enforcement
9-4B-1: TITLE:
This article shall be known and may be cited as the FILLMORE CITY WASTEWATER
IMPACT FEE ORDINANCE. (Ord. 08-02, 5-6-2008)
9-4B-2: INTENT AND PURPOSE:
   A.   This article is intended to assist in the implementation of the general
plan.
   B.   The purpose of this article is to regulate the use and development of
land so as to assure that new development bears its proportionate share of the
cost of capital expenditures necessary for public facility improvements in the
City. (Ord. 08-02, 5-6-2008)
9-4B-3: RULES OF CONSTRUCTION:
   A.   Purpose, Interest: The provisions of this article shall be liberally
construed so as to effectively carry out its purpose in the interest of the
public health, safety and welfare.
   B.   Specified: For the purpose of administration and enforcement, unless
otherwise stated in this article, the following rules of construction shall
apply to the text of this article:
      1.   In case of any difference of meaning or implication between the text
of this article and any caption, illustration, summary table or illustrative
table, the text shall control.
      2.   The word "shall" is always mandatory and not discretionary; the word
"may" is permissive.
      3.   Words used in the present tense shall include the future; words used
in the singular shall include plural; and the plural the singular, unless the
context clearly indicates the contrary.
      4.   The phrase "used for" includes "arranged for", "designed for", and
"maintained for", or "occupied for".
      5.   The word "person" includes an individual, a corporation, a
partnership, an association, or any other similar entity.
      6.   Unless the context clearly indicates the contrary, where a
regulation involves two (2) or more items, conditions, provisions or events
connected by the conjunction "and", "or", or "either...or", the conjunction
shall be interpreted as follows:
         a.   "And" indicates that all the connected terms, conditions,
provisions or events shall apply.
         b.   "Or" indicates that the connected items, conditions, provisions
or events shall apply singly but not in combination.
         c.   "Either...or" indicates that the connected items, conditions,
provisions or events shall apply singly but not in combination.
      7.   The word "includes" shall not limit a term to the specific example,
but is intended to extend its meaning to all other instances or circumstances
of like kind or character.
      8.   "City" means Fillmore City, Utah, a Utah Municipal corporation.
Unless otherwise specifically designated in a particular section, actions to be
undertaken by the City shall be at the direction of the Fillmore City Council
or the City officials, they may designate to carry out the administration of
this article or other provisions of this Code. (Ord. 08-02, 5-6-2008)
9-4B-4: DEFINITIONS:
The following words and phrases used in this article shall have the following
meanings, unless a different meaning clearly appears from the context:
CAPITAL IMPROVEMENTS: Includes public facility planning and engineering, land
acquisition, site improvements, building and equipment, but excludes
maintenance and operation.
DEVELOPMENT ORDER: A regulatory approval by Fillmore City.
FEE PAYER: A person applying for the issuance of a building permit or
manufactured home placement that will, in any way, be connecting to or
impacting the wastewater system.
PRIVATE RECREATIONAL FACILITY: Any recreational facility which is not owned by
or dedicated to any governmental entity.
STUDY: Refers to the Wastewater Impact Fee Study performed by Sunrise
Engineering, Inc., in 2006. (Ord. 08-02, 5-6-2008)
9-4B-5: IMPACT FEE DISTRICT:
There is hereby established a wastewater impact fee district. The entire City
is one Citywide district. (Ord. 08-02, 5-6-2008)
9-4B-6: IMPOSITION OF IMPACT FEE:
   A.   Payment Required: Any person who, after the effective date hereof,
seeks to develop land with the City by applying for a land use permit or
building installation, is hereby required to pay an impact fee in the manner
and set forth in the study completed by Sunrise Engineering, Inc., in 2006 and
in the amount imposed by this article.
   B.   Issuance Of Permit: No new building permit or new permit for
manufactured home installation, or for any activity requiring payment of an
impact fee pursuant to section
9-4B-9 of this article, shall be issued unless and until the impact fee hereby
required has been paid.
   C.   Extension: No extension of a building permit or permit for manufactured
home installation issued prior to the effective date hereof for any activity
requiring payment of an impact fee pursuant to section
9-4B-9 of this article shall be granted unless and until the impact fee hereby
required has been paid. (Ord. 08-02, 5-6-2008)
9-4B-7: COMPUTATION OF AMOUNT:
   A.   Amount: The amount of the impact fee shall be determined by the method
presented in the study completed by Sunrise Engineering, Inc., in 2006 and is
based on equivalent residential connections (ERCs). The impact fee imposed is
two thousand two hundred dollars ($2,200.00) per ERC, which amount is less than
can be imposed under the study.
      1.   If a building is requested for mixed uses, then the fee shall be
determined using the aforementioned method by apportioning the space committed
to uses specified in the method per equivalent residential dwelling units or as
referred to in the study an ERC. The initial amount of the impact fee is set
forth above. Any changes in amount shall be approved and published by
resolution to the City Council.
      2.   The aforementioned method determines the per unit fee for
residential uses. If the type of development activity that a building permit is
applied for is not a residential use, the City shall determine the fee on an
equivalent residential dwelling unit basis. The City shall be guided in the
determination of equivalent residential dwelling units by the study, supporting
documents of the Zoning Ordinance, Uniform Building Codes and any other
information the City deems appropriate. If the City determines that there are
no comparable equivalent residential dwelling units, then the City shall
determine the appropriate fee by considering demographic or other documentation
which is available from State, local and regional authorities.
      3.   In the case of change of use, redevelopment or expansion or
modification of an existing use which required the issuance of a building
permit or manufactured home placement permit, the impact fee shall be based
upon the net positive increase in the impact fee for the new use as compared to
the previous use.
   B.   Independent Calculation Study: If a fee payer opts not to have the
impact fee determined according to subsection A of this section, then the fee
payer shall prepare and submit to the Mayor an independent fee calculation
study for the land development activity for which a building permit or
manufactured home placement permit is sought. The documentation submitted shall
show the basis upon which the independent fee calculation was made. The Mayor
shall consider the documentation submitted by the fee payer, but is not
required to accept such documentation as the Mayor reasonably deems to be
inaccurate or not reliable and may require the fee payer to submit additional
or different documentation for consideration. If an acceptable independent fee
calculation study is not presented, the fee payer shall pay the impact fee
based upon ERCs as applied in subsection A of this section. If an acceptable
independent fee calculation study is presented, the Mayor may adjust the fee to
that appropriate to the particular development. Determinations made by the
Mayor pursuant to this subsection may be appealed to the City Council by filing
a written appeal request with the City Recorder within ten (10) days of the
determination. (Ord. 08-02, 5-6-2008)
9-4B-8: BIANNUAL FEE SCHEDULE REVIEW:
The fee schedule contained in subsection 9-4B-7A of this article shall be
reviewed by the City Council at least once each fiscal biennium (i.e., every 2
years). Any new or changed fee amounts shall be approved and published by
resolution of the City Council. (Ord. 08-02, 5-6-2008)
9-4B-9: PAYMENT OF FEE:
   A.   Required: The fee payer shall pay the wastewater impact fee required by
this article to the City prior to the issuance of a land use permit or building
permit or a permit for manufactured home installation.
   B.   Funds Collected: All funds collected shall be properly identified by
impact fee type and district and promptly transferred for deposit in the
appropriate Impact Fee Trust Fund to be held in separate accounts as determined
by section
9-4B-11 of this article and used solely for the purposes specified in this
article. (Ord. 08-02, 5-6-2008)
9-4B-10: SERVICE OUTSIDE CITY LIMITS:
No service outside City limits is allowed under this article, unless the City
Council approves each service connection on an individual basis. (Ord. 08-02,
5-6-2008)
9-4B-11: TRUST FUND ESTABLISHED:
   A.   Separate Fund: There is hereby established a separate Impact Fee Trust
Fund for wastewater facilities.
   B.   Use: Funds withdrawn from this account must be used in accordance with
the provision of section
9-4B-12 of this article. (Ord. 08-02, 5-6-2008)
9-4B-12: USE OF FUNDS:
   A.   Capital Improvements: Funds collected from impact fees shall be used
solely for the purpose of acquiring and/or making capital improvements and
their related costs to public facilities under jurisdiction of the City.
   B.   Identified Use: Funds shall be used exclusively for acquisitions,
expansions or capital improvements within the Wastewater Impact Fee District,
as identified in the study, from which the funds were collected and only for
wastewater collection and treatment facilities. Funds shall be expended in the
order in which they are collected.
   C.   Payment Of Bonds: In the event that bonds or similar debt instruments
are issued for advance provision of capital facilities for which impact fees
may be expended, the impact fee may be used to pay debt service on such bonds
or similar debt instruments to the extent that the facilities provided are of
the type described in subsection A of this section and are located within the
appropriate impact fees district created by section
9-4B-5 of this article, or as provided in subsection B of this section.
   D.   Proposed Capital Improvements Program Submitted: At least once each
fiscal period the Mayor shall present to the City Council a proposed capital
improvements program for the public facilities, assigning funds, including any
accrued interest from the several impact fee trust funds, to specific public
improvement projects and related expenses. Monies, including any accrued
interest, not assigned in any fiscal period shall be retained in the same
impact fee trust funds until the next fiscal period, except as provided by the
refund provisions of this article.
   E.   Previously Incurred Costs: Funds may be used for wastewater collection
and treatment facility costs previously incurred by the City for the extent
that new growth and development will be served by the previously constructed
improvement.
   F.   Refunds: Funds may be used to provide refunds as described in section
9-4B-13 of this article. (Ord. 08-02, 5-6-2008)
9-4B-13: REFUND OF FEES PAID:
   A.   Expiration Without Commencement Of Construction: If a building permit
or manufactured home placement permit expires without commencement of
construction, the fees have not been spent or encumbered, and no impact has
resulted, the fee payer shall be entitled to a refund, with interest at the
rate the City has received on the fee, of the impact fee paid as a condition
for its issuance, except that the City shall retain ten percent (10%) of the
fee to offset a portion of the cost of collection and refund. The fee payer
must submit an application for such refund to the City within thirty (30) days
of the expiration of the permit.
   B.   Unexpended Funds: Except as provided in Utah Code Annotated section 11-
36a-603, or its successor section, any funds not expended or encumbered by the
end of the calendar quarter immediately following six (6) years from the date
the impact fee was paid shall, upon application of the then current landowner,
be returned to such landowner with interest at the rate the City has received
on the fee; provided, that the landowner submits an application for a refund to
the City within one hundred eighty (180) days of the expiration of the six (6)
year period. (Ord. 08-02, 5-6-2008)
9-4B-14: EXEMPTIONS AND CREDITS:
   A.   Exemptions: The following may be exempted from payment of the impact
fee:
      1.   Alterations or expansions of an existing building where no
additional residential units or equivalent residential units are created and
where the use is not changed.
      2.   The construction of accessory buildings or structures where no
additional residential units or equivalent residential units are created and
where the use is not changed.
      3.   The replacement of a destroyed or partially destroyed building or
structure with a new building or structure of the same size and use.
      4.   The installation of a replacement mobile home on a lot or such site
when an impact fee for such mobile home site has previously been paid pursuant
to this article or where a mobile home legally existed on such a site on or
prior to the effective date hereof.
      5.   The construction of buildings by a government agency or other
development activities with a broad public purpose as determined by the City.
In the event that an exemption is granted, the City Council shall establish the
source of funding to pay for the impact of the development activity.
Any claim of exemption must be made no later than the time of application for a
building permit or permit for modular home installation. Any claim not so made
shall be deemed waived.
   B.   Credits:
      1.   Public capital improvements may be offered by the fee payer as total
or partial payment of the required impact fee. The offer must specifically
request or provide for an impact fee credit. If the City accepts such an offer,
whether the acceptance is before or after the effective date hereof, the credit
shall be determined and provided in the following manner:
         a.   Credit for the dedication of land shall be valued at one hundred
percent (100%) of the most recent assessed value by the County property
appraiser; by such other appropriate method as the City Council may have
accepted prior to the effective date hereof for particular public improvements;
or by fair market value established by private appraiser acceptable to the
City. Credit for the dedication of park land shall be provided when the
property has been conveyed at no charge to, and accepted by, the City in a
manner satisfactory to the City Council.
         b.   Applicants for credit for construction of public improvements
shall submit acceptable engineering drawings and specifications, and
construction costs estimates to the City. The City shall determine credit for
construction based upon either these cost estimates or upon alternative
engineering criteria and construction cost estimates performed by the City. The
City shall provide the applicant with a letter of certificate setting forth the
dollar amount of the credit, the reason for the credit, and the legal
description or other adequate description of the project or development to
which the credit may be applied. The applicant must sign and date a duplicate
copy of such letter or certificate and return such signed document to the City
before credit will be given. The failure of the applicant to sign, date and
return such document within sixty (60) days shall nullify the credit.
         c.   Except as provided in subsection B1d of this section, credit
against impact fees otherwise due will not be provided until:
            (1)   The construction is completed and accepted by the City;
            (2)   A suitable maintenance and warranty bond is received and
approved by the City, when applicable.
         d.   Credit may be provided before completion of specified public
improvements if adequate assurances are given by the applicant that the
standards set out in subsection B1c of this section will be met and if the fee
payer posts security as provided below for the costs of such construction.
Security in the form of a cash escrow agreement shall be posted with and
approved by the City at one hundred twenty five percent (125%) of the amount
determined by the City. Twenty five percent (25%) of the cash escrow account
shall remain for two (2) years after completion of the project, as a guarantee
of the work, pursuant to the City's cash bond escrow agreement. If the public
improvement construction project will not be constructed within one year of the
acceptance of the offer by the City, the amount of the security shall be
increased by ten percent (10%) compounded for each year of the life of the
security. The security shall be reviewed and approved by the City
representatives prior to acceptance of the security by the City Council. If the
public improvement construction project is not to be complete within five (5)
years of the date of the fee payer's offer, the City Council must approve the
public improvement construction project and its scheduled completion date prior
to the acceptance of the offer by the City.
      2.   The City need not approve the credit unless the dedication is for
public facilities identified in the study or other similar studies adopted by
the City or a capital facilities plan adopted by the City and such public
facilities are required by the City as a condition of approving the development
activity.
      3.   Any claim for credit must be made no later than the time of
application for a land use permit, building permit or permit for modular home
installation. Any claim not so made shall be deemed waived.
      4.   Credits shall not be transferable from one project or development to
another without the approval of the City Council.
      5.   Determinations made by the City pursuant to this section may be
appealed to the City Council by filing a written appeal with the City Recorder
within ten (10) days of the determination. (Ord. 08-02, 5-6-2008)
9-4B-15: CHALLENGES AND APPEALS:
Any challenges or appeals of this impact fee shall follow the procedures in
section
9-4A-11 of this chapter. (Ord. 08-02, 5-6-2008; amd. 2019 Code)
9-4B-16: ENFORCEMENT:
The City may enforce the provisions of this article by an action at law or in
equity in any court having jurisdiction. (Ord. 08-02, 5-6-2008)
ARTICLE C. CITY POWER SYSTEM IMPACT FEE
SECTION:
9-4C-1: Findings And Purpose
9-4C-2: Definitions
9-4C-3: Power System Impact Fee Analysis Adopted
9-4C-4: Service Area Establishment
9-4C-5: Impact Fees Levied
9-4C-6: Time Of Collection
9-4C-7: Use Of Fees
9-4C-8: Adjustments, Credits, And Reimbursements
9-4C-9: Exemptions
9-4C-10: Accounting, Expenditures, And Refund
9-4C-11: Challenges And Appeals
9-4C-12: Administrative Development Fees
9-4C-1: FINDINGS AND PURPOSE:
The City Council hereby finds and determines:
   A.   There is a need for public facilities for development activity, which
need be consistent with the City General Plan and to protect the public health,
safety and welfare.
   B.   The continuing growth of the City necessitates the imposition and
collection of impact fees that requires development to pay its fair share of
the cost of providing public facilities occasioned by the demands and needs of
the development project at service levels necessary to promote and preserve the
public health, safety and welfare. (Ord. 23-07, 4-18-2023)
9-4C-2: DEFINITIONS:
The following words and phrases used in this article shall have the following
meanings unless a different meaning clearly appears from the context:
   CAPITAL FACILITIES PLAN: Those portions of the Fillmore City Power System
Impact Fee Analysis and Fillmore City Power Master Plan which pertain to (i)
identifying the existing level of service; (ii) establishing a proposed level
of service; (iii) identifying any excess capacity to accommodate future growth
at the proposed level of service; (iv) identifying demands placed upon existing
public facilities by new development activity at the proposed level of service;
and (v) identifying the means by which the political subdivision or private
entity will meet those growth demands.
   CITY: Fillmore City, Utah, a Utah Municipal corporation.
   DEVELOPMENT ACTIVITY: Any construction or expansion of a building,
structure, or use, any change in use of a building or structure, or any changes
in the use of land that creates additional demand and need for public
facilities.
   DEVELOPMENT APPROVAL: Written authorization from the City that authorizes
the commencement of development activity.
   IMPACT FEE: A payment of money imposed upon new development activity as a
condition of development approval to mitigate the impact of the development on
public infrastructure. Impact fee does not mean a tax, a special assessment, a
building permit fee, a hookup fee, a fee for project improvements, or other
reasonable permit or application fee.
   PROJECT IMPROVEMENT: Site improvements and facilities that are:
   A.   Planned and designed to provide service for development resulting from
a development activity; and
   B.   Necessary for the use and convenience of the occupants or users of the
development resulting from a development activity.
   SERVICE AREA: The geographic area designated by the City in which a defined
set of public facilities provides service within the area.
   The IMPACT FEES ACT or the ACT: Title 11, Chapter 36a, Utah Code Annotated
or its successor state statute of that title and chapter if renumbered,
recodified, or amended.
(Ord. 23-07, 4-18-2023)
9-4C-3: POWER SYSTEM IMPACT FEE ANALYSIS ADOPTED:
The City Council hereby adopts the report from Dixie Power dated March 2023,
entitled, "Fillmore City Power System Impact Fee Analysis." Said Fillmore City
Power System Impact Fee Analysis is set forth as Exhibit B on file in the City
and is incorporated herein by reference.
(Ord. 23-07, 4-18-2023)
9-4C-4: SERVICE AREA ESTABLISHED:
The City shall constitute a single service area and all real property located
within the corporate boundaries of the City shall be included within such
service area as well as adjacent areas, as approved by the City Council, that
are served by the Fillmore City Power System.
(Ord. 23-07, 4-18-2023)
9-4C-5: IMPACT FEES LEVIED:
The impact fees for the Service Area are hereby established and levied and will
be contained in the City fee schedule as follows 1 :
"The impact fee per connection is calculated by multiplying the expected kVA
based on the connection type and panel rating per Table 6.1 [in the Fillmore
City Power Impact Fee Analysis] by the cost per kVA from Table 6.4 [in the
Fillmore City Power Impact Fee Analysis]. 2 "
(Ord. 23-07, 4-18-2023)
 
Notes
1    A recommended impact fee cost schedule is included in Exhibit B, Fillmore
  City Power System Impact Fee Analysis, Exhibit 7.
2    Fillmore City Power System Impact Fee Analysis, § 7.0, Conclusions and
  Recommendations, p. viii.
9-4C-6: TIME OF COLLECTION:
Unless otherwise provided by the City Council, impact fees shall be payable at
the time of the application or issuance of a building permit by the City. In no
event can a developer prepay impact fees prior to applying for a building
permit.
(Ord. 23-07, 4-18-2023)
9-4C-7: USE OF FEES:
The fees shall be used solely as allowed under the Impact Fees Act.
(Ord. 23-07, 4-18-2023)
9-4C-8: ADJUSTMENTS, CREDITS, AND REIMBURSEMENTS:
   A.   Adjustments. The City may, upon a proper showing, adjust (but not above
the maximum allowable fee) the standard impact fee at the time the fee is
charged:
      1.   To respond to unusual circumstances in specific cases or a request
for a prompt and individualized impact fee review for the development activity
of the state, a school district, or a charter school and an offset or credit
for a public facility for which an impact fee has been or will be collected;
and ensure that the impact fees are imposed fairly;
      2.   Upon the City's review and approval of studies and data submitted by
a developer showing a substantial discrepancy between the fee being assessed
and the actual impact of the development activity on the system.
   B.   Credits/Reimbursements. A developer, including a school district or
charter school, may be allowed a credit against or proportionate reimbursement
of impact fees if the developer dedicates land for a system improvement; builds
and dedicates some or all of a system improvement; or dedicates a public
facility that Fillmore City and the developer agree will reduce the need for a
system improvement. A credit against impact fees shall be granted for any
dedication of land for, improvement to, or new construction of, any system
improvements provided by the developer if the facilities are system
improvements to the respective utilities, or are dedicated to the public and
offset the need for an identified future improvement.
(Ord. 23-07, 4-18-2023)
9-4C-9: EXEMPTIONS:
The following may be exempted from payment of the impact fee:
   A.   Alterations or expansion of an existing building where no additional
demand and need for public facilities is created and where the use is not
changed.
   B.   The construction of accessory buildings or structures where no
additional demand and need for public facilities is created and where the use
is not changed.
   C.   The replacement of a destroyed or partially destroyed building or
structure where no additional demand and need for public facilities is created
and where the use is not changed.
(Ord. 23-07, 4-18-2023)
9-4C-10: ACCOUNTING, EXPENDITURES, AND REFUND:
The City shall account for, expend and refund impact fees in accordance with
the provisions of the Impact Fees Act.
(Ord. 23-07, 4-18-2023)
9-4C-11: CHALLENGES AND APPEALS:
The City adopts and incorporates herein Part 7, Challenges, of the Impact Fees
Act.
(Ord. 23-07, 4-18-2023)
9-4C-12: ADMINISTRATIVE DEVELOPMENT FEES:
